raw_output:
# Binance Cryptocurrency Market Data Service

This is a comprehensive MCP (Model Context Protocol) server that provides real-time cryptocurrency market data from Binance directly to AI agents. It enables seamless access to current prices, order books, candlestick charts, trading history, and price statistics without needing to visit external sites.

## Key Features

- **Real-time Market Data**: Access live cryptocurrency prices and market information
- **Order Book Data**: Get current bid/ask prices and market depth
- **Trading History**: Retrieve recent, historical, and aggregated trade data  
- **Candlestick Charts**: Access K-line data for technical analysis
- **Price Statistics**: Get 24-hour tickers, rolling window stats, and average prices
- **Multiple Data Formats**: Support for both full and mini data types

## Available Tools (12 total)

### Price & Market Data
- **get_price** - Get current prices for trading pairs
- **get_avg_price** - Get average price for a symbol
- **get_24hr_ticker** - Get 24-hour price change statistics
- **get_trading_day_ticker** - Get trading day ticker statistics
- **get_rolling_window_ticker** - Get rolling window price statistics

### Order Book & Trading
- **get_order_book** - Get current order book depth (up to 5000 levels)
- **get_book_ticker** - Get best bid/ask prices and quantities

### Trading History
- **get_recent_trades** - Get recent trades (up to 1000)
- **get_historical_trades** - Get historical trade data
- **get_aggregate_trades** - Get aggregated trade data with time filtering

### Chart Data
- **get_klines** - Get candlestick/K-line data for technical analysis
- **get_ui_klines** - Get UI-optimized K-line data

## Common Parameters

- **symbol**: Trading pair symbol (e.g., "BTCUSDT", "ETHBTC")
- **symbols**: Array of multiple trading pairs for batch queries
- **interval**: Time intervals (1m, 3m, 5m, 15m, 30m, 1h, 2h, 4h, 6h, 8h, 12h, 1d, 3d, 1w, 1M)
- **limit**: Number of records to return (varies by endpoint, max 1000-5000)
- **startTime/endTime**: Timestamp filtering in milliseconds
- **timeZone**: Time zone specification (default UTC)

## Use Cases

- **Trading Analysis**: Get real-time market data for trading decisions
- **Price Monitoring**: Track cryptocurrency prices and market movements
- **Technical Analysis**: Access candlestick data for chart analysis
- **Market Research**: Analyze trading volumes and price trends
- **Portfolio Tracking**: Monitor multiple cryptocurrency pairs simultaneously

This server is perfect for AI agents that need to provide cryptocurrency market insights, trading analysis, or real-time price information without manual data fetching.

Plug-and-play components for flexible agent or agentic application design - üîÑ **Workflow System** - RAG, Chain of Thought, and Research workflows - üñºÔ∏è **Media Generation** - Image creation and processing capabilities - üé§ **Voice Processing** - Audio transcription and text-to-speech - üíæ **Vector Storage** - Knowledge retrieval with PostgreSQL/SQLite support - üõ†Ô∏è **Tool Integration** - Extensible tool framework with MCP support - üåê **Mesh Agent Access** - Connect to community-contributed specialized agents via API or MCP - üîå **Multi-platform Support**: - Telegram bot - Discord bot - Twitter automation - Farcaster integration - REST API - MCP integration ## Heurist Mesh ![mesh](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/77a2ab3b-e35c-4313-8a5b-a0e751cac879) **Heurist Mesh** is an open network where AI agents are contributed by the community and used modularly‚Äîsimilar to DeFi smart contracts. Each agent is a specialized unit that can process data, generate reports, or perform actions while collectively forming an intelligent swarm to tackle complex tasks. Each agent is accessible via a unified REST API interface, and can be used in conjunction with any agent framework or application. Want to contribute your own agent? Check out the [Mesh README](./mesh/README.md) for detailed guidelines, examples, and best practices. ### MCP Support **Just In:** All Heurist Mesh agents are accessible via MCP! This means you can access them from your favorite MCP client, including [Claude Desktop](https://claude.ai/download), [Cursor](https://www.cursor.com/), and [Windsurf](https://codeium.com/windsurf). Head to [heurist-mesh-mcp-server](https://github.com/heurist-network/heurist-mesh-mcp-server) to set up a server and give your AI assistant a powerup. ### Recommended Mesh Agents ‚Ä¢ [BitquerySolanaTokenInfoAgent](./mesh/agents/bitquery_solana_token_info_agent.py) - Provides comprehensive analysis of Solana tokens including metrics, holders, trading activity, and trending token discovery ‚Ä¢ [CoinGeckoTokenInfoAgent](./mesh/agents/coingecko_token_info_agent.py) - Fetches token information, market data, trending coins, and category data from CoinGecko ‚Ä¢ [DexScreenerTokenInfoAgent](./mesh/agents/dexscreener_token_info_agent.py) - Fetches real-time DEX trading data and token information across multiple chains ‚Ä¢ [ElfaTwitterIntelligenceAgent](./mesh/agents/elfa_twitter_intelligence_agent.py) - Analyzes tokens, topics or Twitter accounts using Twitter data, highlighting smart influencers ‚Ä¢ [ExaSearchAgent](./mesh/agents/exa_search_agent.py) - Searches the web and provides direct answers to questions ‚Ä¢ [GoplusAnalysisAgent](./mesh/agents/goplus_analysis_agent.py) - Fetches and analyzes security details of blockchain token contracts ‚Ä¢ [MetaSleuthSolTokenWalletClusterAgent](./mesh/agents/metasleuth_sol_token_wallet_cluster_agent.py) - Analyzes wallet clusters holding Solana tokens to identify holder behavior, concentration, and potential market manipulation ‚Ä¢ [PumpFunTokenAgent](./mesh/agents/pumpfun_token_agent.py) - Analyzes Pump.fun toke [...truncated for length...]', 'tools': [], 'tools_count': 0, 'homepage': '', 'url': 'https://github.com/heurist-network/heurist-agent-framework/tree/main/mesh', 'topics': ['agentic-framework', 'ai', 'mcp', 'agentic-ai'], 'data_sources': ['official']}
raw_output:
# Heurist Mesh Network MCP Server

This MCP server provides access to the **Heurist Mesh network** - a specialized ecosystem of web3 AI agents designed for blockchain analysis, smart contract security, token metrics, and blockchain interactions.

## What is Heurist Mesh?

Heurist Mesh is an open network where AI agents are contributed by the community and used modularly‚Äîsimilar to DeFi smart contracts. Each agent is a specialized unit that can process data, generate reports, or perform actions while collectively forming an intelligent swarm to tackle complex tasks.

## Key Features

- üîó **Web3 Specialized Agents** - Access to dozens of specialized blockchain analysis agents
- üõ°Ô∏è **Smart Contract Security** - Security analysis and vulnerability detection tools
- üìä **Token Metrics** - Comprehensive token analysis and market data
- üîç **Blockchain Interactions** - Direct blockchain querying and transaction analysis
- üåê **Multi-Chain Support** - Agents covering Ethereum, Solana, and other major chains

## Recommended Agents Available

### Token Analysis
- **BitquerySolanaTokenInfoAgent** - Comprehensive Solana token analysis including metrics, holders, and trading activity
- **CoinGeckoTokenInfoAgent** - Market data, trending coins, and category data from CoinGecko
- **DexScreenerTokenInfoAgent** - Real-time DEX trading data across multiple chains
- **PumpFunTokenAgent** - Analysis of Pump.fun tokens

### Security & Intelligence
- **GoplusAnalysisAgent** - Security analysis of blockchain token contracts
- **ElfaTwitterIntelligenceAgent** - Token and account analysis using Twitter data
- **MetaSleuthSolTokenWalletClusterAgent** - Wallet cluster analysis for market manipulation detection

### Research & Discovery
- **ExaSearchAgent** - Web search with direct answers
- **Various specialized agents** for NFT analysis, DeFi protocols, and more

## Setup

To use this MCP server, you'll need:

1. A Heurist API key (get one free at https://heurist.ai/dev-access using code 'agent')
2. An MCP-compatible client like Claude Desktop, Cursor, or Windsurf

## Repository Structure

This server is part of the larger Heurist Agent Framework, which includes:
- Multi-platform support (Telegram, Discord, Twitter, Farcaster)
- Voice processing capabilities
- Vector storage for knowledge retrieval
- Extensible workflow system
- Component-based architecture

Perfect for developers and analysts working with blockchain data who want to leverage specialized AI agents for comprehensive web3 analysis and research.

raw_output:
# GOAT SDK - Onchain Agent Toolkit

## Overview
GOAT is the **largest agentic finance toolkit** for AI agents, enabling them to perform 200+ onchain actions across multiple blockchains including Ethereum, Solana, and Base.

## Key Features

### üéØ What Agents Can Do
- **Payments**: Send and receive cryptocurrency payments
- **Commerce**: Purchase physical and digital goods/services  
- **Investing**: 
  - Earn yield through DeFi protocols
  - Bet on prediction markets
  - Purchase crypto assets
- **Tokenization**: Create tokens for any asset
- **Analytics**: Get financial insights and data

### üèóÔ∏è Architecture
GOAT leverages blockchain infrastructure to make agents economic actors:

1. **Give agents a wallet** - Support for multiple wallet types
2. **Enable transactions anywhere** - Multi-chain compatibility
3. **Access 200+ tools** - Comprehensive toolkit
4. **Use any agent framework** - Framework agnostic

### ‚ö° Design Philosophy
- **Lightweight**: Minimal core with modular components
- **Extendable**: Install only the tools you need
- **Flexible**: Easy to add custom plugins, chains, wallets, and frameworks
- **Open Source**: MIT licensed

## Use Cases

### Money Transmission
Send and receive payments across:
- EVM chains (Ethereum, Base, etc.)
- Solana
- Chromia, Cosmos, Fuel, Radix, Zetrix

### Commerce
- Purchase items on Amazon using crypto
- Buy digital goods and services

### DeFi & Investing
- Yield farming and liquidity provision
- Prediction market participation (Polymarket)
- Token swapping and portfolio management

### Tokenization
- Create NFTs and fungible tokens
- Tokenize real-world assets

## Getting Started

The SDK provides quickstarts for different use cases across multiple chains and frameworks. Each example can be adapted to work with any supported chain, wallet, or agent framework.

## Community & Development

- **GitHub**: [goat-sdk/goat](https://github.com/goat-sdk/goat)
- **Languages**: TypeScript and Python support
- **Sponsored by**: Crossmint
- **License**: MIT

GOAT makes it easy for developers to create financially-capable AI agents that can interact with the broader crypto ecosystem through a simple, unified interface.

    Get transactions for an address within a specific time range.

      - `get_transactions_by_address(address, age_from)` - get all transactions to/from the address since the given date up to the current time
      - `get_transactions_by_address(address, age_from, age_to)` - get all transactions to/from the address between the given dates
      - `get_transactions_by_address(address, age_from, age_to, methods)` - get all transactions to/from the address between the given dates and invoking the given method signature
    Manipulating `age_from` and `age_to` allows you to paginate through results by time ranges.
    ', 'inputSchema': {'type': 'object', 'title': 'get_transactions_by_addressArguments', 'required': ['chain_id', 'address'], 'properties': {'age_to': {'anyOf': [{'type': 'string'}, {'type': 'null'}], 'title': 'Age To', 'default': None, 'description': 'End date and time (e.g 2025-05-22T22:30:00.00Z).'}, 'address': {'type': 'string', 'title': 'Address', 'description': 'Address which either sender or receiver of the transaction'}, 'methods': {'anyOf': [{'type': 'string'}, {'type': 'null'}], 'title': 'Methods', 'default': None, 'description': 'A method signature to filter transactions by (e.g 0x304e6ade)'}, 'age_from': {'anyOf': [{'type': 'string'}, {'type': 'null'}], 'title': 'Age From', 'default': None, 'description': 'Start date and time (e.g 2025-05-22T23:00:00.00Z).'}, 'chain_id': {'type': 'string', 'title': 'Chain Id', 'description': 'The ID of the blockchain'}}}, 'source': 'smithery', 'access_level': 'write'}, {'name': 'get_token_transfers_by_address', 'description': '
    Get ERC-20 token transfers for an address within a specific time range.
    Use cases:
      - `get_token_transfers_by_address(address, age_from)` - get all transfers of any ERC-20 token to/from the address since the given date up to the current time
      - `get_token_transfers_by_address(address, age_from, age_to)` - get all transfers of any ERC-20 token to/from the address between the given dates
      - `get_token_transfers_by_address(address, age_from, age_to, token)` - get all transfers of the given ERC-20 token to/from the address between the given dates
    Manipulating `age_from` and `age_to` allows you to paginate through results by time ranges. For example, after getting transfers up to a certain timestamp, you can use that timestamp as `age_to` in the next query to get the next page of older transfers.
    ', 'inputSchema': {'type': 'object', 'title': 'get_token_transfers_by_addressArguments', 'required': ['chain_id', 'address'], 'properties': {'token': {'anyOf': [{'type': 'string'}, {'type': 'null'}], 'title': 'Token', 'default': None, 'description': 'An ERC-20 token contract address to filter transfers by a specific token. If omitted, returns transfers of all tokens.'}, 'age_to': {'anyOf': [{'type': 'string'}, {'type': 'null'}], 'title': 'Age To', 'default': None, 'description': 'End date and time (e.g 2025-05-22T22:30:00.00Z). Can be omitted to get all transfers up to the current time.'}, 'address': {'type': 'string', 'title': 'Address', 'description': 'Address which either transfer initiator or transfer receiver'}, 'age_from': {'anyOf': [{'type': 'string'}, {'type': 'null'}], 'title': 'Age From', 'default': None, 'description': 'Start date and time (e.g 2025-05-22T23:00:00.00Z). This parameter should be provided in most cases to limit transfers and avoid heavy database queries. Omit only if you absolutely need the full history.'}, 'chain_id': {'type': 'string', 'title': 'Chain Id', 'description': 'The ID of the blockchain'}}}, 'source': 'smithery', 'access_level': 'write'}, {'name': 'lookup_token_by_symbol', 'description': '

    Get comprehensive information about an address, including:

    ', 'inputSchema': {'type': 'object', 'title': 'get_address_infoArguments', 'required': ['chain_id', 'address'], 'properties': {'address': {'type': 'string', 'title': 'Address', 'description': 'Address to get information about'}, 'chain_id': {'type': 'string', 'title': 'Chain Id', 'description': 'The ID of the blockchain'}}}, 'source': 'smithery', 'access_level': 'write'}, {'name': 'get_tokens_by_address', 'description': '

    Get human-readable transaction summaries from Blockscout Transaction Interpreter.

    Note: Not all transactions can be summarized and accuracy is not guaranteed for complex patterns.
    ', 'inputSchema': {'type': 'object', 'title': 'transaction_summaryArguments', 'required': ['chain_id', 'transaction_hash'], 'properties': {'chain_id': {'type': 'string', 'title': 'Chain Id', 'description': 'The ID of the blockchain'}, 'transaction_hash': {'type': 'string', 'title': 'Transaction Hash', 'description': 'Transaction hash'}}}, 'source': 'smithery', 'access_level': 'read'}, {'name': 'nft_tokens_by_address', 'description': "
    Retrieve NFT tokens (ERC-721, ERC-404, ERC-1155) owned by an address, grouped by collection.
    Provides collection details (type, address, name, symbol, total supply, holder count) and individual token instance data (ID, name, description, external URL, metadata attributes).
    Essential for a detailed overview of an address's digital collectibles and their associated collection data.
    ", 'inputSchema': {'type': 'object', 'title': 'nft_tokens_by_addressArguments', 'required': ['chain_id', 'address'], 'properties': {'cursor': {'anyOf': [{'type': 'string'}, {'type': 'null'}], 'title': 'Cursor', 'default': None, 'description': 'The pagination cursor from a previous response to get the next page of results.'}, 'address': {'type': 'string', 'title': 'Address', 'description': 'NFT owner address'}, 'chain_id': {'type': 'string', 'title': 'Chain Id', 'description': 'The ID of the blockchain'}}}, 'source': 'smithery', 'access_level': 'write'}, {'name': 'get_transaction_info', 'description': '
    Get comprehensive transaction information. 
    Unlike standard eth_getTransactionByHash, this tool returns enriched data including decoded input parameters, detailed token transfers with token metadata, transaction fee breakdown (priority fees, burnt fees) and categorized transaction types.
    By default, the raw transaction input is omitted if a decoded version is available to save context; request it with `include_raw_input=True` only when you truly need the raw hex data.
    Essential for transaction analysis, debugging smart contract interactions, tracking DeFi operations.

    Get comprehensive transaction logs.
    Unlike standard eth_getLogs, this tool returns enriched logs, primarily focusing on decoded event parameters with their types and values (if event decoding is applicable).
    Essential for analyzing smart contract events, tracking token transfers, monitoring DeFi protocol interactions, debugging event emissions, and understanding complex multi-contract transaction flows.
    ', 'inputSchema': {'type': 'object', 'title': 'get_transaction_logsArguments', 'required': ['chain_id', 'transaction_hash'], 'properties': {'cursor': {'anyOf': [{'type': 'string'}, {'type': 'null'}], 'title': 'Cursor', 'default': None, 'description': 'The pagination cursor from a previous response to get the next page of results.'}, 'chain_id': {'type': 'string', 'title': 'Chain Id', 'description': 'The ID of the blockchain'}, 'transaction_hash': {'type': 'string', 'title': 'Transaction Hash', 'description': 'Transaction hash'}}}, 'source': 'smithery', 'access_level': 'read'}, {'name': 'get_address_logs', 'description': '
    Get comprehensive logs emitted by a specific address.
    Returns enriched logs, primarily focusing on decoded event parameters with their types and values (if event decoding is applicable).
    Essential for analyzing smart contract events emitted by specific addresses, monitoring token contract activities, tracking DeFi protocol state changes, debugging contract event emissions, and understanding address-specific event history flows.
    ', 'inputSchema': {'type': 'object', 'title': 'get_address_logsArguments', 'required': ['chain_id', 'address'], 'properties': {'cursor': {'anyOf': [{'type': 'string'}, {'type': 'null'}], 'title': 'Cursor', 'default': None, 'description': 'The pagination cursor from a previous response to get the next page of results.'}, 'address': {'type': 'string', 'title': 'Address', 'description': 'Account address'}, 'chain_id': {'type': 'string', 'title': 'Chain Id', 'description': 'The ID of the blockchain'}}}, 'source': 'smithery', 'access_level': 'write'}, {'name': 'get_chains_list', 'description': '
    Get the list of known blockchain chains with their IDs.
    Useful for getting a chain ID when the chain name is known. This information can be used in other tools that require a chain ID to request information.
    ', 'inputSchema': {'type': 'object', 'title': 'get_chains_listArguments', 'properties': {}}, 'source': 'smithery', 'access_level': 'read'}], 'tools_count': 16, 'homepage': 'https://smithery.ai/server/@blockscout/mcp-server', 'url': '', 'topics': [], 'data_sources': ['smithery']}
raw_output:
# Blockscout MCP Server

The **Blockscout MCP Server** is a powerful blockchain data integration tool that provides AI agents and automation systems with contextual access to comprehensive blockchain information across multiple chains.

## Overview

This MCP server enables seamless integration between AI hosts (like Claude Desktop) and blockchain data, offering real-time access to balances, tokens, NFTs, smart contracts, and transaction details. It's designed to enhance blockchain data analysis with progress notifications for long-running queries and multi-chain support.

## Key Features

### üîó Multi-Chain Support
- Access data across multiple blockchain networks
- Get chain information and IDs for supported networks
- Consistent API across different blockchains

### üí∞ Financial Data
- **Address Analysis**: Comprehensive address information including balances, contract status, and ENS names
- **Token Holdings**: Detailed ERC-20 token portfolios with market data and metadata
- **NFT Collections**: Complete NFT ownership data (ERC-721, ERC-404, ERC-1155) with collection details

### üìä Transaction Intelligence
- **Transaction Summaries**: Human-readable transaction descriptions via Blockscout Transaction Interpreter
- **Detailed Transaction Info**: Enriched transaction data with decoded parameters and fee breakdowns
- **Transaction History**: Time-filtered transaction queries with method signature filtering
- **Token Transfer Tracking**: Comprehensive ERC-20 transfer history with token-specific filtering

### üîç Smart Contract Tools
- **Contract ABI Retrieval**: Access to verified contract ABIs for function calls and data interpretation
- **Event Log Analysis**: Decoded smart contract events with parameter details
- **Proxy Contract Detection**: Identification of proxy contracts and their implementations

### üß± Block Data
- **Block Information**: Detailed block data including gas usage, fees, and transaction counts
- **Latest Block Tracking**: Real-time blockchain state monitoring
- **Transaction Lists**: Optional transaction hash inclusion for block analysis

## Available Tools

### Essential Setup
- `__get_instructions__` - **Must be called first** - Initializes the MCP server

### Address & Identity
- `get_address_info` - Comprehensive address analysis
- `get_address_by_ens_name` - ENS domain resolution
- `get_tokens_by_address` - ERC-20 token holdings
- `nft_tokens_by_address` - NFT collection ownership

### Transaction Analysis
- `get_transactions_by_address` - Transaction history with time/method filtering
- `get_token_transfers_by_address` - ERC-20 transfer tracking
- `get_transaction_info` - Detailed transaction data with decoded parameters
- `transaction_summary` - Human-readable transaction descriptions
- `get_transaction_logs` - Decoded event logs for transactions

### Smart Contracts
- `get_contract_abi` - Contract interface retrieval
- `get_address_logs` - Contract event history

### Blockchain Data
- `get_block_info` - Block details and metadata
- `get_latest_block` - Current blockchain state
- `get_chains_list` - Supported blockchain networks

### Token Discovery
- `lookup_token_by_symbol` - Find tokens by symbol or name

## Use Cases

### üìà Portfolio Analysis
- Track wallet holdings across multiple tokens and NFTs
- Monitor transaction history and patterns
- Analyze DeFi positions and activities

### üîç Blockchain Investigation
- Investigate suspicious addresses and transactions
- Trace token flows and contract interactions
- Analyze smart contract behavior and events

### ü§ñ AI-Powered Analytics
- Generate insights from blockchain data
- Create automated reports and summaries
- Build intelligent blockchain monitoring systems

### üõ†Ô∏è Developer Tools
- Debug smart contract interactions
- Analyze transaction failures and gas usage
- Monitor contract events and state changes

## Getting Started

1. **Initialize**: Always call `__get_instructions__` first
2. **Choose Chain**: Use `get_chains_list` to find supported blockchain IDs
3. **Analyze**: Use the various tools to gather blockchain intelligence
4. **Paginate**: Use cursor-based pagination for large datasets

The Blockscout MCP Server transforms raw blockchain data into actionable insights, making it an essential tool for AI-powered blockchain analysis and automation.

# Baidu AI Search Server

This is the **Baidu AI Search** MCP server that provides web search capabilities using Baidu Cloud's AI Search technology. It's part of the AppBuilder-SDK ecosystem from Baidu Intelligent Cloud Qianfan platform.

## What is AppBuilder-SDK?

AppBuilder-SDK is a comprehensive client SDK for AI native application developers, offering a one-stop development platform. It provides essential capabilities for AI application development including:

### Key Features

**üîß Invocation Capabilities:**
- **Large Model Access**: Call models from Baidu Intelligent Cloud Qianfan platform with custom prompt development
- **40+ Component Library**: High-quality components from Baidu's ecosystem for Agent applications
- **AI Native Applications**: Access and manage applications published on the web console

**‚öôÔ∏è Orchestration:**
- **Knowledge Base Management**: Configure and manage knowledge bases with document operations
- **Workflow Orchestration**: Multi-level workflow abstraction with integration to LangChain, OpenAI, etc.

**üìä Monitoring:**
- **Visual Tracing**: Comprehensive monitoring tools with detailed debug logs for production environments

**üöÄ Deployment:**
- **API Services**: Deploy as Flask + gunicorn based API services
- **Interactive Frontend**: Deploy as Chainlit-based conversational interfaces
- **Cloud Deployment**: Quick deployment to Baidu Cloud with public API services

## Installation

### Requirements
- Python >= 3.9

### Install via pip
```bash
python3 -m pip install --upgrade appbuilder-sdk
```

## Quick Start Example

Here's a simple example of using the large model capabilities:

```python
import appbuilder
import os

# Set environment TOKEN (trial token with limited access/QPS)
os.environ["APPBUILDER_TOKEN"] = "bce-v3/ALTAK-n5AYUIUJMarF7F7iFXVeK/1bf65eed7c8c7efef9b11388524fa1087f90ea58"

# Define prompt template
template_str = "You play the role of {role}, please answer my question.\n\nQuestion: {question}.\n\nAnswer:"

# Define input and call playground component
input = appbuilder.Message({
    "role": "java engineer", 
    "question": "Please briefly explain Java's memory garbage collection mechanism in under 100 words"
})

playground = appbuilder.Playground(
    prompt_template=template_str, 
    model="Qianfan-Agent-Speed-8K"
)

# Stream the response like a typewriter
output = playground(input, stream=True, temperature=1e-10)
for stream_message in output.content:
    print(stream_message, end="")
```

## RAG Application Components

The SDK provides comprehensive components for building enterprise-grade RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation) applications:

| Stage | Component | Type |
|-------|-----------|------|
| Document Parsing | DocCropEnhance, DocFormatConverter, DocParser | Basic Components |
| Document Chunking | DocSplitter | Basic Component |
| Vectorization | Embedding | Basic Component |
| Indexing & Retrieval | BaiduVectorDBRetriever, BaiduElasticSearchRetriever | Basic Components |
| Answer Generation | QAPairMining, SimilarQuestion, MRC | Advanced Components |

## Available Tools

This MCP server provides several tools for AI application development:

1. **RAG**: Core RAG application functionality
2. **Message**: Workflow abstraction for message handling
3. **AgentRuntime**: Deploy as Flask/gunicorn API services
4. **Playground**: Access to Qianfan platform models with custom prompts
5. **Language Support**: Python (3.9+), Java, and Go versions available

## Topics & Use Cases

- **AI Native Applications**: Build production-ready AI applications
- **Large Language Models**: Integration with ERNIE Bot and Qianfan models
- **RAG Systems**: Enterprise-grade retrieval-augmented generation
- **Agent Development**: Create intelligent agents with rich component library
- **Assistant APIs**: Build conversational AI assistants

This server bridges the gap between Baidu's powerful AI infrastructure and practical application development, making it easier to build sophisticated AI-powered applications.

{'server_name': 'remote-mcp-server-demo', 'server_id': 'elithrar/remote-mcp-server-demo', 'description': '', 'readme': '# Remote MCP Server on Cloudflare Let's get a remote MCP server up-and-running on Cloudflare Workers complete with OAuth login! ## Develop locally ```bash # clone the repository git clone git@github.com:cloudflare/ai.git # install dependencies cd ai npm install # run locally npx nx dev remote-mcp-server ``` You should be able to open [`http://localhost:8787/`](http://localhost:8787/) in your browser ## Connect the MCP inspector to your server To explore your new MCP api, you can use the [MCP Inspector](https://modelcontextprotocol.io/docs/tools/inspector). - Start it with `npx @modelcontextprotocol/inspector` - [Within the inspector](http://localhost:5173), switch the Transport Type to `SSE` and enter `http://localhost:8787/sse` as the URL of the MCP server to connect to, and click "Connect" - You will navigate to a (mock) user/password login screen. Input any email and pass to login. - You should be redirected back to the MCP Inspector and you can now list and call any defined tools!
## Connect Claude Desktop to your local MCP server The MCP inspector is great, but we really want to connect this to Claude! Follow [Anthropic's Quickstart](https://modelcontextprotocol.io/quickstart/user) and within Claude Desktop go to Settings > Developer > Edit Config to find your configuration file. Open the file in your text editor and replace it with this configuration: ```json { "mcpServers": { "math": { "command": "npx", "args": [ "mcp-remote", "http://localhost:8787/sse" ] } } } ``` This will run a local proxy and let Claude talk to your MCP server over HTTP When you open Claude a browser window should open and allow you to login. You should see the tools available in the bottom right. Given the right prompt Claude should ask to call the tool.
## Deploy to Cloudflare 1. `npx wrangler kv namespace create OAUTH_KV` 2. Follow the guidance to add the kv namespace ID to `wrangler.jsonc` 3. `npm run deploy` ## Call your newly deployed remote MCP server from a remote MCP client Just like you did above in "Develop locally", run the MCP inspector: `npx @modelcontextprotocol/inspector@latest` Then enter the `workers.dev` URL (ex: `worker-name.account-name.workers.dev/sse`) of your Worker in the inspector as the URL of the MCP server to connect to, and click "Connect". You've now connected to your MCP server from a remote MCP client. ## Connect Claude Desktop to your remote MCP server Update the Claude configuration file to point to your `workers.dev` URL (ex: `worker-name.account-name.workers.dev/sse`) and restart Claude ```json { "mcpServers": { "math": { "command": "npx", "args": [ "mcp-remote", "https://worker-name.account-name.workers.dev/sse" ] } } } ``` ## Debugging Should anything go wrong it can be helpful to restart Claude, or to try connecting directly to your MCP server on the command line with the following command. ```bash npx mcp-remote http://localhost:8787/sse ``` In some rare cases it may help to clear the files added to `~/.mcp-auth` ```bash rm -rf ~/.mcp-auth ``` ', 'tools': [{'name': 'SSE', 'description': 'and enter `http://localhost:8787/sse` as the URL of the MCP server to connect to, and click "Connect"', 'inputSchema': {'type': 'object', 'properties': {'url': {'type': 'string', 'description': 'URL or link to process'}}, 'required': ['url']}, 'source': 'readme', 'access_level': 'read'}], 'tools_count': 1, 'homepage': '', 'url': 'https://github.com/elithrar/remote-mcp-server-demo', 'topics': [], 'data_sources': ['github']}

This is a **Remote MCP Server Demo** that shows how to deploy an MCP (Model Context Protocol) server on Cloudflare Workers with OAuth authentication. It's a great example for learning how to build and deploy remote MCP servers.

## Key Features

- **Remote MCP Server**: Runs on Cloudflare Workers (not just locally)
- **OAuth Authentication**: Includes user authentication flow
- **SSE Transport**: Uses Server-Sent Events for communication
- **Math Tools**: Provides basic mathematical operations as MCP tools

## What You Can Do

### Local Development
1. **Run locally** with `npx nx dev remote-mcp-server`
2. **Test with MCP Inspector** at `http://localhost:8787/sse`
3. **Connect Claude Desktop** using the mcp-remote proxy

### Production Deployment
1. **Deploy to Cloudflare** using Wrangler
2. **Connect remotely** from any MCP client
3. **Use with Claude Desktop** via your deployed URL

## How to Get Started

```bash
# Clone and setup
git clone git@github.com:cloudflare/ai.git
cd ai
npm install

# Run locally
npx nx dev remote-mcp-server
```

Then connect via MCP Inspector or Claude Desktop using the SSE endpoint at `http://localhost:8787/sse`.

## Why This Is Useful

- **Learn remote MCP architecture** - Most examples are local-only
- **OAuth integration** - Shows how to add authentication
- **Production deployment** - Ready for real-world use
- **Cloudflare Workers** - Serverless, globally distributed

This is an excellent starting point if you want to build your own remote MCP servers that can be accessed by AI assistants from anywhere on the internet!

# click-mcp

A Python library that makes it incredibly easy to turn Click CLI applications into Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers, enabling AI agents to interact with your command-line tools programmatically.

## What it does

**click-mcp** provides a simple `@click_mcp` decorator that automatically converts your Click commands into MCP tools. With just one line of code, your CLI becomes accessible to AI agents through the standardized Model Context Protocol.

## Key Features

- **One-line integration**: Just add the `@click_mcp` decorator
- **Automatic tool generation**: Click commands become MCP tools automatically
- **Full Click support**: Works with nested command groups, options, and positional arguments
- **Stdio-based server**: Easy integration with AI agents and MCP clients
- **Customizable**: Configure server names and command names to fit your needs

## Quick Start

```python
import click
from click_mcp import click_mcp

@click_mcp(server_name="my-cli-app")
@click.group()
def cli():
    """Sample CLI application."""
    pass

@cli.command()
@click.option('--name', required=True, help='Name to greet')
def greet(name):
    """Greet someone."""
    click.echo(f"Hello, {name}!")

if __name__ == '__main__':
    cli()
```

Start the MCP server:
```bash
python my_app.py mcp
```

Now AI agents can invoke your CLI commands via MCP:
```json
{
  "type": "invoke",
  "tool": "greet",
  "parameters": {
    "name": "World"
  }
}
```

## Advanced Features

### Nested Command Groups
Complex CLI structures with subcommands are fully supported. Nested commands are exposed using dot notation (e.g., `users.create`, `users.delete`).

### Positional Arguments
Click's `@click.argument()` decorators are automatically converted to named parameters in the MCP tool schema.

### Customization Options
- **Custom MCP command name**: Change the default `mcp` command name
- **Custom server name**: Set a descriptive name for your MCP server
- **Full Click compatibility**: Works with all Click features including flags, options, and complex command structures

## Installation

```bash
pip install click-mcp
```

## Use Cases

Perfect for:
- Making existing CLI tools accessible to AI agents
- Building AI-powered automation workflows
- Creating structured interfaces for command-line utilities
- Enabling programmatic access to administrative tools

**click-mcp** bridges the gap between traditional command-line interfaces and modern AI agent interactions, making your CLI tools more powerful and accessible than ever before.

{'server_name': 'n8n-workflow-builder', 'server_id': 'makafeli/n8n-workflow-builder', 'description': 'MCP server for programmatically creating and managing n8n workflows', 'readme': '[![MseeP.ai Security Assessment Badge](https://mseep.net/pr/makafeli-n8n-workflow-builder-badge.png)](https://mseep.ai/app/makafeli-n8n-workflow-builder)

# n8n Workflow Builder MCP Server

This project provides an MCP server for managing n8n workflows. It offers functionality to list, create, update, delete, activate, and deactivate workflows through a set of defined tools.

**Important:**  
This version exclusively supports **npm** for package management and running the server. (npx support will be reintroduced in a future update.)

## Requirements

- Node.js (v14+ recommended)
- npm

## Extensive Installation Guide

### 1. Clone the Repository

Clone the repository from your preferred source. For example:

```bash
git clone https://github.com/makafeli/n8n-workflow-builder.git
```

Then, navigate to the project directory:

```bash
cd /root/n8n-workflow-builder
```

### 2. Install Dependencies

Install the necessary dependencies using npm:

```bash
npm install
```

This command will download and install all required packages as defined in the `package.json` file.

### 3. Build and Test

For testing and getting the server online, use the following commands:

- **Build the project:**  
  This compiles the TypeScript files and produces the executable JavaScript in the `build` directory.
  
  ```bash
  npm run build
  ```

- **Start the MCP Server:**  
  Launch the server using:
  
  ```bash
  npm start
  ```

The server will start and connect via stdio. You can check the console to see messages confirming that the server has started correctly.

### 4. Deployment

For testing purposes and to get the server online, use the build and start commands mentioned above. This basic workflow (install, build, start) is currently the recommended method.

### 5. Additional Configuration

Server configuration for [Cline](https://cline.bot) is managed via the `cline_mcp_settings.json` file. Ensure that the following environment variables are correctly set:

- `N8N_HOST`: Your n8n API host URL.
- `N8N_API_KEY`: Your n8n API key.

Example configuration in `cline_mcp_settings.json`:

```json
{
  "n8n-workflow-builder": {
    "command": "node",
    "args": ["/root/n8n-workflow-builder/build/index.js"],
    "env": {
      "N8N_HOST": "https://n8n.io/api/v1/",
      "N8N_API_KEY": "YOUR_N8N_API_KEY_HERE"
    },
    "disabled": false,
    "alwaysAllow": [
      "create_workflow",
      "create_workflow_and_activate",
      "update_workflow",
      "activate_workflow",
      "deactivate_workflow",
      "get_workflow",
      "delete_workflow"
    ],
    "autoApprove": []
  }
}
```

## Available Features

### MCP Tools

The following tools are defined in the server and can be accessed through your MCP client:

#### Workflow Management
- **list_workflows**: Lists all workflows from n8n.
- **create_workflow**: Creates a new workflow in n8n.
- **get_workflow**: Retrieves a workflow by its ID.
- **update_workflow**: Updates an existing workflow.
- **delete_workflow**: Deletes a workflow by its ID.
- **activate_workflow**: Activates a workflow by its ID.
- **deactivate_workflow**: Deactivates a workflow by its ID.

#### Execution Management
- **list_executions**: Lists all workflow executions with optional filters.
- **get_execution**: Retrieves details of a specific execution by its ID.
- **delete_execution**: Deletes an execution by its ID.

### MCP Resources

The server also provides the following resources for more efficient context access:

#### Static Resources
- **/workflows**: List of all available workflows in the n8n instance
- **/execution-stats**: Summary statistics about workflow executions

#### Dynamic Resource Templates
- **/workflows/{id}**: Detailed information about a specific workflow
- **/executions/{id}**: Detailed information about a specific execution

## Troubleshooting

- Ensure you are using npm (this version does not support npx).
- If you encounter any issues, try cleaning the build directory and rebuilding:
  ```bash
  npm run clean && npm run build
  ```
- Verify that your environment variables in `cline_mcp_settings.json` are correct.

## Future Enhancements

- Reintroduction of npx support.
- Additional tools and workflow features.
- Further enhancements to deployment and scaling.

## License

This project is licensed under the MIT License.

raw_output:
# n8n Workflow Builder MCP Server

This is an MCP (Model Context Protocol) server that provides programmatic access to n8n workflows, allowing you to create, manage, and monitor automation workflows through a standardized interface.

## Key Features

### Workflow Management
- **List workflows** - View all available workflows
- **Create workflows** - Build new automation workflows
- **Update workflows** - Modify existing workflows
- **Delete workflows** - Remove unwanted workflows
- **Activate/Deactivate** - Control workflow execution state

### Execution Monitoring
- **List executions** - View workflow run history with filtering
- **Get execution details** - Inspect specific workflow runs
- **Delete executions** - Clean up execution history
- **Execution statistics** - Monitor performance metrics

### MCP Resources
- Static resources for workflows and execution stats
- Dynamic templates for detailed workflow and execution data

## Installation & Setup

### Prerequisites
- Node.js (v14+)
- npm package manager
- n8n instance with API access

### Quick Start

1. **Clone and install:**
```bash
git clone https://github.com/makafeli/n8n-workflow-builder.git
cd n8n-workflow-builder
npm install
```

2. **Build and start:**
```bash
npm run build
npm start
```

3. **Configure for Cline:**
Create/update your `cline_mcp_settings.json`:

```json
{
  "n8n-workflow-builder": {
    "command": "node",
    "args": ["/path/to/n8n-workflow-builder/build/index.js"],
    "env": {
      "N8N_HOST": "https://your-n8n-instance.com/api/v1/",
      "N8N_API_KEY": "your-api-key-here"
    },
    "disabled": false,
    "alwaysAllow": [
      "create_workflow",
      "update_workflow",
      "activate_workflow",
      "deactivate_workflow"
    ]
  }
}
```

## Configuration

You'll need to set these environment variables:
- `N8N_HOST` - Your n8n API endpoint URL
- `N8N_API_KEY` - Your n8n API authentication key

## Use Cases

This MCP server is perfect for:
- **Automation Management** - Programmatically manage your n8n workflows
- **CI/CD Integration** - Deploy workflows as part of your development pipeline
- **Monitoring & Analytics** - Track workflow performance and execution history
- **Bulk Operations** - Manage multiple workflows efficiently
- **Development Workflows** - Create and test automation flows programmatically

## Security

The project includes a security assessment badge and follows MCP security best practices for tool access and approval workflows.

**Repository:** https://github.com/makafeli/n8n-workflow-builder

This server bridges the gap between n8n's powerful automation capabilities and programmatic workflow management, making it easier to integrate workflow automation into larger systems and development processes.

# DBHub - Universal Database MCP Server

DBHub is a comprehensive database gateway that implements the Model Context Protocol (MCP), allowing AI assistants to connect to and interact with multiple database types including PostgreSQL, MySQL, SQLite, DuckDB, and more.

## Key Features

### üîó Universal Database Connectivity
- **PostgreSQL** ‚úÖ
- **MySQL** ‚úÖ  
- **MariaDB** ‚úÖ
- **SQL Server** ‚úÖ
- **SQLite** ‚úÖ
- **Oracle** ‚úÖ
- **DuckDB** ‚úÖ

### üõ†Ô∏è Core Capabilities

**Database Resources:**
- Schema exploration (`db://schemas`)
- Table structure inspection (`db://schemas/{schema}/tables/{table}`)
- Index information (`db://schemas/{schema}/tables/{table}/indexes`)
- Stored procedure details (`db://schemas/{schema}/procedures/{procedure}`)

**SQL Operations:**
- **`execute_sql`** - Execute single or multiple SQL statements
- **`generate_sql`** - AI-powered SQL generation based on natural language
- **`explain_db`** - Get explanations of database elements and structures

## Quick Start

### Docker Installation
```bash
# PostgreSQL example
docker run --rm --init \
   --name dbhub \
   --publish 8080:8080 \
   bytebase/dbhub \
   --transport http \
   --port 8080 \
   --dsn "postgres://user:password@localhost:5432/dbname?sslmode=disable"
```

### Demo Mode
```bash
# Try with sample employee database
docker run --rm --init \
   --name dbhub \
   --publish 8080:8080 \
   bytebase/dbhub \
   --transport http \
   --port 8080 \
   --demo
```

### NPX Installation
```bash
npx @bytebase/dbhub
```

## Configuration

| Environment Variable | Description | Default |
|---------------------|-------------|---------|
| `DSN` | Database connection string | Required |
| `TRANSPORT` | Transport mode: `stdio` or `http` | `stdio` |
| `PORT` | HTTP server port | `8080` |
| `READONLY` | Restrict to read-only operations | `false` |

## Demo Endpoint

Try DBHub immediately with the demo endpoint:
**https://demo.dbhub.ai/message**

This connects to a sample employee database and can be used with Cursor or MCP Inspector to explore the functionality.

## Use Cases

- **Database Schema Exploration** - Understand database structure and relationships
- **SQL Query Generation** - Convert natural language to SQL queries
- **Data Analysis** - Execute complex queries and analyze results
- **Database Documentation** - Generate explanations of database elements
- **Multi-Database Management** - Work with different database systems through a unified interface

## Integration

DBHub works seamlessly with MCP-compatible clients:
- **Claude Desktop**
- **Cursor IDE** 
- **Other MCP Clients**

The server acts as a bridge between AI assistants and your databases, enabling natural language database interactions while maintaining security through configurable read-only modes.

Perfect for developers, data analysts, and anyone who needs to interact with databases using natural language through AI assistants.

{'server_name': 'GlutamateMCPServers', 'server_id': 'shadowclonelabs/glutamatemcpservers', 'description': 'Glutamate is a powerful desktop platform that simplifies the deployment and management of Model Context Protocol servers. It provides a user-friendly interface and robust tools for server administration, making it easier than ever to run and customize your MCP servers.', 'readme': '
# Glutamate MCP Servers Welcome to the Glutamate MCP Servers repository! This project contains a collection of MCPs (Model Context Protocol) servers that are made by gluamate team can be easily deployed and managed through the Glutamate platform. We support all stdio and sse servers by any creators. ## üé• Introduction Video

## About Glutamate [Glutamate](https://glutamateapp.com) is a powerful desktop platform that simplifies the deployment and management of Model Context Protocol servers. It provides a user-friendly interface and robust tools for server administration, making it easier than ever to run and customize your MCP servers. Key Features: - üîí All keys are securely stored locally - ‚ö° Install & Start/Stop MCP servers on your local machine - üíª Full support for both stdio & SSE protocols - üì¶ No Node.js installation required on your system - üéÅ 100% free to use , now and forever - Avaible on Windows , Linux and Mac (coming soon) ## Road Map: - [x] Auto Sync (server config and port) with any client (cursor , windsurf , cline , roocode etc..) (Added in v0.0.5) - [ ] Auto start of mcp severs on start of glutamate (based on user settings) - [ ] Oath login for mcps to fetch api keys - [ ] Versioning of MCP servers for easier management and updates - [ ] User submission of servers - [ ] Direct Updater of Glutamate ## Custom Made Servers Our repository includes several custom MCP servers that are created by Glutamate Team , We support all stdio and sse server that are node based on our glutamate app ### UI Assist Located in the `src/uiassist` directory, UI Assist is a specialized server that provides enhanced user interface capabilities for MCP servers. It offers: - Custom UI components - Improved user experience - Streamlined navigation - Modern interface design More servers will be added to this repository in the future, expanding the available options for MCP administrators. ## Getting Started 1. Visit [glutamateapp.com](https://glutamateapp.com) 2. Download the app 3. Choose your desired MCP server from the available options 4. Click to install and just connect ## Available MCP Servers (adding more everyday ) For a comprehensive list of available MCP servers and their descriptions, please see our [SERVERS.md](SERVERS.md) file. ## Contributing We welcome contributions to improve our MCP servers. Please feel free to submit pull requests, report issues, or suggest new features. ## Glutamate App Integration To integrate your MCP server with the Glutamate app, you need to create a metadata file that describes your server's capabilities. This helps the Glutamate app understand and properly integrate with your MCP server. ### Important Note for SSE Servers All SSE-type MCP servers must accept the `--port` command line argument to be supported in the Glutamate app. This allows the Glutamate app to dynamically assign ports and manage multiple server instances. Make sure your server implementation includes this functionality. ### Important Note for Connection Type The `connectionType` field in the metadata file must be specified in lowercase. Only two values are supported: - `"sse"` for Server-Sent Events - `"stdio"` for Standard Input/Output Any other value or capitalization will not be recognized by the Glutamate app. ### Creating Metadata File Create a file named `glutamate.json` in your project root with the following structure: ```json { "name": "UI Assist MCP Server", "description": "A Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that connects with the UI Assist Chrome extension to help with UI-based input in web development", "version": "0.1.0", "releaseDate": "YYYY-MM-DD", "author": "Your Name or Organization", "license": "MIT", "repositoryUrl": "https://github.com/username/repository", "implementationLanguage": "JavaScript", "connectionType": "sse", "runtimeRequirements": "Node.js", "packageName": "@glutamateapp/ui-assist", "color": "#HEXCOLOR", "tools": [ { "name": "get_selected_elements", "description": "Retrieves HTML elements that have been selected in the browser" }, { "name": "clear_selected_elements", "de [...truncated for length...]', 'tools': [{'name': 'connectionType', 'description': 'field in the metadata file must be specified in lowercase. Only two values are supported:', 'inputSchema': {'type': 'object', 'properties': {'file_path': {'type': 'string', 'description': 'File path or file to process'}, 'amount': {'type': 'number', 'description': 'Numeric amount or value'}}, 'required': ['file_path', 'amount']}, 'source': 'readme', 'access_level': 'read'}], 'tools_count': 1, 'homepage': 'https://glutamateapp.com/', 'url': 'https://github.com/ShadowCloneLabs/GlutamateMCPServers', 'topics': ['desktop-app', 'free', 'linux', 'macos', 'mcp', 'mcpservers', 'windows'], 'data_sources': ['github']}
raw_output:
# Glutamate MCP Servers

Glutamate is a powerful desktop platform that simplifies the deployment and management of Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers. It provides a user-friendly interface and robust tools for server administration, making MCP server management accessible to everyone.

## üåü Key Features

- **üîí Secure Local Storage**: All API keys are stored securely on your local machine
- **‚ö° Easy Management**: Install, start, and stop MCP servers with a single click
- **üíª Full Protocol Support**: Compatible with both stdio and SSE protocols
- **üì¶ Zero Dependencies**: No Node.js installation required on your system
- **üéÅ Completely Free**: 100% free to use, now and forever
- **üåç Cross-Platform**: Available on Windows and Linux (Mac coming soon)

## üöÄ Getting Started

1. Visit [glutamateapp.com](https://glutamateapp.com)
2. Download the Glutamate desktop app
3. Browse and select your desired MCP servers
4. Click to install and connect instantly

## üõ£Ô∏è Roadmap

- [x] **Auto Sync** - Automatic server config and port synchronization with clients (Cursor, Windsurf, Cline, etc.) ‚úÖ *Added in v0.0.5*
- [ ] **Auto Start** - Automatic MCP server startup based on user settings
- [ ] **OAuth Integration** - OAuth login for MCP servers to fetch API keys
- [ ] **Version Management** - Versioning system for easier server management and updates
- [ ] **Community Submissions** - User-contributed server submissions
- [ ] **Direct Updates** - Built-in Glutamate updater

## üîß For Developers

### Creating MCP Server Metadata

To integrate your MCP server with Glutamate, create a `glutamate.json` file in your project root:

```json
{
  "name": "Your MCP Server Name",
  "description": "Description of your server's capabilities",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "releaseDate": "2024-01-01",
  "author": "Your Name",
  "license": "MIT",
  "repositoryUrl": "https://github.com/username/repository",
  "implementationLanguage": "JavaScript",
  "connectionType": "sse", // or "stdio" (lowercase required)
  "runtimeRequirements": "Node.js",
  "packageName": "@your-org/your-server",
  "color": "#FF6B6B",
  "tools": [
    {
      "name": "tool_name",
      "description": "Tool description"
    }
  ]
}
```

### Important Requirements

- **SSE Servers**: Must accept the `--port` command line argument for dynamic port assignment
- **Connection Type**: Must be lowercase (`"sse"` or `"stdio"`)
- **Protocols**: Support for both stdio and SSE-based MCP servers

## ü§ù Community

- **Discord**: Join our community for support and discussions
- **GitHub**: Contribute to the project and report issues
- **YouTube**: Watch tutorials and introduction videos

## üìö Available Servers

The platform includes both custom-made servers by the Glutamate team and support for community-created MCP servers. New servers are added regularly to expand the available functionality.

Glutamate makes MCP server management simple, secure, and accessible for developers of all skill levels. Whether you're running local development tools or production services, Glutamate provides the interface and tools you need to manage your MCP ecosystem effectively.

Install dependencies: ```bash npm install ``` 2. Create a `.env` file based on `.env.example` and fill in your Jira credentials: ```env JIRA_HOST=https://your-domain.atlassian.net JIRA_EMAIL=your-email@example.com JIRA_API_TOKEN=your-api-token PORT=3000 ``` To get your Jira API token: 1. Log in to 2. Click "Create API token" 3. Copy the token and paste it in your `.env` file ## Development Run the development server: ```bash npm run dev ``` ## Build and Run Build the project: ```bash npm run build ``` Start the server: ```bash npm start ``` ## Cursor Integration To use this MCP server with Cursor, you have two options: ### Option 1: Command-based Integration (Recommended) 1. Build the project: ```bash npm run build ``` 2. Open Cursor's settings: - Click on the Cursor menu - Select "Settings" (or use the keyboard shortcut) - Navigate to the "Extensions" or "Integrations" section 3. Add the MCP configuration: ```json { "mcpServers": { "jira": { "command": "node", "args": ["/path/to/jira-mcp-cursor/dist/server.js"] } } } ``` Replace `/path/to/jira-mcp-cursor` with the absolute path to your project. ### Option 2: HTTP-based Integration (Alternative) 1. Start the MCP server (if not already running): ```bash npm start ``` 2. Open Cursor's settings: * Click on the Cursor menu * Select "Settings" (or use the keyboard shortcut) * Navigate to the "Extensions" or "Integrations" section 3. Add the MCP configuration: ```json { "mcpServers": { "jira": { "url": "http://localhost:3000", "capabilities": [ "list_tickets", "get_ticket", "get_comments", "create_ticket", "update_status", "add_comment" ] } } } } ``` ## Using Jira in Cursor After configuring the MCP server, you can use Jira commands directly in Cursor: - `/jira list` - List your tickets - `/jira view TICKET-123` - View ticket details - `/jira comments TICKET-123` - Get ticket comments - `/jira create` - Create a new ticket - `/jira comment TICKET-123` - Add a comment - `/jira status TICKET-123` - Update ticket status ## MCP Protocol Support The server implements the Model-Client-Protocol (MCP) required by Cursor: - Stdio communication for command-based integration - Tool registration for Jira operations ## API Endpoints ### List Tickets Retrieves a list of Jira tickets, optionally filtered by a JQL query. **Endpoint:** `GET /api/tickets` **Query Parameters:** | Parameter | Type | Required | Description | |-----------|------|----------|-------------| | jql | string | No | Jira Query Language (JQL) string to filter tickets | **Example Request:** ```http GET /api/tickets?jql=project=TEST+AND+status=Open ``` **Example Response:** ```text TEST-123: Example ticket (Open) TEST-124: Another ticket (In Progress) ``` ### Get Ticket Retrieves detailed information about a specific ticket. **Endpoint:** `GET /api/tickets/:id` **Path Parameters:** | Parameter | Type | Required | Description | |-----------|------|----------|-------------| | id | string | Yes | The Jira ticket ID (e.g., TEST-123) | **Example Request:** ```http GET /api/tickets/TEST-123 ``` **Example Response:** ```text Key: TEST-123 Summary: Example ticket Status: Open Type: Task Description: Detailed ticket description ``` ### Get Ticket Comments Retrieves all comments for a specific ticket. **Endpoint:** `GET /api/tickets/:id/comments` **Path Parameters:** | Parameter | Type | Required | Description | |-----------|------|----------|-------------| | id | string | Yes | The Jira ticket ID (e.g., TEST-123) | **Example Request:** ```http GET /api/tickets/TEST-123/comments ``` **Example Response:** ```text [3/20/2024, 10:00:00 AM] John Doe: Comment text --- [3/20/2024, 9:30:00 AM] Jane Smith: Another comment --- ``` ### Create Ticket Creates a new Jira ticket. **Endpoint:** `POST /api/tickets` **Request Body:** | Parameter | Type | R [...truncated for length...]', 'tools': [], 'tools_count': 0, 'homepage': '', 'url': 'https://github.com/kornbed/jira-mcp-server', 'topics': [], 'data_sources': ['github']}
raw_output:
# Jira MCP Server for Cursor

This is a TypeScript-based Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that integrates Jira with Cursor IDE, enabling seamless interaction with Jira tickets directly from your development environment.

## üöÄ Features

- **List Jira tickets** with optional JQL filtering
- **Get detailed ticket information** including description, status, and metadata
- **View ticket comments** with timestamps and authors
- **Create new tickets** programmatically
- **Add comments** to existing tickets
- **Update ticket status** workflow transitions
- **Full MCP protocol support** for Cursor integration

## üì¶ Quick Installation

### Via Smithery (Recommended)
```bash
npx -y @smithery/cli install @kornbed/jira-mcp-server --client claude
```

### Manual Setup

1. **Clone and install dependencies:**
```bash
git clone https://github.com/kornbed/jira-mcp-server
cd jira-mcp-server
npm install
```

2. **Configure Jira credentials:**
Create a `.env` file:
```env
JIRA_HOST=https://your-domain.atlassian.net
JIRA_EMAIL=your-email@example.com
JIRA_API_TOKEN=your-api-token
PORT=3000
```

3. **Get your Jira API token:**
   - Visit [Atlassian API Tokens](https://id.atlassian.com/manage/api-tokens)
   - Click "Create API token"
   - Copy and paste into your `.env` file

## ‚öôÔ∏è Cursor Integration

### Option 1: Command-based (Recommended)

1. Build the project:
```bash
npm run build
```

2. Add to Cursor settings:
```json
{
  "mcpServers": {
    "jira": {
      "command": "node",
      "args": ["/absolute/path/to/jira-mcp-server/dist/server.js"]
    }
  }
}
```

### Option 2: HTTP-based

1. Start the server:
```bash
npm start
```

2. Configure Cursor:
```json
{
  "mcpServers": {
    "jira": {
      "url": "http://localhost:3000",
      "capabilities": [
        "list_tickets",
        "get_ticket", 
        "get_comments",
        "create_ticket",
        "update_status",
        "add_comment"
      ]
    }
  }
}
```

## üíª Usage in Cursor

Once configured, use these commands directly in Cursor:

- `/jira list` - List your tickets
- `/jira view TICKET-123` - View ticket details  
- `/jira comments TICKET-123` - Get ticket comments
- `/jira create` - Create a new ticket
- `/jira comment TICKET-123` - Add a comment
- `/jira status TICKET-123` - Update ticket status

## üîß Development

**Development server:**
```bash
npm run dev
```

**Build for production:**
```bash
npm run build
```

**Start production server:**
```bash
npm start
```

## üì° API Endpoints

| Endpoint | Method | Description |
|----------|--------|-------------|
| `/api/tickets` | GET | List tickets (supports JQL filtering) |
| `/api/tickets/:id` | GET | Get ticket details |
| `/api/tickets/:id/comments` | GET | Get ticket comments |
| `/api/tickets` | POST | Create new ticket |
| `/api/tickets/:id/comments` | POST | Add comment |
| `/api/tickets/:id/status` | PUT | Update ticket status |

## üè∑Ô∏è Repository Details

- **GitHub:** [kornbed/jira-mcp-server](https://github.com/kornbed/jira-mcp-server)
- **Language:** TypeScript
- **Protocol:** Model Context Protocol (MCP)
- **IDE Integration:** Cursor

This server bridges the gap between your development workflow in Cursor and your project management in Jira, making it easier to stay connected to your tickets without leaving your IDE.

{'server_name': 'codex', 'server_id': 'mdashley/codex', 'description': 'A simple MCP server that provides a LLM with tools for accessing legislative data from the Congress.gov API', 'readme': '# Codex

A simple MCP server that provides a LLM with tools for accessing legislative data from the [Congress.gov API](https://github.com/LibraryOfCongress/api.congress.gov).

## Features

Over 40 tools organized into categories:

- **Amendments**: List amendments, get details, actions, cosponsors, and text
- **Bills**: Search and retrieve bill information, actions, amendments, committees, cosponsors, subjects, summaries, and text
- **Committees**: List committees and get committee details and bills
- **Members**: Access member information, sponsored and cosponsored legislation
- **Nominations**: List and get details about presidential nominations
- **Treaties**: Access treaty information and actions
- **Congressional Record**: Browse congressional record entries
- **Hearings**: Search and get details about congressional hearings
- **Communications**: Access House and Senate communications

## Requirements

- Python 3.10+
- [uv](https://astral.sh/uv) package manager
- Congress.gov API key (set as `CONGRESS_API_KEY` environment variable)

## Setup

```bash
# Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/mdashley/codex.git
cd codex

# Set up virtual environment
uv venv
source .venv/bin/activate  # On Windows: .venv\Scripts\activate

# Install dependencies
uv sync
```

## Connecting to Claude for Desktop

1. Install [Claude for Desktop](https://claude.ai/desktop)
2. Configure Claude to use the server by editing `~/Library/Application Support/Claude/claude_desktop_config.json`:

```json
{
  "mcpServers": {
    "codex": {
      "command": "uv",
      "args": [
        "--directory",
        "/ABSOLUTE/PATH/TO/PARENT/FOLDER/codex",
        "run",
        "codex.py"
      ],
      "env": {
        "CONGRESS_API_KEY": "your-api-key-here"
      }
    }
  }
}
```

3. Restart Claude for Desktop
4. Look for the hammer icon to confirm tools are available

## Getting a Congress.gov API Key

To fetch data from the Congress.gov API, you need to [request an API key](https://api.congress.gov/sign-up/).

## Troubleshooting

- Check logs at `~/Library/Logs/Claude/mcp*.log`
- Update the uv path in claude_desktop_config.json to be absolute (run `which uv` to find your uv installation path)

## Learn More

- [MCP documentation](https://modelcontextprotocol.io/introduction)
- [Congress.gov API documentation](https://api.congress.gov/)

raw_output:
# Codex MCP Server

A comprehensive MCP server that provides access to U.S. legislative data through the Congress.gov API, offering over 40 tools for congressional research and information retrieval.

## Overview

The Codex MCP server enables LLMs to access extensive legislative data from Congress.gov, making it valuable for legal research, policy analysis, and civic engagement applications.

## Key Features

### Legislative Data Categories
- **Amendments**: List, details, actions, cosponsors, and full text
- **Bills**: Comprehensive bill information including actions, committees, summaries, and text
- **Committees**: Committee listings, details, and associated legislation
- **Members**: Congressional member information and their legislative activities
- **Nominations**: Presidential nomination data and status
- **Treaties**: Treaty information and related actions
- **Congressional Record**: Browse official congressional proceedings
- **Hearings**: Congressional hearing search and details
- **Communications**: House and Senate communications access

## Setup Requirements

- **Python**: 3.10 or higher
- **Package Manager**: [uv](https://astral.sh/uv)
- **API Access**: Congress.gov API key (free registration required)

## Installation

```bash
# Clone and set up the server
git clone https://github.com/mdashley/codex.git
cd codex

# Create virtual environment
uv venv
source .venv/bin/activate  # Linux/Mac
# .venv\Scripts\activate    # Windows

# Install dependencies
uv sync
```

## Configuration

### Claude Desktop Integration

Edit your Claude configuration file:
- **Location**: `~/Library/Application Support/Claude/claude_desktop_config.json`

```json
{
  "mcpServers": {
    "codex": {
      "command": "uv",
      "args": [
        "--directory",
        "/ABSOLUTE/PATH/TO/codex",
        "run",
        "codex.py"
      ],
      "env": {
        "CONGRESS_API_KEY": "your-api-key-here"
      }
    }
  }
}
```

### API Key Setup

1. Visit [api.congress.gov/sign-up](https://api.congress.gov/sign-up/)
2. Register for a free API key
3. Set the key in your environment or configuration

## Use Cases

- **Legal Research**: Access comprehensive bill texts, amendments, and legislative history
- **Policy Analysis**: Track legislation progress and committee activities
- **Civic Applications**: Build tools for public engagement with legislative processes
- **Academic Research**: Analyze congressional voting patterns and member activities
- **Journalism**: Research legislative developments and member positions

## Data Access

The server provides structured access to:
- Current and historical legislation
- Member voting records and sponsorships
- Committee assignments and activities
- Presidential nominations and confirmations
- Treaty negotiations and ratifications
- Official congressional proceedings

## Troubleshooting

- **Logs**: Check `~/Library/Logs/Claude/mcp*.log` for issues
- **Path Issues**: Use absolute paths in configuration
- **API Limits**: Be aware of Congress.gov API rate limits

## Resources

- **Repository**: [github.com/mdashley/codex](https://github.com/mdashley/codex)
- **Congress.gov API**: [Official API Documentation](https://api.congress.gov/)
- **MCP Protocol**: [Model Context Protocol docs](https://modelcontextprotocol.io/introduction)

This server transforms the Congress.gov API into an accessible tool for LLMs, enabling sophisticated analysis of U.S. legislative data and processes.

{'server_name': 'altium-mcp', 'server_id': 'coffeenmusic/altium-mcp', 'description': 'Altium Model Context Protocol server and Altium API script', 'readme': '# Altium MCP Server

TLDR: Use Claude to control or ask questions about your Altium project.
This is a Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that provides an interface to interact with Altium Designer through Python. The server allows for querying and manipulation of PCB designs programmatically.

Note: Having Claude place components on the PCB currently fails hard.

## Example commands
- Run all output jobs
- Create a symbol for the part in the attached datasheet and use the currently open symbol as a reference example.
- Create a schematic symbol from the attached MPM3650 switching regulator datasheet and make sure to strictly follow the symbol placement rules. (Note: Need to open a schematic library. Uses `C:\AltiumMCP\symbol_placement_rules.txt` description as pin placement rules. Please modify for your own preferences.)
- Duplicate my selected layout. (Will prompt user to now select destination components. Supports Component, Track, Arc, Via, Polygon, & Region)
- Show all my inner layers. Show the top and bottom layer. Turn off solder paste.
- Get me all parts on my design made by Molex
- Give me the description and part number of U4
- Place the selected parts on my pcb with best practices for a switching regulator. Note: It tries, but does terrible placement. Hopefully I can find a way to improve this.
- Give me a list of all IC designators in my design
- Get me all length matching rules

## Setup
Currently only tested on Windows & the Altium scripts have hard coded `C:\AltiumMCP` paths for now. That's probably a good TODO item.

1. Clone the repo to `C:\` so you end up with a `C:\AltiumMCP\` directory
2. Install uv

**On Windows**
```bash
powershell -c "irm https://astral.sh/uv/install.ps1 | iex" 
```
and then
```bash
set Path=C:\Users\nntra\.local\bin;%Path%
```

3. Open cmd in `C:\AltiumMCP\` directory and run `uv sync` to add packages from pyproject.toml file. 

### Claude for Desktop Integration
Enable Developer Mode under Claude > Help > Enable Developer Mode

Go to Claude > Settings > Developer > Edit Config > claude_desktop_config.json to include the following:
Below is specific to Windows, TODO: find out how to run on both without a hard coded path
```json
{
    "mcpServers": {
        "altium": {
            "command": "uv",
            "args": [
                "--directory",
                "C:\\AltiumMCP",
                "run",
                "server.py"
            ]
        }
    }
}
```

### Using with Claude
Restart Claude: Right click on the Claude icon in the System Tray > Quit. Then re-open Claude desktop. 

Once the config file has been set on Claude, and the addon is running on Altium, you will see a hammer icon with tools for the Altium MCP.

![AltiumMCP in the sidebar](assets/hammer-icon.png)

## Configuration

When launching claude for the first time, the server will automatically try to locate your Altium Designer installation. It will search for all directories that start with `C:\Program Files\Altium\AD*` and use the one with the largest revision number. If it cannot find any, you will be prompted to select the Altium executable (X2.EXE) manually when you first run the server. Altium's DelphiScript scripting is used to create an API between the mcp server and Altium. It expects to find this script project in `C:\AltiumMCP\AltiumScript\`.

## Available Tools

The server provides several tools to interact with Altium Designer:

### Output Jobs
- `get_output_job_containers`: Using currently open .OutJob file, reads all available output containers
- `run_output_jobs`: Pass a list of output job container names from the currently open .OutJob to run any number of them. `.OutJob` must be the currently focused document.

### Component Information
- `get_all_designators`: Get a list of all component designators in the current board
- `get_all_component_property_names`: Get a list of all available component property names
- `get_component_property_values`: Get the values of a specific property for all components
- `get_component_data`: Get detailed data for specific components by designator
- `get_component_pins`: Get pin information for specified components

### Schematic/Symbol
- `get_schematic_data`: Get schematic data for specified components
- `create_schematic_symbol` ([YouTube](https://youtu.be/MMP7ZfmbCMI)): Passes pin list with pin type & coordinates to Altium script
- `get_symbol_placement_rules`: Create symbol's helper tool that reads `C:\AltiumMCP\symbol_placement_rules.txt` to get pin placement rules for symbol creation.
- `get_library_symbol_reference`: Create symbol's helper tool to use an open library symbol as an example to create the symbol

![Symbol Creator](assets/symbol_creator.gif)

### Layout Operations
- `get_all_nets`: Returns a list of unique nets from the pcb
- `create_net_class` ([YouTube](https://youtu.be/89booqRbnzQ)): Create a net class from a list of nets
- `get_pcb_layers`: Get detailed layer information including electrical, mechanical, layer pairs,

'object', 'properties': {'file_path': {'type': 'string', 'description': 'File path or file to process'}}, 'required': ['file_path']}, 'source': 'readme', 'access_level': 'write'}, {'name': raw_output:
# Altium MCP Server

This is a Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that provides an interface to control Altium Designer through Claude AI. It allows you to interact with your PCB designs programmatically using natural language commands.

## Key Features

- **PCB Design Control**: Query and manipulate PCB designs directly from Claude
- **Component Management**: Get component data, designators, properties, and pin information
- **Symbol Creation**: Create schematic symbols from datasheets with AI assistance
- **Layout Operations**: Duplicate layouts, manage layers, create net classes
- **Output Generation**: Run output jobs and generate manufacturing files
- **Visual Feedback**: Take screenshots of your PCB or schematic views

## Example Commands

- "Run all output jobs"
- "Create a symbol for the part in the attached datasheet"
- "Duplicate my selected layout"
- "Show all my inner layers, turn off solder paste"
- "Get me all parts on my design made by Molex"
- "Give me a list of all IC designators in my design"

## Setup Requirements

‚ö†Ô∏è **Currently Windows-only** and requires installation to `C:\AltiumMCP\`

### Installation Steps

1. **Clone the repository**:
   ```bash
   git clone https://github.com/coffeenmusic/altium-mcp.git C:\AltiumMCP
   ```

2. **Install uv package manager**:
   ```bash
   powershell -c "irm https://astral.sh/uv/install.ps1 | iex"
   set Path=C:\Users\%USERNAME%\.local\bin;%Path%
   ```

3. **Install dependencies**:
   ```bash
   cd C:\AltiumMCP
   uv sync
   ```

4. **Configure Claude Desktop**:
   - Enable Developer Mode: Claude > Help > Enable Developer Mode
   - Edit config file: Claude > Settings > Developer > Edit Config
   - Add this configuration:
   ```json
   {
       "mcpServers": {
           "altium": {
               "command": "uv",
               "args": [
                   "--directory",
                   "C:\\AltiumMCP",
                   "run",
                   "server.py"
               ]
           }
       }
   }
   ```

5. **Restart Claude** to activate the integration

## Available Tools

### Component Analysis
- Get all component designators and properties
- Query specific component data and pin information
- Filter components by manufacturer or other criteria

### Symbol Creation
- AI-assisted symbol creation from datasheets
- Automatic pin placement following design rules
- Use existing symbols as reference templates

### Layout Management
- Duplicate component layouts with intelligent matching
- Control layer visibility (show/hide inner layers, silk, etc.)
- Move and position components programmatically

### Design Rules & Nets
- View and manage PCB design rules
- Create net classes from component groups
- Get stackup and layer information

### Output Generation
- Run specific output job containers
- Generate manufacturing files automatically

## Limitations

- Windows-only (hardcoded paths to `C:\AltiumMCP\`)
- Component placement on PCB needs improvement
- Requires Altium Designer to be running
- Claude's image analysis of PCB screenshots is limited

## Integration

Once configured, you'll see a hammer icon in Claude's sidebar indicating the Altium MCP tools are available. The server automatically detects your Altium installation or prompts for manual selection.

This tool bridges the gap between AI assistance and professional PCB design, making complex Altium operations accessible through natural language commands.
