AI Terminal Integration Demo](https://img.youtube.com/vi/uFWBGiD4x9c/0.jpg)](https://youtu.be/uFWBGiD4x9c) ## ‚ú® Features - ü§ñ **AI Connection**: Seamlessly connect AI assistants to your terminal - üîå **MCP Server**: Built-in Model Context Protocol server implementation - üñ•Ô∏è **Terminal Control**: Allow AI to execute commands and read terminal output - üîç **Session Management**: View and manage SSH sessions - üö´ **Command Abort**: Safely abort running commands - üìã **Buffer Access**: Retrieve terminal buffer content with flexible options ## üìã Table of Contents - [Installation](#installation) - [Quick Start](#quick-start) - [Usage Examples](#usage-examples) - [Configuration](#configuration) - [API Reference](#api-reference) - [Contributing](#contributing) - [Continuous Integration](#continuous-integration) - [License](#license) ## üîß Installation ### Using Docker You can build and install the plugin using Docker with the following command: ```bash git clone https://github.com/thuanpham582002/tabby-mcp-server.git cd tabby-mcp-server # Build the Docker image docker build -t tabby-mcp . && docker run -v $(pwd)/build:/output tabby-mcp bash scripts/copy_to_plugin_folder.sh ``` This command builds a Docker image tagged as 'tabby-mcp' and runs a container from this image, mounting your local 'build' directory to '/output' in the container. The script `scripts/copy_to_plugin_folder.sh` will copy the built files to the Tabby plugin folder. > **Note:** Our CI/CD workflows on GitHub also use this Docker-based build process to ensure consistency between local development and production releases. ## üöÄ Quick Start 1. Install the plugin 2. Configure your Tabby environment 3. Connect to MCP server from any of the supported clients listed at https://modelcontextprotocol.io/clients ## üíª Usage Examples ### Connect an AI to Control Your Terminal ### Retrieve SSH Session List ## ‚öôÔ∏è Configuration Configure the MCP server through the Tabby settings: ```json { "mcp": { "port": 3001, "host": "http://localhost:3001", // note: in development "enableLogging": false, "startOnBoot": true } } ``` ### MCP Client Configuration When connecting to the Tabby MCP server from an AI client (like Claude, GPT, etc.), use the following configuration: ```json { "mcpServers": { "Tabby MCP": { "url": "http://localhost:3001/sse" } } } ``` You may need to adjust the `url` parameter if you've configured a different host or port in your server settings. ## üìö API Reference ### Available Tools | Tool | Description | Parameters | |------|-------------|------------| | `getSshSessionList` | Get list of SSH sessions | None | | `execCommand` | Execute a command in terminal | `command`, `tabId` | | `getTerminalBuffer` | Get terminal content | `tabId`, `startLine`, `endLine` | | `abortCommand` | Abort a running command | None | ## ü§ù Contributing Contributions are welcome! Here's how you can help: 1. Fork the repository 2. Create a feature branch (`git checkout -b feature/amazing-feature`) 3. Commit your changes (`git commit -m 'Add amazing feature'`) 4. Push to the branch (`git push origin feature/amazing-feature`) 5. Open a Pull Request See the [contributing guidelines](CONTRIBUTING.md) for more details. ### Continuous Integration Our project uses GitHub Actions for CI/CD with Docker-based builds: - **Pull Requests**: Automatically built and tested using Docker to ensure compatibility - **Main Branch**: Builds with Docker, publishes to npm, and creates GitHub releases - **Benefits**: Consistent environment across development, testing, and production To set up the CI/CD pipeline in your fork: 1. Configure the required secrets in your repository settings: - `NPM_TOKEN`: Your npm access token for publishing - `GITHUB_TOKEN`: Automatically provided by GitHub Actions 2. The workflows will automatically run on push and pull request events. ## üìù License This project is licensed under the MIT License - see the [LICENSE](LICENSE) file for details. ---

raw_output:
# Tabby MCP Server

A powerful Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that enables AI assistants to control and interact with Tabby terminal sessions. This plugin bridges the gap between AI and terminal operations, allowing for intelligent automation and assistance.

## üåü Key Features

- **AI Terminal Control**: Let AI assistants execute commands and read terminal output
- **SSH Session Management**: View and manage SSH connections
- **Terminal Buffer Access**: Retrieve terminal content with flexible line-based options
- **Command Safety**: Abort running commands when needed
- **MCP Integration**: Full Model Context Protocol server implementation

## üîß Available Tools

### Core Terminal Operations
- **`getSshSessionList`** - Retrieve all active SSH sessions
- **`execCommand`** - Execute commands in specific terminal tabs (requires `command` and `tabId`)
- **`getTerminalBuffer`** - Get terminal content with optional line range (`tabId`, `startLine`, `endLine`)
- **`abortCommand`** - Safely stop running commands

## üöÄ Installation

### Docker-based Installation (Recommended)
```bash
git clone https://github.com/thuanpham582002/tabby-mcp-server.git
cd tabby-mcp-server
docker build -t tabby-mcp . && docker run -v $(pwd)/build:/output tabby-mcp
bash scripts/copy_to_plugin_folder.sh
```

## ‚öôÔ∏è Configuration

### Server Configuration
```json
{
  "mcp": {
    "port": 3001,
    "host": "http://localhost:3001",
    "enableLogging": false,
    "startOnBoot": true
  }
}
```

### MCP Client Configuration
```json
{
  "mcpServers": {
    "Tabby MCP": {
      "url": "http://localhost:3001/sse"
    }
  }
}
```

## üéØ Use Cases

- **Automated DevOps**: Let AI manage deployments and server operations
- **Smart Debugging**: AI can analyze logs and execute diagnostic commands
- **Interactive Tutorials**: Create AI-guided terminal sessions
- **Remote Management**: Intelligent SSH session handling

## üìä Project Stats

- ‚≠ê GitHub Stars: Growing community adoption
- üì¶ NPM Package: `tabby-mcp`
- üîÑ Active CI/CD: Docker-based builds and automated releases
- üìÑ MIT License: Open source and community-friendly

## ü§ù Contributing

The project welcomes contributions with a well-established workflow:
1. Fork and create feature branches
2. Docker-based testing ensures consistency
3. Automated CI/CD pipeline with GitHub Actions
4. Community-driven development

This MCP server transforms terminal interaction by making it accessible to AI assistants, enabling powerful automation and intelligent terminal management workflows.

raw_output:
# MCP Weather Server

A Model Context Protocol server that provides weather forecasting and city information query functionality. This server allows LLMs to get weather information for the next 24 hours and supports querying city information through city names, coordinates, etc.

## Overview

This is a Chinese weather API MCP server that provides:
- 24-hour weather forecasts
- Support for location queries by city name or coordinates
- Easy integration with Claude and other MCP-compatible applications

## Available Tools

- **get_24h_weather** - Get weather forecast for the next 24 hours
  - Required parameter: `location` (string) - City name or coordinates (e.g., "Âåó‰∫¨" or "116.41,39.92")

## Installation Options

### Using uv (Recommended)
No special installation needed when using [`uv`](https://docs.astral.sh/uv/). Run directly with [`uvx`](https://docs.astral.sh/uv/guides/tools/):

```bash
uvx mcp-server-weather
```

### Using pip
Install via pip:

```bash
pip install mcp-server-weather
```

Then run as:
```bash
python -m mcp_server_weather
```

### Using Docker
```bash
docker run -i --rm mcp/weather
```

## Configuration

### Claude Desktop
Add to your Claude settings:

```json
"mcpServers": {
  "weather": {
    "command": "uvx",
    "args": ["mcp-server-weather"]
  }
}
```

### Zed Editor
Add to Zed's settings.json:

```json
"context_servers": {
  "mcp-server-weather": {
    "command": "uvx",
    "args": ["mcp-server-weather"]
  }
}
```

## Example Usage

Get 24-hour weather forecast:
```json
{
  "name": "get_24h_weather",
  "arguments": {
    "location": "ÂπøÂ∑û Â§©Ê≤≥"
  }
}
```

## Debugging

Use the MCP inspector for debugging:
```bash
npx @modelcontextprotocol/inspector uvx mcp-server-weather
```

## Key Features

- **Chinese Weather Support**: Native support for Chinese cities and locations
- **Flexible Location Input**: Accepts both city names and coordinates
- **24-Hour Forecasts**: Detailed weather information for the next day
- **Easy Integration**: Simple setup with popular MCP clients
- **Multiple Installation Methods**: Support for uv, pip, and Docker

## Repository

- **GitHub**: https://github.com/xuezhijian/mcp_weather
- **License**: MIT License
- **Contributions**: Welcome! Pull requests and improvements encouraged

This server is particularly useful for applications needing Chinese weather data integration with AI assistants and other MCP-compatible tools.

# Easy Copy Service MCP Server

This is a handy utility MCP server that provides quick access to all your configured MCP services in one convenient location. Instead of hunting through configuration files, you can easily see what services are available and copy their details.

## Key Features

- **Quick Reference**: Lists all MCP services configured in your Claude Desktop instance
- **Easy Discovery**: No need to search through config files to see what's available
- **Convenient Access**: Appears at the top of your tools menu with a distinctive separator-style name
- **Dynamic Updates**: Keeps the list current with your actual configuration

## Available Tool

### `_________available_mcp_services_for_easy_copy_________`
- **Purpose**: Displays all configured MCP services
- **Input**: No parameters needed
- **Output**: Complete list of your available MCP services with details
- **Access**: Read-only operation

This tool is particularly useful when:
- Setting up new workflows and need to reference available services
- Sharing your MCP setup with others
- Quickly checking what services are currently configured
- Troubleshooting MCP service availability

The server name format with underscores makes it easy to spot in your tools list, ensuring quick access when you need to reference your MCP services.

**Homepage**: [Smithery - Easy Copy Service](https://smithery.ai/server/@f-is-h/mcp-easy-copy)

This is an MCP (Model Context Protocol) server called **mcp-demo** that serves as a basic demonstration and starting point for MCP server development.

## Server Details
- **Name**: mcp-demo
- **ID**: @nssachin/mcp-demo
- **Homepage**: https://smithery.ai/server/@nssachin/mcp-demo

## Purpose
This server is designed to:
- Provide a simple demonstration of MCP server implementation
- Enable basic interaction with MCP clients to showcase protocol usage
- Serve as a starting point for building more complex MCP servers

## Available Tools
The server includes **1 tool**:

### `hello` Tool
- **Description**: Say hello to someone
- **Access Level**: Read-only
- **Required Parameter**: 
  - `name` (string): Name to greet

**Usage Example**:
```json
{
  "name": "Alice"
}
```

This would return a greeting message for "Alice".

## Use Cases
This demo server is perfect for:
- Learning MCP protocol basics
- Testing MCP client implementations
- Understanding how MCP servers structure tools and responses
- Building a foundation for more sophisticated MCP servers

The simplicity of this server makes it an excellent educational resource for developers getting started with the Model Context Protocol.

raw_output:
This is the DuckDuckGo Search API MCP server, which provides comprehensive search capabilities while maintaining user privacy. Here's what it offers:

## üîç **Available Search Tools**

### 1. **Text Search** (`ddg-text-search`)
- Search the web for text-based results
- Configurable parameters: region, time limits, safe search, max results
- Perfect for general web searches and research

### 2. **Image Search** (`ddg-image-search`)
- Find images with advanced filtering options
- Filter by: size, color, layout, type (photo/clipart/gif), license
- Useful for finding specific visual content

### 3. **News Search** (`ddg-news-search`)
- Search for current news articles
- Time-limited searches (day, week, month)
- Stay updated with recent developments

### 4. **Video Search** (`ddg-video-search`)
- Find videos with filtering by duration and resolution
- Support for different license types (Creative Commons, YouTube)
- Great for multimedia content discovery

### 5. **AI Chat** (`ddg-ai-chat`)
- Interactive AI conversations using multiple models:
  - GPT-4o-mini (default)
  - Llama-3.3-70b
  - Claude-3-haiku
  - o3-mini
  - Mistral-small-3

## üåü **Key Features**
- **Privacy-focused**: Uses DuckDuckGo's privacy-first approach
- **Multi-region support**: Search with different regional settings
- **Flexible filtering**: Time limits, safe search, content types
- **Multiple AI models**: Choose the best model for your needs
- **Read-only access**: Safe for information retrieval

This server is ideal for applications that need comprehensive search capabilities without compromising user privacy, making it perfect for research, content discovery, and AI-powered assistance.

raw_output:
# Pandoc Document Conversion MCP Server

This is a Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that provides document format conversion capabilities using Pandoc. It allows you to convert content between various document formats including Markdown, HTML, PDF, DOCX, LaTeX, and more.

## Key Features

- **Multi-format Support**: Convert between popular document formats including:
  - Basic formats: TXT, HTML, Markdown
  - Advanced formats: PDF, DOCX, RST, LaTeX, EPUB

- **Flexible Input**: Accept content directly or from input files
- **File Output**: Save converted documents to specified file paths

## Critical Requirements

### PDF Conversion Prerequisites
‚ö†Ô∏è **PDF conversion requires TeX Live installation:**
- **Ubuntu/Debian**: `sudo apt-get install texlive-xetex`
- **macOS**: `brew install texlive`
- **Windows**: Install MiKTeX or TeX Live from official sources

### File Path Requirements
When converting to advanced formats (PDF, DOCX, RST, LaTeX, EPUB), you **must** provide:
- Complete directory path
- Filename with extension
- Example: `/path/to/document.pdf` or `C:\Documents\report.docx`

## Usage Examples

### ‚úÖ Correct Usage

**Basic conversion (display output):**
```
Convert this markdown text to HTML
```

**Advanced conversion (save to file):**
```
Convert this content to PDF and save as /documents/report.pdf
```

**File-to-file conversion:**
```
Convert /input/document.md to DOCX format and save as /output/document.docx
```

### ‚ùå Incorrect Usage

```
Save this as PDF in /documents/        # Missing filename
Convert to PDF                         # Missing complete file path
```

## Tool: convert-contents

Converts content between different document formats with the following parameters:

- `contents` (string): Content to convert (required if no input_file)
- `input_file` (string): Path to input file (required if no contents)
- `output_file` (string): Complete output path (required for advanced formats)
- `input_format` (enum): Source format (defaults to markdown)
- `output_format` (enum): Target format (defaults to markdown)

## File Location

After successful conversion, the tool displays the exact path where your file is saved:
```
Content successfully converted and saved to: [file_path]
```

Files are saved to your specified location, or to the system temp directory if no path is provided.

This server is particularly useful for content creators, technical writers, and anyone who needs to convert documents between different formats programmatically.

raw_output:
# Chargebee Platform MCP Server

An MCP (Model Context Protocol) server that connects AI agents to the Chargebee subscription billing platform.

## Overview

This server provides integration with [Chargebee](https://www.chargebee.com), a comprehensive subscription billing and revenue operations platform. It enables AI agents to interact with Chargebee's services for managing subscriptions, invoicing, payments, and other billing-related operations.

## Features

- **Subscription Management**: Handle customer subscriptions, billing cycles, and plan changes
- **Revenue Operations**: Access billing data, revenue metrics, and financial reporting
- **Customer Management**: Manage customer profiles, payment methods, and billing information
- **Invoice Processing**: Generate, send, and track invoices and payment receipts

## Installation

The server is available through the official Chargebee AgentKit repository:

```bash
# Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/chargebee/agentkit.git
cd agentkit/modelcontextprotocol
```

## Configuration

You'll need to configure the server with your Chargebee API credentials and site information. Refer to the [Chargebee documentation](https://www.chargebee.com/docs/) for API setup instructions.

## Use Cases

- **Billing Automation**: Automate subscription billing workflows and processes
- **Customer Support**: Query customer billing information and subscription status
- **Revenue Analytics**: Generate reports and insights from billing data
- **Payment Processing**: Handle payment collection and dunning management

## Links

- **Platform**: [Chargebee](https://www.chargebee.com)
- **Source Code**: [GitHub Repository](https://github.com/chargebee/agentkit/tree/main/modelcontextprotocol)
- **Documentation**: [Chargebee Docs](https://www.chargebee.com/docs/)

This MCP server brings the power of Chargebee's subscription billing platform to AI agents, enabling sophisticated billing and revenue management automation.

# MCPollinations Multimodal Server

This is a comprehensive multimodal AI server that provides image, text, and audio generation capabilities through the Pollinations APIs. Here's what it offers:

## üéØ **Key Features**
- **No Authentication Required** - Simple setup and integration
- **Multimodal Generation** - Images, text, and audio from text prompts
- **Multiple AI Models** - Various options for different use cases
- **Flexible Output** - URLs, base64 data, or saved files

## üõ†Ô∏è **Available Tools**

### **Image Generation**
- **`generateImageUrl`** - Creates image URLs from text prompts
- **`generateImage`** - Generates images and saves them as files (base64 encoded)
- **`listImageModels`** - Shows available image models

**Supported Image Models:**
- `flux` (default), `flux-schnell`, `flux-dev`
- `sdxl`, `sd3`, `sd15`
- `turbo` (SDXL variant)

**Image Options:**
- Custom dimensions (default: 1024x1024)
- Reproducible results with seed values
- Content filtering options
- Prompt enhancement via LLM
- Multiple formats: PNG, JPEG, WebP

### **Audio Generation**
- **`respondAudio`** - Text-to-speech with system playback
- **`listAudioVoices`** - Shows available voice options

**Available Voices:**
`alloy`, `echo`, `fable`, `onyx`, `nova`, `shimmer`, `coral`, `verse`, `ballad`, `ash`, `sage`, `amuch`, `dan`

### **Text Generation**
- **`respondText`** - Text generation using various LLMs
- **`listTextModels`** - Shows available text models

**Supported Text Models:**
`openai`, `anthropic`, `mistral`, `llama`, `gemini`

## üí° **Use Cases**
- **Content Creation** - Generate images for blogs, social media, presentations
- **Prototyping** - Quick visual mockups and concept art
- **Accessibility** - Text-to-speech for audio content
- **AI Assistants** - Enhance chatbots with multimodal capabilities
- **Creative Projects** - Art generation, storytelling, multimedia content

## üöÄ **Getting Started**
Since no authentication is required, you can immediately start generating content by calling the appropriate tools with your prompts. The server handles file management automatically, saving outputs to `./mcpollinations-output/` by default.

This server is perfect for developers looking to add powerful AI generation capabilities to their applications without the complexity of API key management or complex setup procedures.

raw_output:
# iOS Simulator MCP Server

This MCP server provides comprehensive tools for interacting with iOS simulators, enabling automated UI testing, quality assurance, and screen inspection capabilities.

## Overview

The iOS Simulator MCP server allows you to:
- Control iOS simulator interactions programmatically
- Validate UI elements and accessibility information
- Capture screenshots and record videos
- Automate UI testing workflows
- Inspect screen elements at specific coordinates

## Available Tools

### Simulator Management
- **`get_booted_sim_id`** - Get the ID of the currently booted iOS simulator

### UI Interaction
- **`ui_tap`** - Tap at specific coordinates on the simulator screen
- **`ui_type`** - Input text into the simulator
- **`ui_swipe`** - Perform swipe gestures between two points

### UI Inspection
- **`ui_describe_all`** - Get accessibility information for the entire screen
- **`ui_describe_point`** - Get accessibility element details at specific coordinates

### Screen Capture
- **`screenshot`** - Capture screenshots in various formats (PNG, TIFF, BMP, GIF, JPEG)
- **`record_video`** - Start video recording of simulator interactions
- **`stop_recording`** - Stop ongoing video recording

## Key Features

### Flexible Screen Capture
- Multiple image formats supported
- Configurable display selection (internal/external)
- Non-rectangular display mask handling
- Custom output path specification

### Comprehensive UI Testing
- Accessibility-based element inspection
- Coordinate-based interactions
- Gesture support (tap, swipe, type)
- Configurable interaction parameters

### Video Recording
- H.264 and HEVC codec support
- Custom output paths with automatic timestamping
- Force overwrite capabilities
- Clean start/stop recording workflow

## Use Cases

1. **Automated UI Testing** - Script complex user interactions and validate responses
2. **Quality Assurance** - Capture screenshots and videos for bug reporting
3. **Accessibility Testing** - Inspect and validate accessibility information
4. **Documentation** - Generate visual documentation of app workflows
5. **Regression Testing** - Automate repetitive testing scenarios

## Configuration

Most tools accept an optional `udid` parameter to specify the target simulator, or you can set the `IDB_UDID` environment variable for consistent targeting across operations.

This server integrates seamlessly with CI/CD pipelines and testing frameworks to provide reliable, automated iOS app testing capabilities.

This is a server description for a Lean theorem prover integration with the Model Context Protocol (MCP). Here's what this server provides:

## Lean Theorem Prover MCP Server

**Purpose**: Enables interaction with the Lean theorem prover through the Language Server Protocol (LSP) via MCP.

**Key Details**:
- **Server ID**: `lean-theorem-prover`
- **Implementation**: Uses the [lean-lsp-mcp](https://github.com/oOo0oOo/lean-lsp-mcp) project
- **Official Lean Website**: https://lean-lang.org/

**What is Lean?**
Lean is a modern theorem prover and programming language designed for:
- Mathematical formalization
- Formal verification
- Interactive theorem proving
- Dependent type theory

**Current Status**: 
- The server shows 0 tools currently available
- This suggests it may be in development or the tools aren't loaded yet

**Potential Use Cases**:
- Proving mathematical theorems formally
- Verifying software correctness
- Learning formal mathematics
- Research in formal methods

This integration would allow you to interact with Lean's powerful theorem proving capabilities through the MCP framework, potentially making formal verification more accessible through conversational interfaces.

Would you like to know more about Lean theorem proving or how this might be used in practice?

{'server_name': 'Calendly', 'server_id': 'universal-mcp/calendly', 'description': 'Calendly MCP server from', 'readme': "# Calendly Universal MCP Server

This repository contains an implementation of an Calendly Universal MCP (Model Context Protocol) server. It provides a standardized interface for interacting with Calendly's tools and services through a unified API.

The server is built using the Universal MCP framework.

This implementation follows the MCP specification, ensuring compatibility with other MCP-compliant services and tools.

## Usage

You can start using Calendly directly from [agentr.dev](https://agentr.dev). Visit [agentr.dev/apps](https://agentr.dev/apps) and enable Calendly.

If you have not used universal mcp before follow the setup instructions at [agentr.dev/quickstart](https://agentr.dev/quickstart)

## Available Tools

The full list of available tools is at [./src/universal_mcp_calendly/README.md](./src/universal_mcp_calendly/README.md)

## Local Development

### üìã Prerequisites

Ensure you have the following before you begin:

- **Python 3.11+** (recommended)
- **[uv](https://github.com/astral-sh/uv)** (install globally with `pip install uv`)

### üõ†Ô∏è Setup Instructions

Follow the steps below to set up your development environment:

1. **Sync Project Dependencies**

   ```bash
   uv sync
   ```

   This installs all dependencies from `pyproject.toml` into a local virtual environment (`.venv`).

2. **Activate the Virtual Environment**

   For Linux/macOS:

   ```bash
   source .venv/bin/activate
   ```

   For Windows (PowerShell):

   ```powershell
   .venv\Scripts\Activate
   ```

3. **Start the MCP Inspector**

   ```bash
   mcp dev src/universal_mcp_calendly/server.py
   ```

   This will start the MCP inspector. Make note of the address and port shown in the console output.

4. **Install the Application**
   ```bash
   mcp install src/universal_mcp_calendly/server.py
   ```

## üìÅ Project Structure

```text
.
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ src/
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ universal_mcp_calendly/
‚îÇ       ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ __init__.py       # Package initializer
‚îÇ       ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ server.py            # Server entry point
‚îÇ       ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ app.py            # Application tools
‚îÇ       ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ README.md         # List of application tools
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ tests/                    # Test suite
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ .env                      # Environment variables for local development
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ pyproject.toml            # Project configuration
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ README.md                 # This file
```

## üìÑ License

This project is licensed under the [MIT License](LICENSE).

# Calendly MCP Server

This is a **Calendly MCP (Model Context Protocol) server** that provides a standardized interface for interacting with Calendly's scheduling tools and services. It's built using the Universal MCP framework and follows the MCP specification for compatibility with other MCP-compliant services.

## Key Features

- **Universal MCP Framework**: Built on the standardized MCP protocol
- **Calendly Integration**: Direct access to Calendly's scheduling functionality
- **Easy Setup**: Quick start through agentr.dev or local development
- **Standardized API**: Compatible with other MCP-compliant tools

## Quick Start

### Option 1: Use via agentr.dev (Recommended)
1. Visit [agentr.dev/apps](https://agentr.dev/apps)
2. Enable the Calendly integration
3. If new to Universal MCP, follow the setup at [agentr.dev/quickstart](https://agentr.dev/quickstart)

### Option 2: Local Development

**Prerequisites:**
- Python 3.11+
- [uv](https://github.com/astral-sh/uv) package manager

**Setup Steps:**
```bash
# 1. Install dependencies
uv sync

# 2. Activate virtual environment
source .venv/bin/activate  # Linux/macOS
# or
.venv\Scripts\Activate     # Windows PowerShell

# 3. Start MCP inspector
mcp dev src/universal_mcp_calendly/server.py

# 4. Install the application
mcp install src/universal_mcp_calendly/server.py
```

## Project Structure

```
src/
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ universal_mcp_calendly/
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ __init__.py     # Package initializer
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ server.py       # Server entry point
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ app.py          # Application tools
    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ README.md       # Tool documentation
```

## Resources

- **GitHub Repository**: [universal-mcp/calendly](https://github.com/universal-mcp/calendly)
- **Available Tools**: See `./src/universal_mcp_calendly/README.md` in the repository
- **Framework**: Universal MCP
- **License**: MIT

This server enables seamless integration of Calendly's scheduling capabilities into MCP-compatible applications and workflows.

raw_output:
# GemForge - Gemini Tools MCP Server

GemForge is a specialized MCP (Model Context Protocol) server that provides seamless integration with Google's Gemini AI models. It offers four powerful tools designed to handle different AI tasks with intelligent model selection and advanced file handling capabilities.

## üöÄ Key Features

- **Intelligent Model Selection**: Automatically chooses the best Gemini model for each task
- **Multi-Modal Support**: Handles text, PDFs, images, and code files
- **Advanced Reasoning**: Step-by-step problem solving with transparent reasoning
- **Real-time Information**: Search capabilities with latest information via Google Search
- **Code Analysis**: Integrated with Repomix for comprehensive codebase analysis

## üõ†Ô∏è Available Tools

### 1. **gemini_search**
Perfect for general knowledge questions and fact-checking using Gemini 2.0 Flash with Google Search integration.

**Best for:**
- Current events and latest information
- Fact-checking and verification
- General knowledge queries
- Research assistance

**Key Parameters:**
- `query` (required): Your search question
- `file_path` (optional): Include files with your query
- `enable_thinking` (optional): Enable step-by-step reasoning mode

### 2. **gemini_reason**
Tackles complex problems with detailed reasoning using Gemini 2.0 Flash Thinking model.

**Best for:**
- Mathematical problem solving
- Scientific calculations
- Coding challenges
- Logic puzzles
- Complex analysis requiring transparent reasoning

**Key Parameters:**
- `problem` (required): The complex problem to solve
- `show_steps` (optional): Display detailed reasoning process
- `file_path` (optional): Include relevant files

### 3. **gemini_code**
Analyzes entire codebases using Repomix integration and Gemini 2.5 Pro.

**Best for:**
- Code review and analysis
- Architecture understanding
- Bug detection
- Performance optimization suggestions
- Documentation generation

**Key Parameters:**
- `question` (required): Your code-related question
- `directory_path` OR `codebase_path`: Source code location
- Supports both live directories and pre-packed Repomix files

### 4. **gemini_fileops**
Efficiently processes various file types with smart model selection (Flash-Lite for speed, 1.5 Pro for large files).

**Best for:**
- Document summarization
- Data extraction from PDFs/images
- Content analysis
- Multi-file processing

**Key Parameters:**
- `file_path` (required): Single file or array of files
- `operation`: Choose from "summarize", "extract", or "analyze"
- `instruction` (optional): Specific processing instructions
- `use_large_context_model`: Force use of Gemini 1.5 Pro for very large files

## üéØ Use Cases

- **Research & Analysis**: Combine search with file analysis for comprehensive research
- **Code Development**: From understanding existing codebases to solving complex algorithms
- **Document Processing**: Batch process documents with intelligent summarization
- **Problem Solving**: Step-by-step solutions for complex mathematical or logical problems
- **Content Creation**: Analyze and extract insights from various media types

## üîß Integration

GemForge integrates seamlessly with Claude and other MCP-compatible hosts, providing a standardized interface for accessing Google's most advanced AI models. The server handles authentication, model selection, and optimization automatically.

**Server ID:** `@pv-bhat/gemforge-gemini-tools-mcp`

This MCP server transforms how you interact with Gemini models, making advanced AI capabilities easily accessible through a unified, intelligent interface.

# click-mcp

A Python library that turns Click CLI applications into Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers with just one line of code. This enables AI agents to discover and interact with your CLI tools programmatically.

## Key Features

- **Simple decorator syntax**: Just add `@click_mcp` to your Click application
- **Automatic conversion**: Click commands become MCP tools automatically
- **Full Click support**: Works with nested command groups and positional arguments
- **Easy integration**: Stdio-based MCP server for seamless AI agent interaction

## Quick Start

```python
import click
from click_mcp import click_mcp

@click_mcp(server_name="my-cli-app")
@click.group()
def cli():
    """Sample CLI application."""
    pass

@cli.command()
@click.option('--name', required=True, help='Name to greet')
def greet(name):
    """Greet someone."""
    click.echo(f"Hello, {name}!")

if __name__ == '__main__':
    cli()
```

Start the MCP server:
```bash
python my_app.py mcp
```

## How It Works

- Click commands are automatically converted to MCP tools
- Nested commands use dot notation (e.g., `users.create`)
- All Click parameter types are supported (options, arguments, flags)
- AI agents can invoke tools via standard MCP protocol

## Use Cases

- **DevOps automation**: Make deployment scripts accessible to AI agents
- **Data processing**: Expose data transformation tools to AI workflows
- **System administration**: Allow AI to interact with management utilities
- **CI/CD integration**: Enable AI-driven pipeline operations

## Advanced Features

- Custom MCP command names
- Custom server names for identification
- Support for complex nested command structures
- Proper handling of positional arguments and flags
- Full parameter validation and error handling

Perfect for developers who want to quickly expose existing Click CLI tools to AI agents without rewriting their applications.

{'server_name': 'remote-mcp-server-demo', 'server_id': 'elithrar/remote-mcp-server-demo', 'description': '', 'readme': '# Remote MCP Server on Cloudflare Let's get a remote MCP server up-and-running on Cloudflare Workers complete with OAuth login! ## Develop locally ```bash # clone the repository git clone git@github.com:cloudflare/ai.git # install dependencies cd ai npm install # run locally npx nx dev remote-mcp-server ``` You should be able to open [`http://localhost:8787/`](http://localhost:8787/) in your browser ## Connect the MCP inspector to your server To explore your new MCP api, you can use the [MCP Inspector](https://modelcontextprotocol.io/docs/tools/inspector). - Start it with `npx @modelcontextprotocol/inspector` - [Within the inspector](http://localhost:5173), switch the Transport Type to `SSE` and enter `http://localhost:8787/sse` as the URL of the MCP server to connect to, and click "Connect" - You will navigate to a (mock) user/password login screen. Input any email and pass to login. - You should be redirected back to the MCP Inspector and you can now list and call any defined tools!
## Connect Claude Desktop to your local MCP server The MCP inspector is great, but we really want to connect this to Claude! Follow [Anthropic's Quickstart](https://modelcontextprotocol.io/quickstart/user) and within Claude Desktop go to Settings > Developer > Edit Config to find your configuration file. Open the file in your text editor and replace it with this configuration: ```json { "mcpServers": { "math": { "command": "npx", "args": [ "mcp-remote", "http://localhost:8787/sse" ] } } } ``` This will run a local proxy and let Claude talk to your MCP server over HTTP When you open Claude a browser window should open and allow you to login. You should see the tools available in the bottom right. Given the right prompt Claude should ask to call the tool.
## Deploy to Cloudflare 1. `npx wrangler kv namespace create OAUTH_KV` 2. Follow the guidance to add the kv namespace ID to `wrangler.jsonc` 3. `npm run deploy` ## Call your newly deployed remote MCP server from a remote MCP client Just like you did above in "Develop locally", run the MCP inspector: `npx @modelcontextprotocol/inspector@latest` Then enter the `workers.dev` URL (ex: `worker-name.account-name.workers.dev/sse`) of your Worker in the inspector as the URL of the MCP server to connect to, and click "Connect". You've now connected to your MCP server from a remote MCP client. ## Connect Claude Desktop to your remote MCP server Update the Claude configuration file to point to your `workers.dev` URL (ex: `worker-name.account-name.workers.dev/sse`) and restart Claude ```json { "mcpServers": { "math": { "command": "npx", "args": [ "mcp-remote", "https://worker-name.account-name.workers.dev/sse" ] } } } ``` ## Debugging Should anything go wrong it can be helpful to restart Claude, or to try connecting directly to your MCP server on the command line with the following command. ```bash npx mcp-remote http://localhost:8787/sse ``` In some rare cases it may help to clear the files added to `~/.mcp-auth` ```bash rm -rf ~/.mcp-auth ``` ', 'tools': [{'name': 'SSE', 'description': 'and enter `http://localhost:8787/sse` as the URL of the MCP server to connect to, and click "Connect"', 'inputSchema': {'type': 'object', 'properties': {'url': {'type': 'string', 'description': 'URL or link to process'}}, 'required': ['url']}, 'source': 'readme', 'access_level': 'read'}], 'tools_count': 1, 'homepage': '', 'url': 'https://github.com/elithrar/remote-mcp-server-demo', 'topics': [], 'data_sources': ['github']}
raw_output:
This is a fantastic demo of a **Remote MCP Server running on Cloudflare Workers**! This project shows how to build and deploy an MCP (Model Context Protocol) server that can be accessed remotely via HTTP/SSE (Server-Sent Events) rather than just locally.

## Key Features

üåê **Remote MCP Server**: Unlike typical MCP servers that run locally, this runs on Cloudflare Workers and can be accessed from anywhere

üîê **OAuth Authentication**: Includes a complete OAuth login flow for secure access

üõ†Ô∏è **Math Tools**: Provides mathematical operation tools that can be called by Claude or other MCP clients

üì° **SSE Transport**: Uses Server-Sent Events for real-time communication with MCP clients

## What Makes This Special

1. **Cloud-Hosted**: The MCP server runs on Cloudflare's edge network, making it globally accessible
2. **Production Ready**: Includes proper authentication and can be deployed to production
3. **Multiple Client Support**: Works with both the MCP Inspector and Claude Desktop
4. **Easy Development**: Simple local development setup with hot reloading

## How It Works

The server exposes an `/sse` endpoint that MCP clients can connect to. When you connect:
1. You're redirected to an OAuth login page
2. After authentication, you're connected back to the MCP server
3. Claude (or other clients) can then discover and use the available tools

## Perfect For

- **Learning MCP**: Great example of how remote MCP servers work
- **Production MCP Services**: Template for building scalable MCP servers
- **Team Collaboration**: Multiple users can access the same MCP server
- **Enterprise Use**: Centralized tool access with proper authentication

This demo really showcases the potential of remote MCP servers - instead of each user running tools locally, you can centralize powerful tools and services in the cloud while maintaining the MCP protocol's elegant tool discovery and execution model.

# Glutamate MCP Servers Welcome to the Glutamate MCP Servers repository! This project contains a collection of MCPs (Model Context Protocol) servers that are made by gluamate team can be easily deployed and managed through the Glutamate platform. We support all stdio and sse servers by any creators. ## üé• Introduction Video

## About Glutamate [Glutamate](https://glutamateapp.com) is a powerful desktop platform that simplifies the deployment and management of Model Context Protocol servers. It provides a user-friendly interface and robust tools for server administration, making it easier than ever to run and customize your MCP servers. Key Features: - üîí All keys are securely stored locally - ‚ö° Install & Start/Stop MCP servers on your local machine - üíª Full support for both stdio & SSE protocols - üì¶ No Node.js installation required on your system - üéÅ 100% free to use , now and forever - Avaible on Windows , Linux and Mac (coming soon) ## Road Map: - [x] Auto Sync (server config and port) with any client (cursor , windsurf , cline , roocode etc..) (Added in v0.0.5) - [ ] Auto start of mcp severs on start of glutamate (based on user settings) - [ ] Oath login for mcps to fetch api keys - [ ] Versioning of MCP servers for easier management and updates - [ ] User submission of servers - [ ] Direct Updater of Glutamate ## Custom Made Servers Our repository includes several custom MCP servers that are created by Glutamate Team , We support all stdio and sse server that are node based on our glutamate app ### UI Assist Located in the `src/uiassist` directory, UI Assist is a specialized server that provides enhanced user interface capabilities for MCP servers. It offers: - Custom UI components - Improved user experience - Streamlined navigation - Modern interface design More servers will be added to this repository in the future, expanding the available options for MCP administrators. ## Getting Started 1. Visit [glutamateapp.com](https://glutamateapp.com) 2. Download the app 3. Choose your desired MCP server from the available options 4. Click to install and just connect ## Available MCP Servers (adding more everyday ) For a comprehensive list of available MCP servers and their descriptions, please see our [SERVERS.md](SERVERS.md) file. ## Contributing We welcome contributions to improve our MCP servers. Please feel free to submit pull requests, report issues, or suggest new features. ## Glutamate App Integration To integrate your MCP server with the Glutamate app, you need to create a metadata file that describes your server's capabilities. This helps the Glutamate app understand and properly integrate with your MCP server. ### Important Note for SSE Servers All SSE-type MCP servers must accept the `--port` command line argument to be supported in the Glutamate app. This allows the Glutamate app to dynamically assign ports and manage multiple server instances. Make sure your server implementation includes this functionality. ### Important Note for Connection Type The `connectionType` field in the metadata file must be specified in lowercase. Only two values are supported: - `"sse"` for Server-Sent Events - `"stdio"` for Standard Input/Output Any other value or capitalization will not be recognized by the Glutamate app. ### Creating Metadata File Create a file named `glutamate.json` in your project root with the following structure: ```json { "name": "UI Assist MCP Server", "description": "A Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that connects with the UI Assist Chrome extension to help with UI-based input in web development", "version": "0.1.0", "releaseDate": "YYYY-MM-DD", "author": "Your Name or Organization", "license": "MIT", "repositoryUrl": "https://github.com/username/repository", "implementationLanguage": "JavaScript", "connectionType": "sse", "runtimeRequirements": "Node.js", "packageName": "@glutamateapp/ui-assist", "color": "#HEXCOLOR", "tools": [ { "name": "get_selected_elements", "description": "Retrieves HTML elements that have been selected in the browser" }, { "name": "clear_selected_elements", "de [...truncated for length...]', 'tools': [{'name': 'connectionType', 'description': 'field in the metadata file must be specified in lowercase. Only two values are supported:', 'inputSchema': {'type': 'object', 'properties': {'file_path': {'type': 'string', 'description': 'File path or file to process'}, 'amount': {'type': 'number', 'description': 'Numeric amount or value'}}, 'required': ['file_path', 'amount']}, 'source': 'readme', 'access_level': 'read'}], 'tools_count': 1, 'homepage': 'https://glutamateapp.com/', 'url': 'https://github.com/ShadowCloneLabs/GlutamateMCPServers', 'topics': ['desktop-app', 'free', 'linux', 'macos', 'mcp', 'mcpservers', 'windows'], 'data_sources': ['github']}
raw_output:
# Glutamate MCP Servers

Glutamate is an impressive desktop platform that streamlines the deployment and management of Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers. This project offers a comprehensive solution for running and customizing MCP servers with an intuitive user interface.

## üåü Key Highlights

### Core Features
- üîí **Secure Local Storage** - All API keys stored locally on your machine
- ‚ö° **Easy Management** - Install, start, and stop MCP servers with simple clicks
- üíª **Universal Protocol Support** - Full compatibility with both stdio & SSE protocols
- üì¶ **Zero Dependencies** - No Node.js installation required
- üéÅ **Completely Free** - 100% free to use, now and forever
- üñ•Ô∏è **Cross-Platform** - Available on Windows, Linux, and Mac (coming soon)

### Auto-Sync Capability
One standout feature is the auto-sync functionality (added in v0.0.5) that automatically synchronizes server configurations and ports with popular AI coding clients like:
- Cursor
- Windsurf
- Cline
- Roocode

## üó∫Ô∏è Development Roadmap

The project has an ambitious roadmap including:
- ‚úÖ Auto Sync with AI clients (completed)
- üîÑ Auto-start servers on app launch
- üîê OAuth login integration for API key management
- üìä Server versioning system
- üë• Community server submissions
- üîÑ Direct app updater

## üõ†Ô∏è Custom Servers

The repository includes custom-built MCP servers, with **UI Assist** being a notable example that provides enhanced user interface capabilities and modern design components.

## üöÄ Getting Started

1. Visit [glutamateapp.com](https://glutamateapp.com)
2. Download the desktop application
3. Browse and select your desired MCP servers
4. Install with one click and connect instantly

## üìã Developer Integration

For developers wanting to integrate their MCP servers with Glutamate, the platform requires:

- A `glutamate.json` metadata file in the project root
- SSE servers must accept `--port` command line arguments
- Connection type must be specified as either `"sse"` or `"stdio"` in lowercase

## üéØ Perfect For

- Developers working with AI coding assistants
- Teams needing streamlined MCP server management  
- Anyone wanting a user-friendly interface for protocol servers
- Projects requiring secure, local API key management

The combination of ease-of-use, security, and comprehensive feature set makes Glutamate an excellent choice for managing MCP servers in development environments.

{'server_name': 'REDIS-MCP-Server', 'server_id': 'gongrzhe/redis-mcp-server', 'description': 'Redis database operations and caching microservice server with support for key-value operations, expiration management, and pattern-based key listing.', 'readme': '# Redis MCP Server (@gongrzhe/server-redis-mcp@1.0.0)

![](https://badge.mcpx.dev?type=server 'MCP Server')
[![smithery badge](https://smithery.ai/badge/@gongrzhe/server-redis-mcp)](https://smithery.ai/server/@gongrzhe/server-redis-mcp)

A Redis Model Context Protocol (MCP) server implementation for interacting with Redis databases. This server enables LLMs to interact with Redis key-value stores through a set of standardized tools.

## Update
62 Redis MCP tools in https://github.com/GongRzhe/REDIS-MCP-Server/tree/redis-plus

## Installation & Usage

### Installing via Smithery

To install Redis MCP Server for Claude Desktop automatically via [Smithery](https://smithery.ai/server/@gongrzhe/server-redis-mcp):

```bash
npx -y @smithery/cli install @gongrzhe/server-redis-mcp --client claude
```

### Installing Manually
```bash
# Using npx with specific version (recommended)
npx @gongrzhe/server-redis-mcp@1.0.0 redis://your-redis-host:port

# Example:
npx @gongrzhe/server-redis-mcp@1.0.0 redis://localhost:6379
```

Or install globally:

```bash
# Install specific version globally
npm install -g @gongrzhe/server-redis-mcp@1.0.0

# Run after global installation
@gongrzhe/server-redis-mcp redis://your-redis-host:port
```

## Components

### Tools

- **set**
  - Set a Redis key-value pair with optional expiration
  - Input:
    - `key` (string): Redis key
    - `value` (string): Value to store
    - `expireSeconds` (number, optional): Expiration time in seconds

- **get**
  - Get value by key from Redis
  - Input: `key` (string): Redis key to retrieve

- **delete**
  - Delete one or more keys from Redis
  - Input: `key` (string | string[]): Key or array of keys to delete

- **list**
  - List Redis keys matching a pattern
  - Input: `pattern` (string, optional): Pattern to match keys (default: *)

## Configuration

### Usage with Claude Desktop

To use this server with the Claude Desktop app, add the following configuration to the "mcpServers" section of your `claude_desktop_config.json`:

```json
{
  "mcpServers": {
    "redis": {
      "command": "npx",
      "args": [
        "@gongrzhe/server-redis-mcp@1.0.0",
        "redis://localhost:6379"
      ]
    }
  }
}
```

Alternatively, you can use the node command directly if you have the package installed:

```json
{
  "mcpServers": {
    "redis": {
      "command": "node",
      "args": [
        "path/to/build/index.js",
        "redis://10.1.210.223:6379"
      ]
    }
  }
}
```

### Docker Usage

When using Docker:
* For macOS, use `host.docker.internal` if the Redis server is running on the host network
* Redis URL can be specified as an argument, defaults to "redis://localhost:6379"

```json
{
  "mcpServers": {
    "redis": {
      "command": "docker",
      "args": [
        "run", 
        "-i", 
        "--rm", 
        "mcp/redis", 
        "redis://host.docker.internal:6379"
      ]
    }
  }
}
```

## Development

### Building from Source

1. Clone the repository
2. Install dependencies:
   ```bash
   npm install
   ```
3. Build the project:
   ```bash
   npm run build
   ```

### Docker Build

```bash
docker build -t mcp/redis .
```

## License

This MCP server is licensed under the ISC License. For more details, please see the LICENSE file in the project repository.

# Redis MCP Server

A comprehensive Redis database operations server for the Model Context Protocol (MCP) that enables LLMs to interact with Redis key-value stores through standardized tools.

## üöÄ Quick Start

### Automatic Installation (Recommended)
```bash
npx -y @smithery/cli install @gongrzhe/server-redis-mcp --client claude
```

### Manual Installation
```bash
# Using npx (recommended)
npx @gongrzhe/server-redis-mcp@1.0.0 redis://localhost:6379

# Or install globally
npm install -g @gongrzhe/server-redis-mcp@1.0.0
```

## üõ†Ô∏è Features

### Core Tools
- **set** - Store key-value pairs with optional expiration
- **get** - Retrieve values by key
- **delete** - Remove one or multiple keys
- **list** - Find keys using pattern matching

### Advanced Capabilities
- ‚è∞ Expiration management for temporary data
- üîç Pattern-based key discovery
- üîÑ Batch operations support
- üåê Flexible connection options

## ‚öôÔ∏è Configuration

### Claude Desktop Setup
Add to your `claude_desktop_config.json`:

```json
{
  "mcpServers": {
    "redis": {
      "command": "npx",
      "args": [
        "@gongrzhe/server-redis-mcp@1.0.0",
        "redis://localhost:6379"
      ]
    }
  }
}
```

### Docker Configuration
```json
{
  "mcpServers": {
    "redis": {
      "command": "docker",
      "args": [
        "run", "-i", "--rm", "mcp/redis", 
        "redis://host.docker.internal:6379"
      ]
    }
  }
}
```

## üìñ Usage Examples

### Basic Operations
- **Store data**: `set mykey "hello world" 3600` (expires in 1 hour)
- **Retrieve data**: `get mykey`
- **Delete keys**: `delete ["key1", "key2"]`
- **List keys**: `list "user:*"` (find all user keys)

### Use Cases
- üóÑÔ∏è Caching frequently accessed data
- üìä Session management
- üî¢ Rate limiting counters
- üèÉ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è Temporary data storage

## üîß Development

```bash
# Clone and build
git clone https://github.com/GongRzhe/REDIS-MCP-Server
npm install && npm run build

# Docker build
docker build -t mcp/redis .
```

## üìà Extended Version
Access **62 additional Redis tools** in the [redis-plus branch](https://github.com/GongRzhe/REDIS-MCP-Server/tree/redis-plus) for advanced Redis operations.

## üìÑ License
ISC License - see repository for details.

---

*Perfect for integrating Redis caching and data operations into your LLM workflows with full MCP compatibility.*

Install dependencies: ```bash npm install ``` 2. Create a `.env` file based on `.env.example` and fill in your Jira credentials: ```env JIRA_HOST=https://your-domain.atlassian.net JIRA_EMAIL=your-email@example.com JIRA_API_TOKEN=your-api-token PORT=3000 ``` To get your Jira API token: 1. Log in to 2. Click "Create API token" 3. Copy the token and paste it in your `.env` file ## Development Run the development server: ```bash npm run dev ``` ## Build and Run Build the project: ```bash npm run build ``` Start the server: ```bash npm start ``` ## Cursor Integration To use this MCP server with Cursor, you have two options: ### Option 1: Command-based Integration (Recommended) 1. Build the project: ```bash npm run build ``` 2. Open Cursor's settings: - Click on the Cursor menu - Select "Settings" (or use the keyboard shortcut) - Navigate to the "Extensions" or "Integrations" section 3. Add the MCP configuration: ```json { "mcpServers": { "jira": { "command": "node", "args": ["/path/to/jira-mcp-cursor/dist/server.js"] } } } ``` Replace `/path/to/jira-mcp-cursor` with the absolute path to your project. ### Option 2: HTTP-based Integration (Alternative) 1. Start the MCP server (if not already running): ```bash npm start ``` 2. Open Cursor's settings: * Click on the Cursor menu * Select "Settings" (or use the keyboard shortcut) * Navigate to the "Extensions" or "Integrations" section 3. `/jira list` - List your tickets - `/jira view TICKET-123` - View ticket details - `/jira comments TICKET-123` - Get ticket comments - `/jira create` - Create a new ticket - `/jira comment TICKET-123` - Add a comment - `/jira status TICKET-123` - Update ticket status ## MCP Protocol Support The server implements the Model-Client-Protocol (MCP) required by Cursor: - Stdio communication for command-based integration - Tool registration for Jira operations ## API Endpoints ### List Tickets Retrieves a list of Jira tickets, optionally filtered by a JQL query. **Endpoint:** `GET /api/tickets` **Query Parameters:** | Parameter | Type | Required | Description | |-----------|------|----------|-------------| | jql | string | No | Jira Query Language (JQL) string to filter tickets | **Example Request:** ```http GET /api/tickets?jql=project=TEST+AND+status=Open ``` **Example Response:** ```text TEST-123: Example ticket (Open) TEST-124: Another ticket (In Progress) ``` ### Get Ticket Retrieves detailed information about a specific ticket. **Endpoint:** `GET /api/tickets/:id` **Path Parameters:** | Parameter | Type | Required | Description | |-----------|------|----------|-------------| | id | string | Yes | The Jira ticket ID (e.g., TEST-123) | **Example Request:** ```http GET /api/tickets/TEST-123 ``` **Example Response:** ```text Key: TEST-123 Summary: Example ticket Status: Open Type: Task Description: Detailed ticket description ``` ### Get Ticket Comments Retrieves all comments for a specific ticket. **Endpoint:** `GET /api/tickets/:id/comments` **Path Parameters:** | Parameter | Type | Required | Description | |-----------|------|----------|-------------| | id | string | Yes | The Jira ticket ID (e.g., TEST-123) | **Example Request:** ```http GET /api/tickets/TEST-123/comments ``` **Example Response:** ```text [3/20/2024, 10:00:00 AM] John Doe: Comment text --- [3/20/2024, 9:30:00 AM] Jane Smith: Another comment --- ``` ### Create Ticket Creates a new Jira ticket. **Endpoint:** `POST /api/tickets` **Request Body:** | Parameter | Type | R [...truncated for length...]', 'tools': [], 'tools_count': 0, 'homepage': '', 'url': 'https://github.com/kornbed/jira-mcp-server', 'topics': [], 'data_sources': ['github']}

# Jira MCP Server for Cursor

This is a TypeScript-based MCP (Model Context Protocol) server that provides seamless integration between Cursor IDE and Jira. It allows you to interact with Jira tickets directly from within Cursor.

## üöÄ Features

- **List Jira tickets** with JQL filtering
- **Get detailed ticket information**
- **View and manage ticket comments**
- **Create new tickets**
- **Update ticket status**
- **Add comments to existing tickets**
- Full MCP protocol support for Cursor integration

## üì¶ Installation

### Quick Install via Smithery

```bash
npx -y @smithery/cli install @kornbed/jira-mcp-server --client claude
```

### Manual Setup

1. **Clone and install dependencies:**
```bash
git clone https://github.com/kornbed/jira-mcp-server
cd jira-mcp-server
npm install
```

2. **Configure environment variables:**
Create a `.env` file with your Jira credentials:
```env
JIRA_HOST=https://your-domain.atlassian.net
JIRA_EMAIL=your-email@example.com
JIRA_API_TOKEN=your-api-token
PORT=3000
```

3. **Get your Jira API token:**
   - Visit [Atlassian API Tokens](https://id.atlassian.com/manage/api-tokens)
   - Click "Create API token"
   - Copy and paste into your `.env` file

## ‚öôÔ∏è Cursor Integration

### Option 1: Command-based (Recommended)

1. Build the project:
```bash
npm run build
```

2. Add to Cursor settings:
```json
{
  "mcpServers": {
    "jira": {
      "command": "node",
      "args": ["/path/to/jira-mcp-server/dist/server.js"]
    }
  }
}
```

### Option 2: HTTP-based

1. Start the server:
```bash
npm start
```

2. Configure Cursor:
```json
{
  "mcpServers": {
    "jira": {
      "url": "http://localhost:3000",
      "capabilities": [
        "list_tickets",
        "get_ticket",
        "get_comments",
        "create_ticket",
        "update_status",
        "add_comment"
      ]
    }
  }
}
```

## üíª Usage in Cursor

Once configured, you can use these commands directly in Cursor:

- `/jira list` - List your tickets
- `/jira view TICKET-123` - View ticket details
- `/jira comments TICKET-123` - Get ticket comments
- `/jira create` - Create a new ticket
- `/jira comment TICKET-123` - Add a comment
- `/jira status TICKET-123` - Update ticket status

## üõ†Ô∏è Development

```bash
# Development mode
npm run dev

# Build
npm run build

# Start production server
npm start
```

## üì° API Reference

### List Tickets
- **GET** `/api/tickets?jql=<query>`
- Filter tickets using JQL (Jira Query Language)

### Get Ticket Details
- **GET** `/api/tickets/:id`
- Retrieve detailed information for a specific ticket

### Get Comments
- **GET** `/api/tickets/:id/comments`
- Fetch all comments for a ticket

### Create Ticket
- **POST** `/api/tickets`
- Create a new Jira ticket

### Update Status
- **PUT** `/api/tickets/:id/status`
- Change ticket status

### Add Comment
- **POST** `/api/tickets/:id/comments`
- Add a comment to an existing ticket

## üîó Links

- **GitHub**: [kornbed/jira-mcp-server](https://github.com/kornbed/jira-mcp-server)
- **Smithery**: [@kornbed/jira-mcp-server](https://smithery.ai/server/@kornbed/jira-mcp-server)

This server implements the MCP protocol for seamless integration with Cursor, enabling efficient Jira workflow management directly from your IDE.

raw_output:
# DBHub - Universal Database MCP Server

DBHub is a comprehensive Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that provides a unified gateway to connect AI assistants like Claude and Cursor to multiple database systems including PostgreSQL, MySQL, SQLite, DuckDB, and more.

## Key Features

### üîå Universal Database Connectivity
- **Supported Databases**: PostgreSQL, MySQL, MariaDB, SQL Server, SQLite, Oracle
- **Unified Interface**: Single MCP server for all your database needs
- **Easy Integration**: Works with Claude Desktop, Cursor, and other MCP clients

### üõ†Ô∏è Core Tools

**execute_sql** - Execute single or multiple SQL statements
- Supports all major database systems
- Can handle multiple statements separated by semicolons
- **Access Level**: Execute

**generate_sql** - AI-powered SQL generation
- Generate SQL queries from natural language descriptions
- **Access Level**: Write

**explain_db** - Database explanation and documentation
- Get detailed explanations of database elements and structures
- **Access Level**: Read

### üìä Database Resources
Access comprehensive database metadata through structured URIs:
- `db://schemas` - List all schemas
- `db://schemas/{schema}/tables` - Tables in a schema
- `db://schemas/{schema}/tables/{table}` - Table structure details
- `db://schemas/{schema}/tables/{table}/indexes` - Table indexes
- `db://schemas/{schema}/procedures` - Stored procedures

## Quick Start

### Docker Installation
```bash
# Connect to your database
docker run --rm --init \
   --name dbhub \
   --publish 8080:8080 \
   bytebase/dbhub \
   --transport http \
   --port 8080 \
   --dsn "postgres://user:password@localhost:5432/dbname?sslmode=disable"
```

### Demo Mode
Try DBHub instantly with the sample employee database:
```bash
docker run --rm --init \
   --name dbhub \
   --publish 8080:8080 \
   bytebase/dbhub \
   --transport http \
   --port 8080 \
   --demo
```

## Configuration Options

| Environment Variable | Description | Default |
|---------------------|-------------|---------|
| `DSN` | Database connection string | Required |
| `TRANSPORT` | Transport mode: `stdio` or `http` | `stdio` |
| `PORT` | HTTP server port | `8080` |
| `READONLY` | Restrict to read-only operations | `false` |

## Use Cases

- **Database Exploration**: Quickly understand database schemas and structures
- **SQL Generation**: Generate complex queries from natural language
- **Data Analysis**: Execute analytical queries across different database systems
- **Documentation**: Auto-generate database documentation and explanations
- **Multi-Database Management**: Manage multiple database types through a single interface

## Demo Endpoint
Test DBHub immediately at: https://demo.dbhub.ai/message

This connects to a sample employee database and can be used with Cursor or MCP Inspector to see DBHub in action.

DBHub streamlines database operations for AI assistants, making it easier than ever to work with data across multiple database platforms through natural language interactions.

{'server_name': 'n8n-workflow-builder', 'server_id': 'makafeli/n8n-workflow-builder', 'description': 'MCP server for programmatically creating and managing n8n workflows', 'readme': '[![MseeP.ai Security Assessment Badge](https://mseep.net/pr/makafeli-n8n-workflow-builder-badge.png)](https://mseep.ai/app/makafeli-n8n-workflow-builder)

# n8n Workflow Builder MCP Server

This project provides an MCP server for managing n8n workflows. It offers functionality to list, create, update, delete, activate, and deactivate workflows through a set of defined tools.

**Important:**  
This version exclusively supports **npm** for package management and running the server. (npx support will be reintroduced in a future update.)

## Requirements

- Node.js (v14+ recommended)
- npm

## Extensive Installation Guide

### 1. Clone the Repository

Clone the repository from your preferred source. For example:

```bash
git clone https://github.com/makafeli/n8n-workflow-builder.git
```

Then, navigate to the project directory:

```bash
cd /root/n8n-workflow-builder
```

### 2. Install Dependencies

Install the necessary dependencies using npm:

```bash
npm install
```

This command will download and install all required packages as defined in the `package.json` file.

### 3. Build and Test

For testing and getting the server online, use the following commands:

- **Build the project:**  
  This compiles the TypeScript files and produces the executable JavaScript in the `build` directory.
  
  ```bash
  npm run build
  ```

- **Start the MCP Server:**  
  Launch the server using:
  
  ```bash
  npm start
  ```

The server will start and connect via stdio. You can check the console to see messages confirming that the server has started correctly.

### 4. Deployment

For testing purposes and to get the server online, use the build and start commands mentioned above. This basic workflow (install, build, start) is currently the recommended method.

### 5. Additional Configuration

Server configuration for [Cline](https://cline.bot) is managed via the `cline_mcp_settings.json` file. Ensure that the following environment variables are correctly set:

- `N8N_HOST`: Your n8n API host URL.
- `N8N_API_KEY`: Your n8n API key.

Example configuration in `cline_mcp_settings.json`:

```json
{
  "n8n-workflow-builder": {
    "command": "node",
    "args": ["/root/n8n-workflow-builder/build/index.js"],
    "env": {
      "N8N_HOST": "https://n8n.io/api/v1/",
      "N8N_API_KEY": "YOUR_N8N_API_KEY_HERE"
    },
    "disabled": false,
    "alwaysAllow": [
      "create_workflow",
      "create_workflow_and_activate",
      "update_workflow",
      "activate_workflow",
      "deactivate_workflow",
      "get_workflow",
      "delete_workflow"
    ],
    "autoApprove": []
  }
}
```

## Available Features

### MCP Tools

The following tools are defined in the server and can be accessed through your MCP client:

#### Workflow Management
- **list_workflows**: Lists all workflows from n8n.
- **create_workflow**: Creates a new workflow in n8n.
- **get_workflow**: Retrieves a workflow by its ID.
- **update_workflow**: Updates an existing workflow.
- **delete_workflow**: Deletes a workflow by its ID.
- **activate_workflow**: Activates a workflow by its ID.
- **deactivate_workflow**: Deactivates a workflow by its ID.

#### Execution Management
- **list_executions**: Lists all workflow executions with optional filters.
- **get_execution**: Retrieves details of a specific execution by its ID.
- **delete_execution**: Deletes an execution by its ID.

### MCP Resources

The server also provides the following resources for more efficient context access:

#### Static Resources
- **/workflows**: List of all available workflows in the n8n instance
- **/execution-stats**: Summary statistics about workflow executions

#### Dynamic Resource Templates
- **/workflows/{id}**: Detailed information about a specific workflow
- **/executions/{id}**: Detailed information about a specific execution

## Troubleshooting

- Ensure you are using npm (this version does not support npx).
- If you encounter any issues, try cleaning the build directory and rebuilding:
  ```bash
  npm run clean && npm run build
  ```
- Verify that your environment variables in `cline_mcp_settings.json` are correct.

## Future Enhancements

- Reintroduction of npx support.
- Additional tools and workflow features.
- Further enhancements to deployment and scaling.

## License

This project is licensed under the MIT License.

raw_output:
# n8n Workflow Builder MCP Server

This is a Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that provides programmatic access to n8n workflows, allowing you to create, manage, and monitor workflows through a standardized interface.

## üöÄ Key Features

### Workflow Management
- **List workflows** - View all available workflows
- **Create workflows** - Build new automation workflows
- **Update workflows** - Modify existing workflow configurations
- **Delete workflows** - Remove workflows from your n8n instance
- **Activate/Deactivate** - Control workflow execution state
- **Get workflow details** - Retrieve specific workflow information

### Execution Management
- **List executions** - View workflow execution history with filters
- **Get execution details** - Inspect specific execution results
- **Delete executions** - Clean up execution history
- **Execution statistics** - Monitor performance and usage

### MCP Resources
- Static resources for workflows and execution stats
- Dynamic resource templates for detailed workflow and execution data

## üìã Requirements

- Node.js (v14+)
- npm package manager
- Active n8n instance with API access

## üõ†Ô∏è Installation

1. **Clone the repository:**
```bash
git clone https://github.com/makafeli/n8n-workflow-builder.git
cd n8n-workflow-builder
```

2. **Install dependencies:**
```bash
npm install
```

3. **Build the project:**
```bash
npm run build
```

4. **Start the server:**
```bash
npm start
```

## ‚öôÔ∏è Configuration

Configure the server by setting up your `cline_mcp_settings.json` file:

```json
{
  "n8n-workflow-builder": {
    "command": "node",
    "args": ["/path/to/n8n-workflow-builder/build/index.js"],
    "env": {
      "N8N_HOST": "https://your-n8n-instance.com/api/v1/",
      "N8N_API_KEY": "your_api_key_here"
    },
    "disabled": false,
    "alwaysAllow": [
      "create_workflow",
      "create_workflow_and_activate",
      "update_workflow",
      "activate_workflow",
      "deactivate_workflow",
      "get_workflow",
      "delete_workflow"
    ]
  }
}
```

### Required Environment Variables:
- `N8N_HOST`: Your n8n API endpoint URL
- `N8N_API_KEY`: Your n8n API authentication key

## üîß Available Tools

The server provides these MCP tools for workflow automation:

| Tool | Description |
|------|-------------|
| `list_workflows` | Get all workflows from your n8n instance |
| `create_workflow` | Create a new workflow |
| `get_workflow` | Retrieve specific workflow by ID |
| `update_workflow` | Modify existing workflow |
| `delete_workflow` | Remove workflow by ID |
| `activate_workflow` | Enable workflow execution |
| `deactivate_workflow` | Disable workflow execution |
| `list_executions` | View execution history with filters |
| `get_execution` | Get detailed execution information |
| `delete_execution` | Remove execution record |

## üìä Resources

Access workflow data through MCP resources:

- **Static Resources:**
  - `/workflows` - Complete workflow list
  - `/execution-stats` - Execution statistics summary

- **Dynamic Resources:**
  - `/workflows/{id}` - Specific workflow details
  - `/executions/{id}` - Specific execution details

## üîí Security

This server includes security assessment through MseeP.ai to ensure safe operation with your n8n workflows.

## üêõ Troubleshooting

- **Build issues**: Clean and rebuild with `npm run clean && npm run build`
- **Connection problems**: Verify your `N8N_HOST` and `N8N_API_KEY` settings
- **Permission errors**: Ensure your API key has sufficient permissions for workflow management

## üîÆ Future Enhancements

- npx support reintroduction
- Additional workflow automation features
- Enhanced deployment and scaling options
- Extended monitoring and analytics capabilities

This MCP server bridges the gap between n8n's powerful workflow automation and programmatic access, making it easier to integrate n8n into larger automation ecosystems and development workflows.

raw_output:
This is an interesting MCP (Model Context Protocol) tutorial server! Based on the information provided, this appears to be a comprehensive learning resource for MCP server development.

## Overview

**openmcp-tutorial** is a tutorial server created by lstm-kirigaya that demonstrates how to build MCP servers using different programming languages and frameworks.

## Key Features

The tutorial includes three practical examples:

1. **simple-mcp (Python)** - A basic demonstration using `fastmcp`
2. **bing-images (Python)** - An MCP server that retrieves images from Bing using keywords
3. **my-browser (TypeScript)** - A browser-based MCP server for web information searching

## Available Tool

The server provides one tool:
- **fastmcp**: Specifically related to the bing-images functionality for retrieving images by keywords from Bing

## Getting Started

The tutorial provides setup instructions for both Python and TypeScript:

**Python Setup:**
```bash
cd ~/project/your-mcp-project
uv init
uv add mcp "mcp[cli]"
```

**TypeScript Setup:**
(Instructions appear to be incomplete in the current documentation)

## Use Cases

This tutorial server would be valuable for:
- Learning MCP server development patterns
- Understanding multi-language MCP implementation
- Exploring practical examples like image search and web browsing
- Building foundation knowledge for custom MCP servers

The project serves as both a learning resource and a potential template for future MCP server development projects.

Includes pre-built container images for easy installation.', 'readme': '# Hass-MCP A Model Context Protocol (MCP) server for Home Assistant integration with Claude and other LLMs. ## Overview Hass-MCP enables AI assistants like Claude to interact directly with your Home Assistant instance, allowing them to: - Query the state of devices and sensors - Control lights, switches, and other entities - Get summaries of your smart home - Troubleshoot automations and entities - Search for specific entities - Create guided conversations for common tasks ## Screenshots ## Features - **Entity Management**: Get states, control devices, and search for entities - **Domain Summaries**: Get high-level information about entity types - **Automation Support**: List and control automations - **Guided Conversations**: Use prompts for common tasks like creating automations - **Smart Search**: Find entities by name, type, or state - **Token Efficiency**: Lean JSON responses to minimize token usage ## Installation ### Prerequisites - Home Assistant instance with Long-Lived Access Token - One of the following: - Docker (recommended) - Python 3.13+ and [uv](https://github.com/astral-sh/uv) ## Setting Up With Claude Desktop ### Docker Installation (Recommended) 1. Pull the Docker image: ```bash docker pull voska/hass-mcp:latest ``` 2. Add the MCP server to Claude Desktop: a. Open Claude Desktop and go to Settings b. Navigate to Developer > Edit Config c. Add the following configuration to your `claude_desktop_config.json` file: ```json { "mcpServers": { "hass-mcp": { "command": "docker", "args": [ "run", "-i", "--rm", "-e", "HA_URL", "-e", "HA_TOKEN", "voska/hass-mcp" ], "env": { "HA_URL": "http://homeassistant.local:8123", "HA_TOKEN": "YOUR_LONG_LIVED_TOKEN" } } } } ``` d. Replace `YOUR_LONG_LIVED_TOKEN` with your actual Home Assistant long-lived access token e. Update the `HA_URL`: - If running Home Assistant on the same machine: use `http://host.docker.internal:8123` (Docker Desktop on Mac/Windows) - If running Home Assistant on another machine: use the actual IP or hostname f. Save the file and restart Claude Desktop 3. The "Hass-MCP" tool should now appear in your Claude Desktop tools menu > **Note**: If you're running Home Assistant in Docker on the same machine, you may need to add `--network host` to the Docker args for the container to access Home Assistant. Alternatively, use the IP address of your machine instead of `host.docker.internal`. ## Other MCP Clients ### Cursor 1. Go to Cursor Settings > MCP > Add New MCP Server 2. Fill in the form: - Name: `Hass-MCP` - Type: `command` - Command: ``` docker run -i --rm -e HA_URL=http://homeassistant.local:8123 -e HA_TOKEN=YOUR_LONG_LIVED_TOKEN voska/hass-mcp ``` - Replace `YOUR_LONG_LIVED_TOKEN` with your actual Home Assistant token - Update the HA_URL to match your Home Assistant instance address 3. Click "Add" to save ### Claude Code (CLI) To use with Claude Code CLI, you can add the MCP server directly using the `mcp add` command: **Using Docker (recommended):** ```bash claude mcp add hass-mcp -e HA_URL=http://homeassistant.local:8123 -e HA_TOKEN=YOUR_LONG_LIVED_TOKEN -- docker run -i --rm -e HA_URL -e HA_TOKEN voska/hass-mcp ``` Replace `YOUR_LONG_LIVED_TOKEN` with your actual Home Assistant token and update the HA_URL to match your Home Assistant instance address. ## Usage Examples Here are some examples of prompts you can use with Claude once Hass-MCP is set up: - "What's the current state of my living room lights?" - "Turn off all the lights in the kitchen" - "List all my sensors that contain temperature data" - "Give me a summary of my climate entities" - "Create an automation that turns on the lights at sunset" - "Help me troubleshoot why my bedroom motion sensor automation isn't working" - "Search for entities related to my living room" ## Available Tools Hass-MCP provides several tools for interacting with Home Assistant: - `get_version`: Get the Home Assistant version - `get_entity`: Get the state of a specific entity with optional field filtering - `entity_action`: Perform actions on entities (turn on, off, toggle) - `list_entities`: Get a list of entities with optional domain filtering and search - `search_entities_tool`: Search for entities
