{"server_name": "Augmented-Nature-PDB-MCP-Server", "server_id": "augmented-nature/augmented-nature-pdb-mcp-server", "description": "A Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that provides access to the Protein Data Bank (PDB) - the worldwide repository of information about the 3D structures of proteins, nucleic acids, and complex assemblies.", "readme": "![PDB MCP Server Logo](pdb-mcp-server-logo.png)\n# PDB MCP Server\n\nA Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that provides access to the Protein Data Bank (PDB) - the worldwide repository of information about the 3D structures of proteins, nucleic acids, and complex assemblies.\n\n## Features\n\n### Tools\n\n- **search_structures**: Search PDB database for protein structures by keyword, protein name, or PDB ID\n- **get_structure_info**: Get detailed information for a specific PDB structure\n- **download_structure**: Download structure coordinates in various formats (PDB, mmCIF, mmTF, XML)\n- **search_by_uniprot**: Find PDB structures associated with a UniProt accession\n- **get_structure_quality**: Get structure quality metrics and validation data\n\n### Resources\n\n- **pdb://structure/{pdb_id}**: Complete structure information for a PDB ID\n- **pdb://coordinates/{pdb_id}**: Structure coordinates in PDB format\n- **pdb://mmcif/{pdb_id}**: Structure data in mmCIF format\n- **pdb://validation/{pdb_id}**: Structure validation data and quality metrics\n- **pdb://ligands/{pdb_id}**: Ligand and binding site information\n- **pdb://search/{query}**: Search results for structures matching the query\n\n## Installation\n\n```bash\nnpm install\nnpm run build\n```\n\n## Usage\n\n### With Claude Desktop\n\nAdd to your `claude_desktop_config.json`:\n\n```json\n{\n  \"mcpServers\": {\n    \"pdb-server\": {\n      \"command\": \"node\",\n      \"args\": [\"/path/to/pdb-server/build/index.js\"]\n    }\n  }\n}\n```\n\n### Example Queries\n\n1. **Search for insulin structures**:\n\n   ```\n   Use the search_structures tool to find insulin protein structures\n   ```\n\n2. **Get information about a specific structure**:\n\n   ```\n   Get detailed information about PDB structure 1ABC using get_structure_info\n   ```\n\n3. **Download structure coordinates**:\n\n   ```\n   Download the PDB file for structure 1ABC using download_structure\n   ```\n\n4. **Find structures for a UniProt protein**:\n\n   ```\n   Find PDB structures for UniProt accession P01308 using search_by_uniprot\n   ```\n\n5. **Check structure quality**:\n\n   ```\n   Get validation metrics for PDB structure 1ABC using get_structure_quality\n   ```\n\n6. **Access resources directly**:\n   ```\n   Show me the resource pdb://structure/1abc\n   ```\n\n## API Integration\n\nThis server integrates with:\n\n- **RCSB PDB REST API** (https://data.rcsb.org/): For structure metadata and information\n- **RCSB PDB Search API** (https://search.rcsb.org/): For advanced search capabilities\n- **RCSB PDB File Download** (https://files.rcsb.org/): For structure file downloads\n\n## Structure Data Formats\n\n- **PDB**: Original Protein Data Bank format\n- **mmCIF**: Macromolecular Crystallographic Information File (newer standard)\n- **mmTF**: Macromolecular Transmission Format (binary, compressed)\n- **XML**: Extensible Markup Language format\n\n## Quality Metrics\n\nThe server provides various structure quality indicators:\n\n- Resolution (for X-ray crystallography)\n- R-work and R-free values\n- Ramachandran plot statistics\n- Clash scores\n- Rotamer outliers\n- Model validation scores\n\n## Complementary Servers\n\nThis PDB server works well with:\n\n- **UniProt MCP Server**: For protein sequence and functional information\n- **AlphaFold MCP Server**: For predicted protein structures\n\nTogether, these provide comprehensive access to protein structure and function data.\n\n## Error Handling\n\nThe server includes robust error handling for:\n\n- Invalid PDB IDs\n- Network connectivity issues\n- API rate limiting\n- Missing structure files\n- Malformed requests\n\n## Development\n\n```bash\n# Install dependencies\nnpm install\n\n# Build the server\nnpm run build\n\n# Run in development mode\nnpm run dev\n```\n\n## Attribution\n\nThis project is developed by **Augmented Nature**\n\ud83c\udf10 Website: [augmentednature.ai](https://augmentednature.ai)\n", "tools": [], "tools_count": 0, "homepage": "", "url": "https://github.com/Augmented-Nature/Augmented-Nature-PDB-MCP-Server", "topics": ["bioinformatics", "drug-discovery", "mcp-server", "model-context-protocol", "protein-data-bank", "protein-structure"], "data_sources": ["github"]}'}

{"server_name": "n8n-AI-agent-DVM-MCP-client", "server_id": "r0d8lsh0p/n8n-ai-agent-dvm-mcp-client", "description": "An AI agent built in n8n which can find and use Model Context Protocol (MCP) Server Tools served as Data Vending Machines (DVM) over the Nostr network.", "readme": "# n8n AI Agent for DVM MCP\n\nThese workflows create an AI Agent which is a user of Model Context Protocol (MCP) Server Tools served as Data Vending Machines (DVM) over the Nostr network \u2013\n\nThe Agent, given a prompt which requires a tool \u2013\n\n- Will query the network for available tools it can use,\n- Post requests to those tools over the network,\n- Wait as required for the tool response,\n- Read responses from those tools, and reply to the User.\n\nWhy this is interesting\u00a0\u2013\n\n- For an LLM to use a MCP Tool, the MCP Server typically needs to reside upon the same system as the LLM,\n- There has been no discovery methodology for an LLM to find MCP Severs and Tools which it does not yet have installed,\n- Data Vending Machines allow LLMs to discover and use Tools over the Nostr network,\n- This AI Agent Example demonstrates how an AI that can find and use MCP Tools that it does not have installed, by querying for them as DVMs over the Nostr network.\n\n## Technologies\n\n- **MCP**: The Model Context Protocol is an open protocol that allows AI agents to access data sources and tools. [Read more](https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol),\n- **DVM**: Data Vending Machines listen for and respond to queries over the Nostr network. [Read more](https://github.com/nostr-protocol/nips/blob/master/90.md),\n- **DVMCP**: Data Vending Machine Context Protocol bridges Model Context Protocol servers with Nostr's Data Vending Machine ecosystem. Any MCP server can serve any tool over the network, and any Agent client can access all tools served by any server. See [DVMCP by Gzuuus](https://github.com/gzuuus/dvmcp) and [NostrDVM by BelieveTheHype](https://github.com/believethehype/nostrdvm/tree/main),\n- **n8n**: A low-code platform which is very convenient for creating Langchain Tools Agents. [Read more](https://docs.n8n.io/advanced-ai/).\n\n## Prerequisites\n\n- **n8n**: Install a self-hosted n8n on your system. You can follow the instructions from the [n8n website](https://docs.n8n.io/hosting/),\n- **Nostrobots**: Install [Nostrobots Community Nodes](https://github.com/ocknamo/n8n-nodes-nostrobots/tree/main) by [Ocknamo](https://njump.me/npub1y6aja0kkc4fdvuxgqjcdv4fx0v7xv2epuqnddey2eyaxquznp9vq0tp75l) with instructions from the [n8n website](https://docs.n8n.io/integrations/community-nodes/installation/) which adds Nostr tools to your n8n isntance,\n- **Add workflows from Github to n8n**: Add the five workflows to your n8n. 1. From Github copy the URL for the Raw .json ([example](https://github.com/r0d8lsh0p/n8n-AI-agent-DVM-MCP-client/raw/refs/heads/main/DVMCP_Agent_Example_v1_0.json)), 2. In n8n create a new workflow, then click \"...\" and \"Import from URL\",\n- **Credentials**: Add the credentials for an OpenAI API (or other LLM), SerpAPI, Nostr Private Key (Nsec), Postgresql/Supabase,\n- **Settings**: Workflow variables set in the Set Variables Node: Assistant Name, Assistant Npub, Nostr Relays, User Localisation.\n\nIf you do not have a Nostr private key, you can generate one at [NostrTool.com](https://nostrtool.com/).\n\n### Component Workflows\n\n![Screenshot of DVMCP Agent v1.0 Workflow](Screenshots/DVMCP-Agent-v1-0-Workflow.png)\n\nThe main workflow is DVMCP Agent Example v1.0.\n\nUse this together with the four Tools Subworkflows \u2013\n\n- AI Tool \u2013 Find Nostr DVMCP Servers\n- AI Tool \u2013 Post Nostr DVMCP Server Query\n- AI Tool \u2013 Wait\n- AI Tool \u2013 Read Nostr DVMCP Server Response\n\n### Initial Setup on Install\n\n- The DVMCP Agent must connect to its Tools Subworkflows,\n- On initial install you may need to manually reconnect these. To do so, open the DVMCP Agent Example v1.0 and click each tool's node to select the correct subworkflow from the database,\n- The Credentials must be entered in the DVMCP Agent Example v1.0 workflow, and also in the Post Nostr DVMCP Server Query subworkflow.\n\n## How it Works\n\nThe Agent is prompted to use its tools in sequence to satisfy user needs. An extract from its system prompt is illustrative:\n\n```text\n**Tips for DVM Use**\n\n- If your User requests something where you would need a tool, but do not have a tool, query for DVM MCP server tools on Nostr, and where you find a relevant tool, ask your User if you should use it.\n\n- If your User requests to use a tool, follow these steps in sequence:\n\n1) post your request to the MCP server\n2) wait for 15 seconds\n3) read the response from the MCP server\n4) if there is no response from the MCP server and less than 45 seconds have passed \u2013\nThen go back to step 2 and repeat.\nElse continue.\n5) perform any final steps or required localisation (e.g. query forex and convert USD to local currency)\n```\n\nThe system prompt and workflows can be varied to meet your use case.\n\n## Nostr Links\n\n- Contact me [npub1r0d8u8mnj6769500nypnm28a9hpk9qg8jr0ehe30tygr3wuhcnvs4rfsft](https://njump.me/npub1r0d8u8mnj6769500nypnm28a9hpk9qg8jr0ehe30tygr3wuhcnvs4rfsft),\n\n## License\n\n- This project is licensed under the MIT License.\n", "tools": [], "tools_count": 0, "homepage": "", "url": "https://github.com/r0d8lsh0p/n8n-AI-agent-DVM-MCP-client", "topics": ["ai", "dvm", "mcp", "n8n", "nostr"], "data_sources": ["github"]}'}

MCP Server Data: {"server_name": "agent-browser", "server_id": "co-browser/agent-browser", "description": "One connection for all your MCP servers.", "readme": "# Agent Browser\n\n
\n\n![Version](https://img.shields.io/github/v/release/co-browser/agent-browser?label=version)\n![License](https://img.shields.io/badge/license-MIT-green)\n[![Twitter URL](https://img.shields.io/twitter/url/https/twitter.com/cobrowser.svg?label=Follow%20%40cobrowser)](https://x.com/cobrowser)\n[![Discord](https://img.shields.io/discord/1351569878116470928?logo=discord&logoColor=white&label=discord&color=white)](https://discord.gg/gw9UpFUhyY)\n\n\n**Accelerate development by managing all your MCP server in one place**\n\n[Installation](#installation) \u2022\n[Client Integration](#client-integration) \u2022\n[API Documentation](#api-documentation) \u2022\n[Development](#development)\n\n
\n\n---\n\n## Overview\n\nAgent Browser eliminates the need to configure each MCP server in every client. Connect your clients once to Agent Browser, and it will manage all your Server-Sent Events (SSE) MCP servers for you.\n\n
\n\n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n
Without Agent BrowserWith Agent Browser
\n \n \n \n \n
\n \u2713 Add new server in Cursor
\n \u2713 Add new server in Windsurf Client
\n \u2713 Add new server in Claude Client
\n \u2713 Repeat for each additional client
\n \u2713 Update all clients when server changes\n
\n 		\n \n \n \n \n
\n \u2713 Add new server once in Agent Browser UI
\n \u2713 Update once in Agent Browser when server changes\n
\n
\n
\n\n## Usage\n\nAccess the web UI at [http://localhost:8080/ui/](http://localhost:8080/ui/) to:\n\n- **View** connection status of your MCP servers\n- **Add** new MCP server connections\n- **Remove** existing connections\n- **Monitor** connection health in real-time\n\n---\n\n## Installation\n\n### Package Managers\n\n**macOS and Linux**\n```bash\nbrew tap cob-packages/homebrew-agent-browser\nbrew install cob-packages/agent-browser/agent-browser\nagent-browser\n```\n\n**Windows**\n```bash\nscoop bucket add agent-browser https://github.com/cob-packages/scoop-agent-browser\nscoop install agent-browser\nagent-browser\n```\n\n
\nDirect Download\n
\n\nYou can also download the latest release directly from [GitHub Releases](https://github.com/co-browser/agent-browser/releases):\n\n| Platform | Architecture | Download |\n|----------|--------------|----------|\n| macOS | Intel (x86_64) | `agent-browser-[version]-darwin-amd64.tar.gz` |\n| macOS | Apple Silicon (M1/M2) | `agent-browser-[version]-darwin-arm64.tar.gz` |\n| Linux | x86_64 (64-bit) | `agent-browser-[version]-linux-amd64.tar.gz` |\n| Linux | ARM 64-bit | `agent-browser-[version]-linux-arm64.tar.gz` |\n| Linux | ARM 32-bit | `agent-browser-[version]-linux-arm7.tar.gz` |\n| Windows | 64-bit | `agent-browser-[version]-windows-amd64.zip` |\n| Windows | 32-bit | `agent-browser-[version]-windows-386.zip` |\n| Windows | ARM 64-bit | `agent-browser-[version]-windows-arm64.zip` |\n\n> After downloading, extract the archive and run the executable.\n
\n\n---\n\n## Client Integration\n\n### Cursor\n\nAfter installing and running Agent Browser, Cursor will automatically detect and connect to it. No additional configuration needed.\n\n### Other MCP Clients\n\nAdd Agent Browser as an SSE endpoint in your MCP client configuration:\n\n```json\n{\n \"Agent Browser\": {\n \"url\": \"http://localhost:8087/sse\"\n }\n}\n```\n\nOnce your client is connected to Agent Browser, you can add or remove MCP servers without touching your client configurations.\n\n---\n\n## Project Structure\n\n
\nView Project Structure\n
\n\n```\n/cmd - Application entry points\n/internal\n /app - Core application setup with Fx\n /backend - Database and persistence layer\n /config - Configuration management\n /cursor - Cursor integration\n /events - Event bus for internal communication\n /log - Logging utilities\n /mcp - MCP server implementation\n /web - Web server and UI\n/scripts - Build and utility scripts\n/out - Compiled binaries (git-ignored)\n```\n
\n\n---\n\n## API Documentation\n\nThe Agent Browser exposes a REST API for integration. MCP Server Data: {"server_name": "ethereum-rpc-mpc", "server_id": "phillip-kemper/ethereum-rpc-mpc", "description": "A TypeScript MCP server that leverages the MCP SDK to support all Ethereum JSON-RPC calls, enabling AI models to interact with blockchain data.", "readme": "# Ethereum RPC MPC Server\n\n[![npm version](https://img.shields.io/npm/v/ethereum-rpc-mpc.svg)](https://www.npmjs.com/package/ethereum-rpc-mpc)\n[![npm downloads](https://img.shields.io/npm/dm/ethereum-rpc-mpc.svg)](https://www.npmjs.com/package/ethereum-rpc-mpc)\n\nA TypeScript MCP server that leverages the MCP SDK to support all Ethereum JSON-RPC calls, enabling AI models to interact with blockchain data.\n\n## Overview\n\nThis project provides a Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that allows AI assistants like Cursor or Claude (or any MCP Client implementation) to interact with Ethereum blockchain data through standardized JSON-RPC interfaces. It acts as a bridge between AI models and EVM blockchains, enabling seamless access to on-chain data and functionality.\n\n## Installation\n\n```bash\n# Clone the repository\ngit clone git@github.com:Phillip-Kemper/ethereum-rpc-mpc.git\ncd ethereum-rpc-mpc\n\n# Install dependencies\nyarn install\n\n# Build the project\nyarn build\n\n# Start Inspector with default Ethereum RPC (you can change in the inspector settings on )\nyarn inspector\n```\n\n## Usage\n\n### Using with Cursor\n\nTo use this MPC server with Cursor:\n\n1. In Cursor, go to Settings > Cursor Settings > MCP\n2. Add a new MCP server with the following configuration:\n - Name: Ethereum RPC\n - Type: Command\n - Command: `npx -y ethereum-rpc-mpc https://eth.llamarpc.com Ethereum`\n or\n - Command: `node /path/to/ethereum-rpc-mpc/dist/server/index.js https://eth.llamarpc.com Ethereum`\n\n\n\n### Analytics\n\nYou can also enable analytics using [MCP Analytics Middleware](https://github.com/Phillip-Kemper/mcp-analytics-middleware) to get an overview about number of requests, duration of requests as well as error reporting for all your tools and resources. To enable it, just pass the --analytics flag and additionally a path for the Sqlite File.\n\n- Command: `npx -y ethereum-rpc-mpc https://eth.llamarpc.com Ethereum --analytics --db-path /Users/satoshi/Desktop/analytics.db`\n\n\n### Starting the Server\n\nYou can start the server by providing an Ethereum RPC URL and an optional chain name:\n\n```bash\nyarn start [RPC_URL] [CHAIN_NAME]\n\n# Using npx (without installing)\nnpx -y ethereum-rpc-mpc [RPC_URL] [CHAIN_NAME]\n```\n\nIf no RPC URL is provided, it will default to \"https://eth.llamarpc.com\".\n\nExample:\n\n```bash\n# Connect to Ethereum mainnet\nyarn start https://eth.llamarpc.com Ethereum\n\n# Connect to Zircuit\nyarn start https://mainnet.zircuit.com Zircuit\n```\n\n## Examples\n\nHere are some examples of how to use the Ethereum RPC MPC server with Claude:\n\n### Getting the Current Block Number\n\n```\nWhat's the current block number?\n```\n\n### Checking an Address Balance\n\n```\nWhat's the ETH balance of 0x742d35Cc6634C0532925a3b844Bc454e4438f44e?\n```\n\n### Getting Contract Information\n\n```\nIs 0x6B175474E89094C44Da98b954EedeAC495271d0F a smart contract? If yes, what kind of contract is it?\n```\n\n### Retrieving Transaction Details\n\n```\nCan you show me the details of transaction 0x5c504ed432cb51138bcf09aa5e8a410dd4a1e204ef84bfed1be16dfba1b22060?\n```\n\n## Zircuit SLS (Sequencer Level Security) Methods\n\nThis server includes special support for Zircuit-specific RPC methods. These methods are not enabled by default but are automatically activated when connecting to a Zircuit endpoint (Chain ID: 48900).\n\nThe supported Zircuit methods include:\n\n- `zirc_isQuarantined`: Check if a specific transaction is quarantined\n- `zirc_getQuarantined`: Query all quarantined transactions with optional address filtering\n\nThese methods are particularly useful for monitoring transaction quarantine status.\n\n## Future Steps\n\n### Next to RPC, also support indexed API access\n\nWe plan to extend the functionality beyond basic RPC calls to include support for indexed blockchain data APIs. This will enable more efficient querying of historical data and complex on-chain analytics.\n\n### Multi Chain, Multi RPC Support\n\nFuture versions will support connecting to multiple chains and RPC endpoints simultaneously, allowing AI models to access data across different blockchains in a single session.\n\n### Client Implementation\n\nA future enhancement will be to develop a client-side implementation that makes it easier to interact with this MCP server from various applications.\n\n### Server Analytics\n\nWe plan to add analytics capabilities to track usage patterns, popular RPC methods, and performance metrics. This will help optimize the server and provide insights into how AI models are interacting with blockchain data.\n\n## License\n\nMIT \n", "tools": [{"name": "zirc_isQuarantined", "description": "Check if a specific transaction is quarantined", "inputSchema": {"type": "object", "properties": {"input": {"type": "string", "description": "Input parameter for zirc_isQuarantined"}}, "required": ["input"]}, "source": "readme", "access_level": "read"}, {"name": "zirc_getQuarantined", "description": "Query all quarantined transactions with optional address filtering", "inputSchema": {"type": "object", "properties": {"query": {"type": "string", "description": "Search query or term"}}, "required": ["query"]}, "source": "readme", "access_level": "write"}], "tools_count": 2, "homepage": "", "url": "https://github.com/Phillip-Kemper/ethereum-rpc-mpc", "topics": ["ai", "claude", "cursor", "ethereum", "evm", "json-rpc", "mcp"], "data_sources": ["github"]}'}

  "server_id": "phillip-kemper/ethereum-rpc-mcp",

MCP Server Data: {"server_name": "agent-browser", "server_id": "faintaccomp/agent-browser", "description": "One connection for all your MCP servers. agent, browser, cursor, mcp, sse", "readme": "# Agent Browser\n\n
\n\n![Version](https://img.shields.io/github/v/release/co-browser/agent-browser?label=version)\n![License](https://img.shields.io/badge/license-MIT-green)\n[![Twitter URL](https://img.shields.io/twitter/url/https/twitter.com/cobrowser.svg?label=Follow%20%40cobrowser)](https://x.com/cobrowser)\n[![Discord](https://img.shields.io/discord/1351569878116470928?logo=discord&logoColor=white&label=discord&color=white)](https://discord.gg/gw9UpFUhyY)\n\n\n**Accelerate development by managing all your MCP server in one place**\n\n[Installation](#installation) \u2022\n[Client Integration](#client-integration) \u2022\n[API Documentation](#api-documentation) \u2022\n[Development](#development)\n\n
\n\n---\n\n## Overview\n\nAgent Browser eliminates the need to configure each MCP server in every client. Connect your clients once to Agent Browser, and it will manage all your Server-Sent Events (SSE) MCP servers for you.\n\n
\n\n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n
Without Agent BrowserWith Agent Browser
\n \n \n \n \n
\n \u2713 Add new server in Cursor
\n \u2713 Add new server in Windsurf Client
\n \u2713 Add new server in Claude Client
\n \u2713 Repeat for each additional client
\n \u2713 Update all clients when server changes\n
\n 		\n \n \n \n \n
\n \u2713 Add new server once in Agent Browser UI
\n \u2713 Update once in Agent Browser when server changes\n
\n
\n
\n\n## Usage\n\nAccess the web UI at [http://localhost:8080/ui/](http://localhost:8080/ui/) to:\n\n- **View** connection status of your MCP servers\n- **Add** new MCP server connections\n- **Remove** existing connections\n- **Monitor** connection health in real-time\n\n---\n\n## Installation\n\n### Package Managers\n\n**macOS and Linux**\n```bash\nbrew tap cob-packages/homebrew-agent-browser\nbrew install cob-packages/agent-browser/agent-browser\nagent-browser\n```\n\n**Windows**\n```bash\nscoop bucket add agent-browser https://github.com/cob-packages/scoop-agent-browser\nscoop install agent-browser\nagent-browser\n```\n\n
\nDirect Download\n
\n\nYou can also download the latest release directly from [GitHub Releases](https://github.com/faintaccomp/agent-browser/releases):\n\n| Platform | Architecture | Download |\n|----------|--------------|----------|\n| macOS | Intel (x86_64) | `agent-browser-[version]-darwin-amd64.tar.gz` |\n| macOS | Apple Silicon (M1/M2) | `agent-browser-[version]-darwin-arm64.tar.gz` |\n| Linux | x86_64 (64-bit) | `agent-browser-[version]-linux-amd64.tar.gz` |\n| Linux | ARM 64-bit | `agent-browser-[version]-linux-arm64.tar.gz` |\n| Linux | ARM 32-bit | `agent-browser-[version]-linux-arm7.tar.gz` |\n| Windows | 64-bit | `agent-browser-[version]-windows-amd64.zip` |\n| Windows | 32-bit | `agent-browser-[version]-windows-386.zip` |\n| Windows | ARM 64-bit | `agent-browser-[version]-windows-arm64.zip` |\n\n> After downloading, extract the archive and run the executable.\n
\n\n---\n\n## Client Integration\n\n### Cursor\n\nAfter installing and running Agent Browser, Cursor will automatically detect and connect to it. No additional configuration needed.\n\n### Other MCP Clients\n\nAdd Agent Browser as an SSE endpoint in your MCP client configuration:\n\n```json\n{\n \"Agent Browser\": {\n \"url\": \"http://localhost:8087/sse\"\n }\n}\n```\n\nOnce your client is connected to Agent Browser, you can add or remove MCP servers without touching your client configurations.\n\n---\n\n## Project Structure\n\n
\nView Project Structure\n
\n\n```\n/cmd - Application entry points\n/internal\n /app - Core application setup with Fx\n /backend - Database and persistence layer\n /config - Configuration management\n /cursor - Cursor integration\n /events - Event bus for internal communication\n /log - Logging utilities\n /mcp - MCP server implementation\n /web - Web server and UI\n/scripts - Build and utility scripts\n/out - Compiled binaries (git-ignored)\n```\n
\n\n---\n\n## API Documentation\n\nThe Agent Browser exposes a REST API for integration. For details on accessing the API documentation, using Swagger UI, or integrating with tools like Postman, see [API.md](API.md).\n\n---\n\n## Future Direction\n\n### Protocol Support Implementation\n\nWe plan to expand Agent Browser to support additional protocols alongside MCP.\n\n#### Future Tasks\n\n- [ ] Add A2A protocol support\n- [ ] Add ACP protocol support\n- [ ] Implement protocol auto-detection\n\n```\n Client\n \u2502\n \u25bc\n Agent Browser\n / \u2502 \\\n / \u2502 \\\n \u25bc \u25bc \u25bc\n MCP A2A ACP ...\n```\n\n### Relevant Files\n\n- `/internal/mcp` - MCP protocol implementation\n- `/internal/web` - Web server and UI components\n- `/intern\n[...truncated for length...]", "tools": [], "tools_count": 0, "homepage": "https://github.com/faintaccomp/agent-browser", "url": "https://github.com/faintaccomp/agent-browser", "topics": [], "data_sources": ["github"]}'}

Agent is exposed on various agent transport protocols (AGNTCY Slim, Google A2A, MCP Server)", "readme": "# \ud83d\ude80 ArgoCD AI Agent\n\n[![Python](https://img.shields.io/badge/python-3.13%2B-blue?logo=python)](https://www.python.org/)\n[![Poetry](https://img.shields.io/badge/poetry-2.1.1%2B-blueviolet?logo=python)](https://python-poetry.org/)\n[![License](https://img.shields.io/badge/license-Apache%202.0-green)](LICENSE)\n\n[![Conventional Commits](https://github.com/cnoe-io/openapi-mcp-codegen/actions/workflows/conventional_commits.yml/badge.svg)](https://github.com/cnoe-io/openapi-mcp-codegen/actions/workflows/conventional_commits.yml)\n[![Ruff Linter](https://github.com/cnoe-io/openapi-mcp-codegen/actions/workflows/ruff.yml/badge.svg)](https://github.com/cnoe-io/openapi-mcp-codegen/actions/workflows/ruff.yml)\n[![Unit Tests](https://github.com/cnoe-io/agent-argocd/actions/workflows/unit-tests.yml/badge.svg)](https://github.com/cnoe-io/agent-argocd/actions/workflows/unit-tests.yml)\n\n[![A2A Docker Build and Push](https://github.com/cnoe-io/agent-argocd/actions/workflows/a2a-docker-build.yml/badge.svg)](https://github.com/cnoe-io/agent-argocd/actions/workflows/a2a-docker-build.yml)\n---\n\n---\n\n- \ud83e\udd16 **ArgoCD Agent** is an LLM-powered agent built using the [LangGraph ReAct Agent](https://langchain-ai.github.io/langgraph/agents/agents/) workflow and ArgoCD [MCP Server](https://modelcontextprotocol.io/introduction).\n- \ud83c\udf10 **Protocol Support:** Compatible with [A2A](https://github.com/google/A2A) protocol for integration with external user clients.\n- \ud83d\udee1\ufe0f **Secure by Design:** Enforces ArgoCD API token-based RBAC and supports secondary external authentication for strong access control.\n- \ud83c\udfed **MCP Server:** The MCP server is generated by our first-party [openapi-mcp-codegen](https://github.com/cnoe-io/openapi-mcp-codegen/tree/main) utility, ensuring version/API compatibility and software supply chain integrity.\n- \ud83d\udd0c **MCP Tools:** Uses [langchain-mcp-adapters](https://github.com/langchain-ai/langchain-mcp-adapters) to glue the tools from ArgoCD MCP server to LangGraph ReAct Agent Graph.\n\n---\n\n## \ud83d\udea6 Getting Started\n\n### 1\ufe0f\u20e3 Environment Setup\n\n- Copy and configure your `.env` based on your LLM provider.\n- Use [.env.example](.env.example) and refer to the [cnoe-agent-utils guide](https://github.com/cnoe-io/cnoe-agent-utils#-usage).\n\n### 2\ufe0f\u20e3 Start the Agent (A2A Mode)\n\n  > **Note:** `a2a-stable` is the latest stable version of the agent. For production use cases, consider using a pinned version.\n\n  ```bash\n  docker run -p 0.0.0.0:8000:8000 -it \\\n    -v $(pwd)/.env:/app/.env \\\n    ghcr.io/cnoe-io/agent-argocd:a2a-stable\n  ```\n\n> \ud83d\udca1 Don\u2019t have ArgoCD running? See [Local Dev Setup](#local-development-setup).\n\n### 3\ufe0f\u20e3 Run the A2A Client\n\nPick one of the following methods:\n\n- **Docker:**\n\n  ```bash\n  docker run -it --network=host ghcr.io/cnoe-io/agent-chat-cli:stable\n  ```\n\n- **Python CLI:**\n\n  ```bash\n  uvx https://github.com/cnoe-io/agent-chat-cli.git a2a\n  ```\n\n---\n\n## \ud83c\udfd7\ufe0f Architecture\n\n### System Diagram\n\n```mermaid\nflowchart TD\n  subgraph Client Layer\n    A[User Client A2A]\n  end\n  subgraph Agent Transport Layer\n    B[Google A2A]\n  end\n  subgraph Agent Graph Layer\n    C[LangGraph ReAct Agent]\n  end\n  subgraph Tools Layer\n    D[LangChain MCP Adapter]\n    E[ArgoCD MCP Server]\n    F[ArgoCD API Server]\n  end\n\n  A --> B --> C --> D --> E --> F\n  F --> E --> D --> C --> B --> A\n```\n\n### Sequence Diagram\n\n```mermaid\nsequenceDiagram\n  participant User\n  participant A2A\n  participant Agent as LangGraph ReAct Agent\n  participant LLM\n  participant MCP as ArgoCD MCP Server\n  participant APIServer as ArgoCD API Server\n\n  note over Agent,MCP: \ud83d\udee0\ufe0f Agent Setup Phase\n  rect rgb(245, 245, 220)\n    Agent->>MCP: Get Tools\n    Agent->>LLM: Bind Tools\n  end\n\n  rect rgb(220, 232, 243)\n    note over User,A2A: \ud83e\uddd1\u200d\ud83d\udcbb User Input Phase\n    User->>A2A: Send request\n    A2A->>Agent: Forward to LangGraph Agent\n\n    note over Agent,LLM: \ud83e\udde0 Agent Reasoning & Tool Selection\n    Agent->>LLM: [Reason] User Input\n    LLM-->>Agent: [Act] Excecute MCP Tool\n\n    note over MCP,APIServer: \ud83d\udee0\ufe0f API Invocation Phase\n    Agent->>MCP: Invoke tool\n    MCP->>APIServer: Call API\n    APIServer-->>MCP: Return data\n    MCP-->>Agent: Return data\n\n    note over Agent,LLM: \ud83e\udde0 Agent Reasoning & Output Structuring\n    Agent->>LLM: Input API result data for further ReAct loop\n    LLM-->>Agent: Return Structured Output\n\n    note over User,A2A: \ud83d\udce4 User Output Phase\n    Agent-->>A2A: Respond with Structured Output\n    A2A-->>User: Respond to user (Non-stream or streaming)\n  end\n```\n\n---\n\n## \u2699\ufe0f Local Development Setup\n\nUse this setup to test the agent against a local ArgoCD instance.\n\n### \u25b6\ufe0f Start ArgoCD with kind cluster\n\n> **Note:** KinD (Kubernetes in Docker) is a tool for running local Kubernetes clusters using Docker.\nFor detailed setup instructions, refer to the [KinD documentation](https://kind.sigs.k8s.io/). Below is a quickstart to launch a local cluster and install ArgoCD:\n\n```bash\nkind create cluster --name cnoe-argocd-agent\nkubectl create namespace argocd\nkubectl apply -n argocd -f https://raw.githubuser\n[...truncated for length...]", "tools": [{"name": "uv", "description": "](https://github.com/astral-sh/uv) (a fast Python runner) on the port specified by `A2A_PORT` in your `.env` (defaults to `8000` if not set).", "inputSchema": {"type": "object", "properties": {"input": {"type": "string", "description": "Input parameter for uv"}}, "required": ["input"]}, "source": "readme", "access_level": "execute"}, {"name": "A2A_PORT", "description": "and `A2A_AGENT_IMAGE` from `.env` (uses defaults if not set).", "inputSchema": {"type": "object", "properties": {"input": {"type": "string", "description": "Input parameter for A2A_PORT"}}, "required": ["input"]}, "source": "readme", "access_level": "write"}], "tools_count": 2, "homepage": "https://hub.agntcy.org/explore/e632d15e-6587-4368-8eeb-7bf3ccd09758", "url": "https://github.com/cnoe-io/agent-argocd", "topics": ["agent", "agentic-ai", "argocd", "platform-engineering"], "data_sources": ["github"]}'}

{"server_name": "MessariMCP", "server_id": "n-45div/messarimcp", "description": "A MCP server powered by Messari Chat Agent API and an LLM based kit for mindshare and set insights over the time and plots to be the next crime-fighting AI toolkit.", "readme": "# Messari Influencer Mindshare and Asset Analysis\r\n\r\nThis repository contains a Python script for analyzing mindshare data of cryptocurrency assets using the Messari API. The script fetches mindshare data, performs anomaly detection, visualizes trends, and provides insights into significant spikes in attention for a given asset. The analysis is tailored for use in Google Colab, with plotting and readable insights displayed directly in the notebook.\r\n\r\n---\r\n\r\n## Overview\r\n\r\nThe Python script provides several functions to facilitate mindshare analysis for both cryptocurrency assets and Key Opinion Leaders (KOLs) on social media platforms like Twitter. Below is a description of each function:\r\n\r\n---\r\n\r\n#### `call_mistral`\r\n\r\n- **Purpose**: Interacts with the Mistral API to perform **sentiment analysis** on text data (e.g., summaries of trending topics).\r\n- **Returns**: A JSON object with the sentiment (`positive`, `negative`, or `neutral`) and an insight into how the topic may influence crypto market attention.\r\n- **Features**:\r\n  - Includes **retry logic** for handling rate limits.\r\n  - Caches responses to **avoid redundant API calls**.\r\n- **Used In**: KOL mindshare analysis to explain **anomalies** by sentiment-analyzing related trending topics.\r\n\r\n---\r\n\r\n#### `get_trending_details`\r\n\r\n- **Purpose**: Fetches **trending topics** from the Messari API within a given date range and topic classes (e.g., `\"Macro Commentary, Project Announcements, Legal and Regulatory\"`).\r\n- **Returns**: A dictionary of trending topics for the specified criteria.\r\n- **Used For**: Providing context for **mindshare anomalies** in the KOL analysis by correlating spikes with relevant market news and events.\r\n\r\n---\r\n\r\n#### `analyze_mindshare_data`\r\n\r\n- **Purpose**: Retrieves **mindshare data** for a specific Twitter handle (e.g., `@AltcoinGordon`) from the Messari API.\r\n- **Processes**:\r\n  - Detects **anomalies** in mindshare scores using **z-scores** (default threshold: `2.0`).\r\n  - **Plots** mindshare scores over time with anomalies **highlighted in red**.\r\n  - Provides insights on:\r\n    - **Trends** (upward/downward/stable)\r\n    - **Score and rank ranges**\r\n    - **List of anomalies**\r\n  - Uses `call_mistral` + `get_trending_details` to add **sentiment + market explanation** to detected anomalies.\r\n- **Display**: Results are shown **directly in Google Colab**.\r\n- **Best For**: KOL mindshare tracking and insight generation.\r\n\r\n---\r\n\r\n#### `analyze_asset_mindshare`\r\n\r\n- **Purpose**: Retrieves **mindshare data** for a specific cryptocurrency asset (e.g., `official-trump` for $TRUMP, `mantra-dao` for $OM).\r\n- **Processes**:\r\n  - Detects **anomalies** in asset mindshare scores using **z-scores** (default threshold: `2.0`).\r\n  - **Plots** scores over time with anomalies **highlighted in orange**.\r\n  - Provides concise insights about:\r\n    - **Mindshare trends**\r\n    - **Score and rank ranges**\r\n    - **Anomaly dates and scores**\r\n- **Display**: Designed to work **directly in Google Colab** for interactive visual exploration.\r\n- **Best For**: Analyzing market attention shifts for individual crypto assets.\r\n\r\n---\r\n\r\n## \ud83d\ude80 Running the MCP Server\r\n\r\nThe MCP Server provides a backend for broader mindshare comparison functionality.\r\n\r\n- Navigate to the server code: `server.py`\r\n- Ensure the Messari API key is configured correctly.\r\n\r\n---\r\n\r\n## API List\r\n\r\nThe following APIs are used in this project:\r\n\r\n- **Copilot Agent API**\r\n- **Current Topics API**\r\n- **X-Users Mindshare Over Time API**\r\n- **Mindshare of Asset Over Time API**\r\n- **Asset Details API**\r\n\r\n---\r\n\r\n## \ud83d\udd11 Key Features\r\n\r\n- **Mindshare Data Fetching**: Uses the Messari API to retrieve daily mindshare data for assets.\r\n- **Anomaly Detection**: Identifies significant spikes in mindshare scores using a z-score threshold (default: 2.0).\r\n- **Visualization**: Plots mindshare scores over time with anomalies highlighted in Google Colab.\r\n- **Insights**: Provides readable insights about trends, score ranges, rank ranges, and anomalies.\r\n- **Extensible**: Designed to work alongside KOL mindshare analysis (e.g., for Twitter handles) with potential for combined analysis.\r\n\r\n---\r\n\r\n## \ud83d\udcc2 Code Links in the repository\r\n\r\n- **Colab Notebook**: [LLM_Mindshare_asset_analysis.ipynb](https://github.com/N-45div/MessariMCP/blob/main/colab/LLM_Mindshare_asset_analysis.ipynb)\r\n- **MCP Server Code**: [server.py](https://github.com/N-45div/MessariMCP/blob/main/server.py)\r\n\r\n---\r\n\r\n## \ud83d\udcc4 License\r\n\r\nThis project is licensed under the MIT License. {"server_name": "scmcp", "server_id": "scmcphub/scmcp", "description": "An MCP server for scRNA-Seq analysis with natural language!", "readme": "# SCMCP\n\nAn MCP server for scRNA-Seq analysis  with natural language!\n\n## \ud83e\udea9 What can it do?\n\n- IO module like read and write scRNA-Seq data with natural language\n- Preprocessing module,like filtering, quality control, normalization, scaling, highly-variable genes, PCA, Neighbors,...\n- Tool module, like clustering, differential expression etc.\n- Plotting module, like violin, heatmap, dotplot\n- cell-cell communication analysis\n- Pseudotime analysis\n- enrichment analysis\n\n## \u2753 Who is this for?\n\n- Anyone who wants to do scRNA-Seq analysis natural language!\n- Agent developers who want to call scanpy's functions for their applications\n\n## \ud83c\udf10 Where to use it?\n\nYou can use scmcp in most AI clients, plugins, or agent frameworks that support the MCP:\n\n- AI clients, like Cherry Studio\n- Plugins, like Cline\n- Agent frameworks, like Agno \n\n\n## \ud83d\udcda Documentation\n\nscmcphub's complete documentation is available at https://docs.scmcphub.org\n\n\n## \ud83c\udfac Demo\n\nA demo showing scRNA-Seq cell cluster analysis in a AI client Cherry Studio using natural language based on scmcp\n\nhttps://github.com/user-attachments/assets/93a8fcd8-aa38-4875-a147-a5eeff22a559\n\n## \ud83c\udfce\ufe0f Quickstart\n\n### Install\n\nInstall from PyPI\n```\npip install scmcp\n```\nyou can test it by running\n```\nscmcp run\n```\n\n#### run scnapy-mcp locally\nRefer to the following configuration in your MCP client:\n\ncheck path\n```\n$ which scmcp \n/home/test/bin/scmcp\n```\n\n> it has many tools , so it couldn't work if you model context is not large...More time, I recommend it is backend mcp server for scanpy-mcp, liana-mcp,cellrank-mcp, so they can use shared Anndata object.\n\n```\n\"mcpServers\": {\n  \"scmcp\": {\n    \"command\": \"/home/test/bin/scmcp\",\n    \"args\": [\n      \"run\"\n    ]\n  }\n}\n```\n\n#### run scmcp remotely\nRefer to the following configuration in your MCP client:\n\nrun it in your server\n```\nscmcp run --transport shttp --port 8000\n```\n\nThen configure your MCP client in local AI client, like this:\n```\n\n\"mcpServers\": {\n  \"scmcp\": {\n    \"url\": \"http://localhost:8000/mcp\"\n  }\n}\n```\n\n## Intelligent Tool Selection (Experimental)\n\nSCMCP implements an intelligent tool selection system to optimize performance and reduce token usage. \n\n### How it Works\n\nThe intelligent tool selection system operates in two phases:\n1. **Search_tool**: First identifies the most relevant tools for your analysis\n2. **run_tool**: Then runs only the selected tools, reducing token consumption\n\n\n### Usage\n\n1. Ensure you have the latest version of scmcp-shared installed:\n```bash\npip install --upgrade scmcp-shared\n```\n\n2. Start the server with intelligent tool selection enabled:\n```bash\nscmcp run --transport shttp --port 8000 --tool-mode auto\n```\n\n3. Configure your MCP client to connect to the server:\n```json\n{\n  \"mcpServers\": {\n    \"scmcp\": {\n      \"url\": \"http://localhost:8000/mcp\"\n    }\n  }\n}\n```\n\n\n## \ud83e\udd1d Contributing\n\nIf you have any questions, welcome to submit an issue, or contact me(hsh-me@outlook.com). Contributions to the code are also welcome!\n\n## Citing\nIf you use scmcp in for your research, please consider citing  following works: \n> Wolf, F., Angerer, P. & Theis, F. SCANPY: large-scale single-cell gene expression data analysis. Genome Biol 19, 15 (2018). https://doi.org/10.1186/s13059-017-1382-0\n\n> Dimitrov D., Sch\u00e4fer P.S.L, Farr E., Rodriguez Mier P., Lobentanzer S., Badia-i-Mompel P., Dugourd A., Tanevski J., Ramirez Flores R.O. and Saez-Rodriguez J. LIANA+ provides an all-in-one framework for cell\u2013cell communication inference. Nat Cell Biol (2024). https://doi.org/10.1038/s41556-024-01469-w\n\n> Badia-i-Mompel P., V\u00e9lez Santiago J., Braunger J., Geiss C., Dimitrov D., M\u00fcller-Dott S., Taus P., Dugourd A., Holland C.H., Ramirez Flores R.O. and Saez-Rodriguez J. 2022. decoupleR: ensemble of computational methods to infer biological activities from omics data. Bioinformatics Advances. https://doi.org/10.1093/bioadv/vbac016\n\n> Weiler, P., Lange, M., Klein, M. et al. CellRank 2: unified fate mapping in multiview single-cell data. Nat Methods 21, 1196\u20131205 (2024). https://doi.org/10.1038/s41592-024-02303-9\n\n", "tools": [], "tools_count": 0, "homepage": "https://docs.scmcphub.org/", "url": "https://github.com/scmcphub/scmcp", "topics": ["agent", "ai", "llm", "mcp", "scrna-seq"], "data_sources": ["github"]}'}

{"server_name": "neo-n3-mcp", "server_id": "r3e-network/neo-n3-mcp", "description": "An MCP server for interacting with the Neo N3 blockchain.", "readme": "# Neo N3 MCP Server\n\n**MCP Server for Neo N3 Blockchain Integration** | Version 1.5.0\n\n[![MCP SDK](https://img.shields.io/badge/MCP%20SDK-1.9.0-blue)](https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/typescript-sdk)\n[![Neo N3](https://img.shields.io/badge/Neo%20N3-Compatible-green)](https://neo.org/)\n[![NPM](https://img.shields.io/badge/NPM-@r3e/neo--n3--mcp-red)](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@r3e/neo-n3-mcp)\n\nA production-ready MCP server providing Neo N3 blockchain integration with 34 tools and 9 resources for wallet management, asset transfers, contract interactions, and blockchain queries.\n\n## \ud83d\ude80 Quick Start\n\n### Install from NPM\n```bash\n# Install globally\nnpm install -g @r3e/neo-n3-mcp\n\n# Or install locally\nnpm install @r3e/neo-n3-mcp\n```\n\n### Basic Usage\n```bash\n# Run with default configuration\nnpx @r3e/neo-n3-mcp\n\n# Or if installed globally\nneo-n3-mcp\n```\n\n## \u2699\ufe0f Configuration\n\n### 1. Command Line Configuration\n\n```bash\n# Specify network\nneo-n3-mcp --network testnet\n\n# Custom RPC endpoints\nneo-n3-mcp --mainnet-rpc https://mainnet1.neo.coz.io:443 --testnet-rpc https://testnet1.neo.coz.io:443\n\n# Enable logging\nneo-n3-mcp --log-level info --log-file ./neo-mcp.log\n\n# Complete example\nneo-n3-mcp \\\n  --network mainnet \\\n  --mainnet-rpc https://mainnet1.neo.coz.io:443 \\\n  --testnet-rpc https://testnet1.neo.coz.io:443 \\\n  --log-level debug \\\n  --log-file ./logs/neo-mcp.log\n```\n\n### 2. JSON Configuration\n\nCreate a `neo-mcp-config.json` file:\n\n```json\n{\n  \"network\": \"mainnet\",\n  \"rpc\": {\n    \"mainnet\": \"https://mainnet1.neo.coz.io:443\",\n    \"testnet\": \"https://testnet1.neo.coz.io:443\"\n  },\n  \"logging\": {\n    \"level\": \"info\",\n    \"file\": \"./logs/neo-mcp.log\",\n    \"console\": true\n  },\n  \"server\": {\n    \"name\": \"neo-n3-mcp-server\",\n    \"version\": \"1.5.0\"\n  },\n  \"wallets\": {\n    \"directory\": \"./wallets\"\n  }\n}\n```\n\nRun with config file:\n```bash\nneo-n3-mcp --config ./neo-mcp-config.json\n```\n\n### 3. Docker Configuration\n\n#### Using Docker Hub Image\n```bash\n# Basic run\ndocker run -p 3000:3000 r3e/neo-n3-mcp:1.5.0\n\n# With environment variables\ndocker run -p 3000:3000 \\\n  -e NEO_NETWORK=mainnet \\\n  -e NEO_MAINNET_RPC=https://mainnet1.neo.coz.io:443 \\\n  -e NEO_TESTNET_RPC=https://testnet1.neo.coz.io:443 \\\n  -e LOG_LEVEL=info \\\n  r3e/neo-n3-mcp:1.5.0\n\n# With volume for persistent data\ndocker run -p 3000:3000 \\\n  -v $(pwd)/wallets:/app/wallets \\\n  -v $(pwd)/logs:/app/logs \\\n  -e NEO_NETWORK=testnet \\\n  r3e/neo-n3-mcp:1.5.0\n```\n\n#### Docker Compose\nCreate a `docker-compose.yml`:\n\n```yaml\nversion: '3.8'\nservices:\n  neo-mcp:\n    image: r3e/neo-n3-mcp:1.5.0\n    ports:\n      - \"3000:3000\"\n    environment:\n      - NEO_NETWORK=mainnet\n      - NEO_MAINNET_RPC=https://mainnet1.neo.coz.io:443\n      - NEO_TESTNET_RPC=https://testnet1.neo.coz.io:443\n      - LOG_LEVEL=info\n      - LOG_FILE=/app/logs/neo-mcp.log\n    volumes:\n      - ./wallets:/app/wallets\n      - ./logs:/app/logs\n      - ./config:/app/config\n    restart: unless-stopped\n```\n\nRun with:\n```bash\ndocker-compose up -d\n```\n\n#### Custom Dockerfile\n```dockerfile\nFROM node:18-alpine\n\nWORKDIR /app\nCOPY package*.json ./\nRUN npm ci --only=production\n\nCOPY dist/ ./dist/\nCOPY config/ ./config/\n\n# Create necessary directories\nRUN mkdir -p wallets logs\n\nEXPOSE 3000\n\nCMD [\"node\", \"dist/index.js\"]\n```\n\n## \ud83d\udd27 Configuration Options\n\n### Environment Variables\n| Variable | Description | Default |\n|----------|-------------|---------|\n| `NEO_NETWORK` | Default network (mainnet/testnet) | `testnet` |\n| `NEO_MAINNET_RPC` | Mainnet RPC endpoint | `https://mainnet1.neo.coz.io:443` |\n| `NEO_TESTNET_RPC` | Testnet RPC endpoint | `https://testnet1.neo.coz.io:443` |\n| `LOG_LEVEL` | Logging level (debug/info/warn/error) | `info` |\n| `LOG_FILE` | Log file path | `./logs/neo-mcp.log` |\n| `WALLET_DIR` | Wallet storage directory | `./wallets` |\n\n### Command Line Options\n| Option | Description |\n|--------|-------------|\n| `--network` | Set default network |\n| `--mainnet-rpc` | Mainnet RPC URL |\n| `--testnet-rpc` | Testnet RPC URL |\n| `--log-level` | Set logging level |\n| `--log-file` | Set log file path |\n| `--config` | Load configuration from JSON file |\n| `--help` | Show help information |\n\n## \ud83d\udee0\ufe0f MCP Client Integration\n\n### Claude Desktop\nAdd to your Claude Desktop config (`~/.cursor/mcp.json` or similar):\n\n```json\n{\n  \"mcpServers\": {\n  \"env\": {\n        \"NEO_NETWORK\": \"testnet\",\n        \"LOG_LEVEL\": \"info\"\n      }\n    }\n  }\n}\n```\n\nFor mainnet configuration:\n```json\n{\n  \"mcpServers\": {\n    \"neo-n3\": {\n {"server_name": "mcp-web3-stats", "server_id": "crazyrabbitltc/mcp-web3-stats", "description": "A high-performance MCP server providing blockchain wallet analysis and token data via the Dune API for AI assistants and MCP clients.", "readme": "\n![ChatGPT Image May 23, 2025, 10_25_41 AM](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/fe40d718-d1d8-44e9-a8a4-a5ad39153218)\n\n# Dune API MCP Server\n\nThis project implements a Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that exposes functionality from the Dune API, allowing LLM agents and other MCP clients to analyze blockchain information.\n\n## Features\n\nThe server provides the following MCP tools and resources based on the Dune API:\n\n**EVM Tools:**\n*   `get_evm_balances`: Fetches EVM token balances for a wallet.\n*   `get_evm_activity`: Fetches EVM account activity.\n*   `get_evm_collectibles`: Fetches EVM NFT collectibles.\n*   `get_evm_transactions`: Retrieves granular EVM transaction details.\n*   `get_evm_token_info`: Fetches metadata and price for EVM tokens.\n*   `get_evm_token_holders`: Discovers EVM token holder distributions.\n\n**SVM Tools:**\n*   `get_svm_balances`: Fetches SVM token balances.\n*   `get_svm_transactions`: Fetches SVM transactions (Solana only).\n\n**Resources:**\n*   `dune://evm/supported-chains`: Provides a list of EVM chains supported by the Dune API.\n\n**Prompts:**\n*   `/evm_wallet_overview {walletAddress}`: Get a quick overview of an EVM wallet.\n*   `/analyze_erc20_token {chainId} {tokenAddress}`: Analyze a specific ERC20 token.\n*   `/svm_address_check {walletAddress}`: Check basic information for an SVM address.\n\n## Quick Start\n\n```bash\n# Clone the repository\ngit clone https://github.com/crazyrabbitLTC/mcp-web3-stats.git\ncd mcp-web3-stats\n\n# Install dependencies\nbun install\n\n# Create .env file with your Dune API key\necho \"DUNE_API_KEY=your_actual_dune_api_key_here\" > .env\n\n# Start the server\nbun start\n\n# In a separate terminal, run the MCP Inspector to test the tools\nnpx @modelcontextprotocol/inspector bun run index.ts\n```\n\n## Installation from npm\n\nYou can install the Web3 Stats Server globally via npm:\n\n```bash\n# Install globally\nnpm install -g mcp-web3-stats\n\n# Set your Dune API key as an environment variable\nexport DUNE_API_KEY=your_actual_dune_api_key_here\n\n# Run the server\nmcp-web3-stats\n\n# In a separate terminal, test with the MCP Inspector\nnpx @modelcontextprotocol/inspector mcp-web3-stats\n```\n\nAlternatively, you can run it directly with npx:\n\n```bash\n# Set your Dune API key as an environment variable\nexport DUNE_API_KEY=your_actual_dune_api_key_here\n\n# Run the server with npx\nnpx mcp-web3-stats\n\n# In a separate terminal, test with the MCP Inspector\nnpx @modelcontextprotocol/inspector npx mcp-web3-stats\n```\n\n## What You Can Do With This\n\nThis MCP server allows you and your AI assistant to analyze blockchain data and wallet information directly. Here are some example use cases:\n\n### 1. Check Wallet Balances\n\nYou can quickly view all tokens (including ERC20s and NFTs) held by any wallet address:\n\n```\nAssistant: Let me check the balances in this wallet for you.\n\n[Uses get_evm_balances with walletAddress=0xYourWalletAddress]\n\nThis wallet contains:\n- 1.25 ETH (~$3,800)\n- 500 USDC ($500)\n- Several NFTs including a CryptoPunk and two Bored Apes\n```\n\n### 2. Analyze Token Information and Holders\n\nYou can research specific tokens and their distribution:\n\n```\nAssistant: Let me analyze this token for you.\n\n[Uses get_evm_token_info with chainId=1 and tokenAddress=0x1f9840a85d5aF5bf1D1762F925BDADdC4201F984]\n\nUNI Token Information:\n- Current price: $5.32\n- Market cap: $2.7B \n- 24h trading volume: $89M\n\n[Uses get_evm_token_holders with chainId=1 and tokenAddress=0x1f9840a85d5aF5bf1D1762F925BDADdC4201F984]\n\nTop UNI Token Holders:\n1. 0x47173B170C64d16393a52e6C480b3Ad8c302ba1e: 5.2% of supply\n2. 0x1a9C8182C09F50C8318d769245beA52c32BE35BC: 3.8% of supply\n...\n```\n\n### 3. Review Recent Transactions\n\nYou can analyze transaction history for any address:\n\n```\nAssistant: Here's a summary of recent transactions.\n\n[Uses get_evm_transactions with walletAddress=0xYourWalletAddress]\n\nRecent activity:\n- Yesterday: Swapped 2 ETH for 3,500 UNI on Uniswap\n- 3 days ago: Withdrew 5 ETH from Binance\n- Last week: Minted an NFT for 0.08 ETH\n```\n\n### 4. Check Solana Balances\n\nYou can also analyze Solana wallets:\n\n```\nAssistant: Let me check your Solana wallet balances.\n\n[Uses get_svm_balances with walletAddress=YourSolanaAddress]\n\nThis wallet contains:\n- 12.5 SOL (~$875)\n- 2,500 USDC ($2,500)\n- Several SPL tokens including 150 BONK\n```\n\nConfigure this server with Claude Desktop or other MCP clients to enable your AI assistant to retrieve and analyze on-chain data in real time.\n\n## Prerequisites\n\n*   [Bun](https://bun.sh/) (latest version recommended)\n*   A Dune API Key from [Sim API](https://docs.sim.dune.com/)\n\n## Setup\n\n1.  **Clone the repository (if applicable) or ensure you have the project files.**\n\n2.  **Install dependencies:**\n    ```bash\n    bun install\n    ```\n\n3.  **Configure Environment Variables:**\n    Create a `.env` file in the project root and add your Dune API key:\n    ```env\n    DUNE_API_KEY=your_actual_dune_api_key_here\n    ```\n    Replace `your_actual_dune_api_key_here` {"server_name": "perplexity-mcp-server", "server_id": "cyanheads/perplexity-mcp-server", "description": "A Perplexity API Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that unlocks Perplexity's search-augmented AI capabilities for LLM agents. Features robust error handling, secure input validation, and transparent reasoning with the showThinking parameter. Built with type safety, modular architecture, and production-ready utilities.", "readme": "# Perplexity MCP Server\n\n[![TypeScript](https://img.shields.io/badge/TypeScript-^5.8.2-blue.svg)](https://www.typescriptlang.org/)\n[![Model Context Protocol](https://img.shields.io/badge/MCP-^1.8.0-green.svg)](https://modelcontextprotocol.io/)\n[![Version](https://img.shields.io/badge/Version-1.0.0-blue.svg)]()\n[![License](https://img.shields.io/badge/License-Apache%202.0-blue.svg)](https://opensource.org/licenses/Apache-2.0)\n[![Status](https://img.shields.io/badge/Status-Stable-green.svg)](https://github.com/cyanheads/perplexity-mcp-server/issues)\n[![GitHub](https://img.shields.io/github/stars/cyanheads/perplexity-mcp-server?style=social)](https://github.com/cyanheads/perplexity-mcp-server)\n\nAn MCP server providing tools to interact with the [Perplexity AI API](https://docs.perplexity.ai/docs/getting-started), built using the [mcp-ts-template](https://github.com/cyanheads/mcp-ts-template). This server allows AI agents compatible with the [Model Context Protocol (MCP)](https://modelcontextprotocol.io/) to leverage Perplexity's search-augmented query capabilities. Includes a showThinking parameter to enable reasoning models to show its internal reasoning process.\n\n## Core Features\n\n- **Utilities**: Reusable components for logging, error handling, ID generation, rate limiting, and request context management.\n- **Type Safety**: Strong typing with TypeScript.\n- **Error Handling**: Robust error handling system.\n- **Security**: Basic security features like input sanitization.\n- **Perplexity Tool**: A ready-to-use tool for interacting with the Perplexity Search API.\n\n> **.clinerules**: This repository includes a [.clinerules](.clinerules) file that serves as a developer cheat sheet for LLM coding agents (like Cline) providing quick references for codebase patterns, file locations, and code snippets specific to this project.\n\n## Table of Contents\n\n- [Overview](#overview)\n  - [What is Model Context Protocol?](#what-is-model-context-protocol)\n  - [Architecture & Components](#architecture--components)\n- [Features](#features)\n  - [Core Utilities](#core-utilities)\n  - [Type Safety](#type-safety)\n  - [Error Handling](#error-handling)\n  - [Security](#security)\n  - [Perplexity Search Tool](#perplexity-search-tool)\n- [Installation](#installation)\n- [Configuration](#configuration)\n- [Project Structure](#project-structure)\n- [Tool Documentation](#tool-documentation)\n  - [perplexity_search](#perplexity_search)\n- [Development Guidelines](#development-guidelines)\n  - [Adding a New Tool](#adding-a-new-tool)\n  - [Adding a New Resource](#adding-a-new-resource)\n- [License](#license)\n\n## Overview\n\n### What is Model Context Protocol?\n\nModel Context Protocol (MCP) is a framework that enables AI systems to interact with external tools and resources. It allows language models to:\n\n- Execute **tools** that perform actions and return results\n- Access structured **resources** that provide information\n- Create contextual workflows through standardized interfaces\n\nThis server allows AI systems to use the Perplexity API via MCP.\n\n### Architecture & Components\n\nThe server is based on the `mcp-ts-template` and follows its modular architecture:\n\n<details>\n<summary>Click to expand architecture diagram</summary>\n\n```mermaid\nflowchart TB\n    subgraph API[\"API Layer\"]\n        direction LR\n        MCP[\"MCP Protocol\"]\n        Val[\"Validation\"]\n        San[\"Sanitization\"]\n\n        MCP --> Val --> San\n    end\n\n    subgraph Core[\"Core Components\"]\n        direction LR\n        Config[\"Configuration\"]\n        Logger[\"Logging System\"]\n        Error[\"Error Handling\"]\n        Server[\"MCP Server\"]\n\n        Config --> Server\n        Logger --> Server\n        Error --> Server\n    end\n\n    subgraph Implementation[\"Implementation Layer\"]\n        direction LR\n        Tool[\"Tools (Perplexity)\"]\n        Util[\"Utilities\"]\n\n        Tool --> Server\n        Util --> Tool\n    end\n\n    San --> Config\n    San --> Server\n\n    classDef layer fill:#2d3748,stroke:#4299e1,stroke-width:3px,rx:5,color:#fff\n    classDef component fill:#1a202c,stroke:#a0aec0,stroke-width:2px,rx:3,color:#fff\n    class API,Core,Implementation layer\n    class MCP,Val,San,Config,Logger,Error,Server,Tool,Util component\n```\n\n</details>\n\nCore Components:\n\n- **Configuration System**: Environment-aware configuration with validation\n- **Logging System**: Structured logging with sensitive data redaction\n- **Error Handling**: Centralized error processing with consistent patterns\n- **MCP Server**: Protocol implementation for tools\n- **Validation Layer**: Input validation and sanitization using `validator` and `sanitize-html`.\n- **Utilities**: Reusable utility functions for common operations\n\n## Features\n\n### Core Utilities\n\n- **Logging**: Configurable logging with file rotation and sensitive data redaction\n- **Error Handling**: Pattern-based error classification and standardized reporting\n- **ID Generation**: Secure unique identifier creation with prefix support\n- **Rate Limiting**: Request throttling to simple runtime system that allows AI agents to:\n\n* Discover user-allowed tools provided to the AI by the extension based on browser site recipes\n* Call tools using structured markup; e.g. (``)\n* Route tool execution to a local or remote server\n* Receive formatted responses back into their current conversation\n\nThis gives AI models plugin-like powers **without cloud dependencies**, **without vendor lock-in**, and with **user-side control**.\n\n---\n\n## \ud83d\udd10 Designed for Enterprise-Grade Trust\n\nMCP Link is built for safe, auditable real-world AI action.\n\n* \ud83e\udde0 **Agents can only see tools you\u2019ve approved**\n* \ud83d\uded1 **AIs cannot call any tool unless you\u2019ve explicitly enabled it**\n* \ud83e\uddee **Every call can prompt for user approval, unless you override it**\n* \ud83e\uddf1 **Supports sandboxing via Docker for isolated tool environments**\n* \ud83d\udcdc **Logs every tool request, tool response, and agent call**\n\nWhether you\u2019re letting ChatGPT rename a folder, wanting Gemini to book you a hotel, or asking Claude to run semantic SQL queries, MCP Link ensures you stay in control \u2014 every step of the way.\n\n---\n\n## \ud83e\uddf0 What This Repo Contains\n\nThis repo isn't just an extension \u2014 it's an entire AI-tool ecosystem:\n\n| Folder | Purpose |\n| ----------------- | ---------------------------------------------------------------- |\n| `extension/` | Lightweight browser extension for Chrome, Firefox, Safari, etc. |\n| `remote/recipes/` | Enhancement recipes for popular AI sites (ChatGPT, Claude, etc.) |\n| `server/` | MCP SSE backend server (Python 3.9+) for tool execution |\n| `store/` | Licensing, gating, and optional payment/subscription logic |\n| `toolspecs/` | Shared schemas and validation logic for tools + manifests |\n\n---\n\n## \u2699\ufe0f How It Works\n\nMCP Link activates enhancement recipes in popular AI websites like:\n\n* [ChatGPT.com](https://chatgpt.com)\n* [claude.ai](https://claude.ai)\n* [gemini.google.com/app](https://gemini.google.com/app)\n* [perplexity.ai](https://www.perplexity.ai)\n* [x.com/i/grok](https://x.com/i/grok)\n\nThese recipes tell the AI how to discover and use the tools you approve it to use via your browser.\n\n---\n\n## \ud83e\udde9 What Tools Can Be Called?\n\nMCP Link enables AI agents to call both **remote tools** (hosted online) and **local tools** (run securely on your own machine or LAN).\n\nTools are activated using structured markup emitted by supported AI models and interpreted by the extension \u2014 but **only for tools the user has explicitly enabled**.\n\n---\n\n### \ud83e\uddcd\u200d\u2642\ufe0f User-Controlled Tool Access & Security\n\nMCP {"server_name": "deep-research-mcp", "server_id": "ali-kh7/deep-research-mcp", "description": "A Model Context Protocol (MCP) compliant server designed for comprehensive web research. It uses Tavily's Search and Crawl APIs to gather detailed information on a given topic, then structures this data in a format perfect for LLMs to create high-quality markdown documents.", "readme": "# Deep Research MCP \ud83c\udf10\n\n![Deep Research MCP](https://img.shields.io/badge/Release-v1.0.0-blue.svg)  \n[Download Releases](https://github.com/ali-kh7/deep-research-mcp/releases)\n\nWelcome to the **Deep Research MCP** repository! This project provides a server compliant with the Model Context Protocol (MCP). It is designed to facilitate comprehensive web research. By utilizing Tavily's Search and Crawl APIs, the server gathers detailed information on various topics and structures this data to support high-quality markdown document creation using large language models (LLMs).\n\n## Table of Contents\n\n- [Features](#features)\n- [Installation](#installation)\n- [Usage](#usage)\n- [API Documentation](#api-documentation)\n- [Contributing](#contributing)\n- [License](#license)\n- [Support](#support)\n\n## Features\n\n- **MCP Compliance**: The server adheres to the Model Context Protocol, ensuring compatibility with various tools and services.\n- **Data Aggregation**: Efficiently gathers and structures data from multiple sources.\n- **Markdown Generation**: Converts gathered data into well-structured markdown documents.\n- **Web Crawling**: Utilizes Tavily's Search and Crawl APIs for in-depth web research.\n- **Node.js and TypeScript**: Built using modern technologies for better performance and maintainability.\n\n## Installation\n\nTo get started with Deep Research MCP, follow these steps:\n\n1. **Clone the repository**:\n\n   ```bash\n   git clone https://github.com/ali-kh7/deep-research-mcp.git\n   ```\n\n2. **Navigate to the project directory**:\n\n   ```bash\n   cd deep-research-mcp\n   ```\n\n3. **Install the dependencies**:\n\n   ```bash\n   npm install\n   ```\n\n4. **Run the server**:\n\n   ```bash\n   npm start\n   ```\n\nYou can also check the [Releases](https://github.com/ali-kh7/deep-research-mcp/releases) section for downloadable files and specific versions.\n\n## Usage\n\nOnce the server is running, you can interact with it via the API. Here\u2019s how to use it effectively:\n\n1. **Send a request to gather information**:\n\n   You can send a request to the server with a specific topic to gather data. The server will return structured information ready for markdown generation.\n\n   Example request:\n\n   ```http\n   POST /api/research\n   Content-Type: application/json\n\n   {\n     \"topic\": \"Artificial Intelligence\"\n   }\n   ```\n\n2. **Receive structured data**:\n\n   The server responds with data in a structured format. This data can be used directly or transformed into markdown documents.\n\n3. **Generate markdown documents**:\n\n   The structured data can be converted into markdown using the provided functions in the API.\n\n### Example Markdown Output\n\n```markdown\n# Artificial Intelligence\n\n## Overview\nArtificial Intelligence (AI) refers to the simulation of human intelligence in machines.\n\n## Applications\n- Healthcare\n- Finance\n- Transportation\n\n## Conclusion\nAI is transforming industries and shaping the future.\n```\n\n## API Documentation\n\nFor detailed API documentation, please refer to the `docs` folder in this repository. It contains information on all available endpoints, request formats, and response structures.\n\n### Endpoints\n\n- **POST /api/research**: Gather information on a specific topic.\n- **GET /api/status**: Check the server status.\n\n## Contributing\n\nWe welcome contributions to improve Deep Research MCP. If you want to contribute, please follow these steps:\n\n1. **Fork the repository**.\n2. **Create a new branch**:\n\n   ```bash\n   git checkout -b feature/YourFeatureName\n   ```\n\n3. **Make your changes**.\n4. **Commit your changes**:\n\n   ```bash\n   git commit -m \"Add your message here\"\n   ```\n\n5. **Push to the branch**:\n\n   ```bash\n   git push origin feature/YourFeatureName\n   ```\n\n6. **Open a Pull Request**.\n\n## License\n\nThis project is licensed under the MIT License. See the [LICENSE](LICENSE) file for details.\n\n## Support\n\nIf you encounter any issues or have questions, please check the [Releases](https://github.com/ali-kh7/deep-research-mcp/releases) section or open an issue in the repository.\n\n---\n\nThank you for checking out Deep Research MCP! We hope this tool enhances your web research capabilities. Happy coding!", "tools": [{"name": "docs", "description": "folder in this repository. It contains information on all available endpoints, request formats, and response structures.", "inputSchema": {"type": "object", "properties": {"input": {"type": "string", "description": "Input parameter for docs"}}, "required": ["input"]}, "source": "readme", "access_level": "read"}], "tools_count": 1, "homepage": "", "url": "https://github.com/ali-kh7/deep-research-mcp", "topics": ["agent", "agentic-ai", "ai-research", "aiagent", "airesearch", "deep-research", "gpt-researcher", "graph-database", "information-retrieval", "mcp-server", "multi-agent", "openrouter", "research-and-development", "typescript"], "data_sources": ["github"]}'}

{"server_name": "drift-detector", "server_id": "saranshhalwai/drift-detector", "description": "A proof-of-concept showing the use of a meta-agent to monitor drift in an LLM, with the use of an MCP server. ", "readme": "---\ntitle: Drift Detector\nemoji: \ud83d\udcda\ncolorFrom: blue\ncolorTo: red\nsdk: gradio\nsdk_version: 5.33.0\napp_file: app.py\npinned: false\nlicense: mit\ntags: \n- mcp-server-track\n- agent-demo-track\n---\n\nThis was made with the combined efforts of Saransh Halwai(HF username: [Sars6](https://huggingface.co/Sars6)), Harsh Bhati(HF username: [HarshBhati](https://huggingface.co/HarshBhati)), and Anurag Prasad(HF username: [LegendXInfinity](https://huggingface.co/LegendXInfinity))\nGitHub repo: [Drift Detector](https://github.com/saranshhalwai/drift-detector)\n\n# Drift Detector\nDrift Detector is an MCP server, designed to detect drift in LLM performance over time by using the power of the **sampling** functionality of MCP. \nThis implementation is intended as a **proof of concept** and is **NOT intended** for production use without significant changes.\n\n## The Idea\n\nThe drift detector is a server that can be connected to any LLM client that supports the MCP sampling functionality. \nIt allows you to monitor the performance of your LLM models over time, detecting any drift in their behavior.\nThis is particularly useful for applications where the model's performance may change due to various factors, such as changes in the data distribution, model updates, or other external influences.\n\n## How to run\n\nTo run the Drift Detector, you need to have Python installed on your machine. Follow these steps:\n\n1. Clone the repository:\n   ```bash\n   git clone https://github.com/saranshhalwai/drift-detector\n    cd drift-detector\n    ```\n2. Install the required dependencies:\n    ```bash\n    pip install -r requirements.txt\n    ```\n3. Start the server:\n    ```bash\n   gradio app.py\n    ```\n4. Open your web browser and navigate to `http://localhost:7860` to access the Drift Detector interface.\n\n## Interface\n\nThe interface consists of the following components:\n- **Model Selection** - A panel allowing you to:\n  - Select models from a dropdown list\n  - Search for models by name or description\n  - Create new models with custom system prompts\n  - Enhance prompts with AI assistance\n\n- **Model Operations** - A tabbed interface with:\n  - **Chatbot** - Interact with the selected model through a conversational interface\n  - **Drift Analysis** - Analyze and visualize model drift over time, including:\n    - Calculate new drift scores for the selected model\n    - View historical drift data in JSON format\n    - Visualize drift trends through interactive charts\n\nThe drift detection functionality allows you to track changes in model performance over time, which is essential for monitoring and maintaining model quality.\n\n## Under the Hood\n\nOur GitHub repo consists of two main components:\n\n- **Drift Detector Server**  \n    A low-level MCP server that detects drift in LLM performance of the connected client.\n- **Target Client**\n    A client implemented using the fast-agent library, which connects to the Drift Detector server and demonstrates it's functionality.\n\nThe gradio interface in [app.py](app.py) is an example dashboard which allows users to interact with the Drift Detector server and visualize drift data.\n\n### Database Integration\n\nThe system uses SQLite (by default) to store:\n- Model information (name, capabilities, creation date)\n- Drift history (date and score for each drift calculation)\n- Diagnostic data (baseline and current questions/answers)\n\nThis enables persistent tracking of model performance over time, allowing for:\n- Historical trend analysis\n- Comparison between different models\n- Early detection of performance degradation\n\n### Drift Detector Server\n\nThe Drift Detector server is implemented using the MCP python SDK.\nIt exposes the following tools:\n\n1. **run_initial_diagnostics**\n   - **Purpose**: Establishes a baseline for model behavior using adaptive sampling techniques\n   - **Parameters**:\n     - `model`: The name of the model to run diagnostics on\n     - `model_capabilities`: Full description of the model's capabilities and special features\n   - **Sampling Process**:\n     - First generates a tailored questionnaire based on model-specific capabilities\n     - Collects responses by sampling the target model with controlled parameters (temperature=0.7)\n     - Each question is processed individually to ensure proper context isolation\n     - Baseline samples are stored as paired question-answer JSON records for future comparison\n   - **Output**: Confirmation message indicating successful baseline creation\n\n2. **check_drift**\n   - **Purpose**: Measures potential drift by comparative sampling against the baseline\n   - **Parameters**:\n     - `model`: The name of the model to check for drift\n   - **Sampling Process**:\n     - Retrieves the original questions from the baseline\n     - Re-samples the model with identical questions using the same sampling parameters\n     - Maintains consistent context conditions to ensure fair comparison\n     - Uses differential analysis to compare semantic and functional differences between sample sets\n   - **Drift Evaluation*\n[...truncated for length...]", "tools": [{"name": "model", "description": "The name of the model to run diagnostics on", "inputSchema": {"type": "object", "properties": {"input": {"type": "string", "description": "Input parameter for model"}}, "required": ["input"]}, "source": "readme", "access_level": "execute"}, {"name": "model_capabilities", "description": "Full description of the model's capabilities and special features", "inputSchema": {"type": "object", "properties": {"input": {"type": "string", "description": "Input parameter for model_capabilities"}}, "required": ["input"]}, "source": "readme", "access_level": "read"}, {"name": "run_initial_diagnostics", "description": "tool.", "inputSchema": {"type": "object", "properties": {"input": {"type": "string", "description": "Input parameter for run_initial_diagnostics"}}, "required": ["input"]}, "source": "readme", "access_level": "execute"}, {"name": "check_drift", "description": "tool to measure potential drift in the model's performance.", "inputSchema": {"type": "object", "properties": {"input": {"type": "string", "description": "Input parameter for check_drift"}}, "required": ["input"]}, "source": "readme", "access_level": "read"}], "tools_count": 4, "homepage": "https://huggingface.co/spaces/Agents-MCP-Hackathon/drift-detector", "url": "https://github.com/saranshhalwai/drift-detector", "topics": [], "data_sources": ["github"]}'}

Easily recall and save information from your Mac using simple AppleScript commands. Compatible with all macOS versions with minimal setup requirements.", "readme": "# MCP Server - My Apple Remembers\n**A simple MCP server that recalls and saves memories from and to Apple Notes.**\n\n[![Docker Pulls](https://img.shields.io/docker/pulls/buryhuang/mcp-my-apple-remembers)](https://hub.docker.com/r/buryhuang/mcp-my-apple-remembers)\n[![License: MIT](https://img.shields.io/badge/License-MIT-yellow.svg)](https://opensource.org/licenses/MIT)\n\n\n\n\n## Features\n\n* **Memory Recall**: Access notes, calendar events, messages, files and other information from your Mac\n* **Memory Persistence**: Save important information to Apple Notes for future reference\n* **Minimal Setup**: Just enable Remote Login on the target Mac\n* **Universal Compatibility**: Works with all macOS versions\n\n## Control in your hand\nYou can use prompt to instruct how you want your memory to be save. For example:\n```\nYou should always use Folder \"baryhuang\" on recall and save memory.\n```\n\n## Installation\n- [Enable SSH on macOS](https://support.apple.com/guide/mac-help/allow-a-remote-computer-to-access-your-mac-mchlp1066/mac)\n- [Install Docker Desktop for local Mac](https://docs.docker.com/desktop/setup/install/mac-install/)\n- [Add this MCP server to Claude Desktop](https://modelcontextprotocol.io/quickstart/user)\n\nYou can configure Claude Desktop to use the Docker image by adding the following to your Claude configuration:\n```json\n{\n \"mcpServers\": {\n \"my-apple-remembers\": {\n \"command\": \"docker\",\n \"args\": [\n \"run\",\n \"-i\",\n \"-e\",\n \"MACOS_USERNAME=your_macos_username\",\n \"-e\",\n \"MACOS_PASSWORD=your_macos_password\",\n \"-e\",\n \"MACOS_HOST=localhost\",\n \"--rm\",\n \"buryhuang/mcp-my-apple-remembers:latest\"\n ]\n }\n }\n}\n```\n\n## Developer Instructions\n### Clone the repo\n```bash\n# Clone the repository\ngit clone https://github.com/baryhuang/mcp-my-apple-remembers.git\ncd mcp-my-apple-remembers\n```\n\n### Building the Docker Image\n\n```bash\n# Build the Docker image\ndocker build -t mcp-my-apple-remembers .\n```\n\n### Publishing Multi-Platform Docker Images\n\n```bash\n# Set up Docker buildx for multi-platform builds\ndocker buildx create --use\n\n# Build and push the multi-platform image\ndocker buildx build --platform linux/amd64,linux/arm64 -t buryhuang/mcp-my-apple-remembers:latest --push .\n```\n\n### Tools Specifications\n\n#### my_apple_recall_memory\nRun AppleScript commands on a remote macOS system to recall memories. This tool helps access Apple Notes, Calendar events, iMessages, chat history, files, and other information on your Mac.\n\n#### my_apple_save_memory\nRun AppleScript commands on a remote macOS system to save important information. This tool allows AI to persist relevant information to Apple Notes for future reference. \n\nAll tools require macOS SSH access, with host and password.\n\n## Security Note\n\nAlways use secure, authenticated connections when accessing remote macOS machines. This tool should only be used with servers you trust and have permission to access.\n\n## License\n\nSee the LICENSE file for details. \n", "tools": [], "tools_count": 0, "homepage": "", "url": "https://github.com/honeybluesky/my-apple-remembers", "topics": ["agent-memory", "agentic-ai", "macos", "mcp-server"], "data_sources": ["github"]}'}
