{"server_name": "Volatility-MCP-Server", "server_id": "omghozlan/volatility-mcp-server", "description": " MCP (Model Context Protocol) interface for Volatility 3, providing memory forensics capabilities through LLM-based tools. Query, analyze, and automate Volatility 3 plugins using natural language via API or agent-based workflows", "readme": "# \u2744\ufe0f Volatility MCP Server\n\n[![Python](https://img.shields.io/badge/Python-3.11-blue.svg)](https://www.python.org/downloads/release/python-3110/)\n[![Volatility 3](https://img.shields.io/badge/Volatility-3.x-success)](https://github.com/volatilityfoundation/volatility3)\n[![Docker (Not) Ready](https://img.shields.io/badge/Docker-Ready-green)](https://hub.docker.com/)\n[![FastMCP](https://img.shields.io/badge/FastMCP-Server-red.svg)](https://github.com/Textualize/fastmcp)\n\n---\n\n## \ud83d\udccc Overview\n\nThe Volatility MCP Server is a powerful memory forensics automation toolkit powered by **Volatility 3**. It provides a modular, extensible interface for running Volatility plugins across Windows, Linux, and macOS memory dumps.\n\nIt makes memory analysis faster and more accessible via:\n\n\u2705 Plugin automation  \n\u2705 Cross-platform support (Windows, Linux, macOS)  \n\u2705 Modular plugin architecture  \n\u2705 Rich logging with beautiful formatting  \n\u2705 Easy plugin registration and management  \n\n---\n\n## \ud83d\udca1 Key Features\n\n- \ud83d\udd0d Powered by **Volatility 3**\n- \ud83e\udde0 Supports Windows, Linux, and macOS plugins\n- \u2699\ufe0f Asynchronous plugin execution\n- \ud83d\udce4 JSON output format\n- \ud83d\udcca Built-in error handling and validation\n- \ud83d\udc68\u200d\ud83d\udcbb FastMCP server interface\n- \ud83d\udc33 Docker-ready environment\n\n---\n\n## \ud83d\udce6 Requirements\n\n```bash\npython 3.11+\npip install -r requirements.txt\n```\n\n**requirements.txt:**\n```\nfastmcp\nrich\npython-dotenv\n```\n\n---\n\n## \ud83d\udcc1 Project Structure\n\n```\nVolatility-MCP-Server/\n\u251c\u2500\u2500 volatility_mcp_server.py    # Main server implementation\n\u251c\u2500\u2500 plugins/                    # Plugin modules\n\u2502   \u251c\u2500\u2500 base_plugin.py         # Base plugin class\n\u2502   \u251c\u2500\u2500 plugin_factory.py      # Plugin registration\n\u2502   \u251c\u2500\u2500 windows/               # Windows plugins\n\u2502   \u251c\u2500\u2500 linux/                 # Linux plugins\n\u2502   \u251c\u2500\u2500 mac/                   # macOS plugins\n\u2502   \u2514\u2500\u2500 common/                # Common plugins\n\u251c\u2500\u2500 requirements.txt           # Dependencies\n\u2514\u2500\u2500 README.md                 # This file\n```\n\n---\n\n## \ud83d\udda5\ufe0f Usage\n\n### \ud83d\udd27 Local Connection\n#### Using `stdio`\nCreate a `.cursor/mcp.json` file with:\n\n```json\n{\n  \"mcpServers\": {\n    \"Volatility3\": {\n      \"command\": \"fastmcp\",\n      \"args\": [\"run\", \"path/to/volatility_mcp_server.py:mcp\", \"--transport\", \"stdio\"]\n    }\n  }\n}\n```\n#### Using `sse`\nRun the server using\n```pwsh\nfastmcp run volatility_mcp_server.py:mcp --transport sse\n```\nFor Claude desktop\n```json\n{\n    \"mcpServers\": {\n      \"volatility3\": {\n        \"command\": \"npx\",\n        \"args\": [\"mcp-remote\", \"http://localhost:8000/sse\"]\n      }\n    }\n  }\n```\nFor Cursor\n```json\n{\n  \"mcpServers\": {\n    \"Volatility3\": {\n      \"url\": \"http://localhost:8000/sse\"\n    }\n  }\n}\n```\n\n### \ud83d\udcca Available Plugins\n\n#### Windows Plugins\n- Process: `PsList`, `PsTree`, `PsScan`\n- Memory: `Malfind`, `MemMap`\n- Network: `NetScan`\n- Registry: `RegistryHiveList`, `RegistryPrintKey`\n- System: `SvcScan`, `CmdLine`, `DllList`, `Handles`, `FileScan`\n- Disk: `ADS`, `MFTScan`, `ResidentData`\n\n#### Linux Plugins\n- Process: `PsList`, `PsTree`, `PsScan`, `PsAux`, `PsCallStack`\n- System: `Bash`, `Boottime`, `Capabilities`\n- Network: `IpAddr`, `IpLink`, `Netfilter`\n- Memory: `Malfind`, `ModuleExtract`\n- File System: `Files`, `InodePages`, `RecoverFs`\n\n#### macOS Plugins\n- Process: `PsList`, `PsTree`, `Psaux`\n- System: `Bash`, `Dmesg`, `Lsmod`\n- Network: `Ifconfig`, `Netstat`\n- Security: `Check_syscall`, `Check_sysctl`, `Check_trap_table`\n\n#### Common Plugins\n- Framework: `Banners`, `ConfigWriter`, `FrameworkInfo`, `IsfInfo`, `LayerWriter`\n- Scan: `RegExScan`, `YaraScan`, `Vmscan`\n- Timeline: `Timeliner`\n\n---\n\n## \ud83d\udc33 Docker Usage (No idea what I wanted to do here but might be useful in the future)\n\n### \u2699\ufe0f 1. Build the Docker Image\n\nFrom the root directory:\n\n```bash\ndocker build -t volatility-mcp .\n```\n\n### \u25b6\ufe0f 2. Run the Server\n\n```bash\ndocker run --rm -it \\\n  -v $(pwd)/memdumps:/memdumps \\\n  -v $(pwd)/output:/output \\\n  volatility-mcp\n```\n\n---\n\n## \ud83d\udd27 Developer/Contributor Guide\n\n### \ud83e\uddf1 Setup Virtual Environment\n\n```bash\npython3 -m venv venv\nsource venv/bin/activate\npip install -r requirements.txt\n```\n\n### \ud83e\uddea Run Locally\n\n```bash\npython volatility_mcp_server.py\n```\n\n---\n\n## \u270d\ufe0f Customization Tips\n\n- \ud83d\udcc0 Want to add a new plugin? Extend `BasePlugin` and register it in `plugin_factory.py`\n- \ud83e\udde9 Want to add a new OS? Create a new plugin directory and implement the plugins\n- \ud83d\udcda Want to add new features? The modular architecture makes it easy to extend\n\n---\n\n## \ud83d\ude4b FAQ\n\n> \ud83d\udfe0 **Does this support Volatility 2.x?**  \n\ud83d\udd3b No. This server supports **Volatility 3 only** for modern plugin support.\n\n> \ud83d\udd35 **Can I add custom plugins?**  \n\u2705 Yes! Just extend the `BasePlugin` class and register it in the factory.\n\n> \ud83d\udd34 **Why use FastMCP?**  \nIt provides a clean, efficient interface for running Volatility plugins with proper error handling and async support.\n\n---\n\n## \ud83d\udcdc License\n\nMIT \u00a9\ufe0f 2025\n\n---\n\n## \ud83c\udf10 More Tools?\n\nYou may also like:\n- [Volatility MCP Server Data: {"server_name": "mcp-postman", "server_id": "shannonlal/mcp-postman", "description": "MCP server for running Postman Collections locally via Newman. Allows for simple execution of Postman Server and returns the results of whether the collection passed all the tests.", "readme": "# Postman MCP Server\n[![smithery badge](https://smithery.ai/badge/mcp-postman)](https://smithery.ai/server/mcp-postman)\n\nAn MCP (Model Context Protocol) server that enables running Postman collections using Newman. This server allows LLMs to execute API tests and get detailed results through a standardized interface.\n\n[![MCP Postman Server Demo](https://img.youtube.com/vi/d1WgTqwMsog/0.jpg)](https://youtu.be/d1WgTqwMsog)\n\n\n\n## Features\n\n- Run Postman collections using Newman\n- Support for environment files\n- Support for global variables\n- Detailed test results including:\n - Overall success/failure status\n - Test summary (total, passed, failed)\n - Detailed failure information\n - Execution timings\n\n## Installation\n\n### Installing via Smithery\n\nTo install Postman Runner for Claude Desktop automatically via [Smithery](https://smithery.ai/server/mcp-postman):\n\n```bash\nnpx -y @smithery/cli install mcp-postman --client claude\n```\n\n### Manual Installation\n```bash\n# Clone the repository\ngit clone \ncd mcp-postman\n\n# Install dependencies\npnpm install\n\n# Build the project\npnpm build\n```\n\n## Usage\n\n### Configuration\n\nAdd the server to your Claude desktop configuration file at `~/Library/Application Support/Claude/claude_desktop_config.json`:\n\n```json\n{\n \"mcpServers\": {\n \"postman-runner\": {\n \"command\": \"node\",\n \"args\": [\"/absolute/path/to/mcp-postman/build/index.js\"]\n }\n }\n}\n```\n\n### Available Tools\n\n#### run-collection\n\nRuns a Postman collection and returns the test results.\n\n**Parameters:**\n\n- `collection` (required): Path or URL to the Postman collection\n- `environment` (optional): Path or URL to environment file\n- `globals` (optional): Path or URL to globals file\n- `iterationCount` (optional): Number of iterations to run\n\n**Example Response:**\n\n```json\n{\n \"success\": true,\n \"summary\": {\n \"total\": 5,\n \"failed\": 0,\n \"passed\": 5\n },\n \"failures\": [],\n \"timings\": {\n \"started\": \"2024-03-14T10:00:00.000Z\",\n \"completed\": \"2024-03-14T10:00:01.000Z\",\n \"duration\": 1000\n }\n}\n```\n\n### Example Usage in Claude\n\nYou can use the server in Claude by asking it to run a Postman collection:\n\n\"Run the Postman collection at /path/to/collection.json and tell me if all tests passed\"\n\nClaude will:\n\n1. Use the run-collection tool\n2. Analyze the test results\n3. Provide a human-friendly summary of the execution\n\n## Development\n\n### Project Structure\n\n```\nsrc/\n \u251c\u2500\u2500 index.ts # Entry point\n \u251c\u2500\u2500 server/\n \u2502 \u251c\u2500\u2500 server.ts # MCP Server implementation\n \u2502 \u2514\u2500\u2500 types.ts # Type definitions\n \u2514\u2500\u2500 newman/\n \u2514\u2500\u2500 runner.ts # Newman runner implementation\ntest/\n \u251c\u2500\u2500 server.test.ts # Server tests\n \u251c\u2500\u2500 newman-runner.test.ts # Runner tests\n \u2514\u2500\u2500 fixtures/ # Test fixtures\n \u2514\u2500\u2500 sample-collection.json\n```\n\n### Running Tests\n\n```bash\n# Run tests\npnpm test\n\n# Run tests with coverage\npnpm test:coverage\n```\n\n### Building\n\n```bash\n# Build the project\npnpm build\n\n# Clean build artifacts\npnpm clean\n```\n\n## Contributing\n\n1. Fork the repository\n2. Create your feature branch (`git checkout -b feature/amazing-feature`)\n3. Commit your changes (`git commit -m 'Add some amazing feature'`)\n4. Push to the branch (`git push origin feature/amazing-feature`)\n5. Open a Pull Request\n\n## License\n\nISC\n", "tools": [{"name": "collection", "description": "(required): Path or URL to the Postman collection", "inputSchema": {"type": "object", "properties": {"file_path": {"type": "string", "description": "File path or file to process"}, "url": {"type": "string", "description": "URL or link to process"}}, "required": ["file_path", "url"]}, "source": "readme", "access_level": "read"}, {"name": "environment", "description": "(optional): Path or URL to environment file", "inputSchema": {"type": "object", "properties": {"file_path": {"type": "string", "description": "File path or file to process"}, "url": {"type": "string", "description": "URL or link to process"}}, "required": ["file_path", "url"]}, "source": "readme", "access_level": "read"}, {"name": "globals", "description": "(optional): Path or URL to globals file", "inputSchema": {"type": "object", "properties": {"file_path": {"type": "string", "description": "File path or file to process"}, "url": {"type": "string", "description": "URL or link to process"}}, "required": ["file_path", "url"]}, "source": "readme", "access_level": "read"}, {"name": "iterationCount", "description": "(optional): Number of iterations to run", "inputSchema": {"type": "object", "properties": {"input": {"type": "string", "description": "Input parameter for iterationCount"}}, "required": ["input"]}, "source": "readme", "access_level": "execute"}], "tools_count": 4, "homepage": "", "url": "https://github.com/shannonlal/mcp-postman", "topics": [], "data_sources": ["github", "official"]}'}

{"server_name": "task-manager-mcp", "server_id": "mryanmyn/task-manager-mcp", "description": "A simple UI and MCP server for task + project plan management ", "readme": "# Terminal Task Tracker\n\nA terminal-based task tracking application with a three-pane layout for managing tasks and project plans.\n\n # Image\n\n![Terminal Task Tracker](https://github.com/MrYanMYN/task-manager-mcp/blob/master/img.png?raw=true)\n\n## Features\n\n- Three-pane terminal UI:\n  - Task list (top left)\n  - Task details (top right)\n  - Project plan (bottom, full width)\n- Task management:\n  - Create, view, edit, and delete tasks\n  - Set priorities and status\n  - Add detailed descriptions\n- Project plan management:\n  - Define high-level project steps\n  - Track step completion\n  - Reorder steps\n- Complete API for programmatic access\n- Command-line interface for scripting\n- Data persistence\n\n## Installation\n\n```bash\n# Clone the repository\ngit clone https://github.com/yourusername/terminal-task-tracker.git\ncd terminal-task-tracker\n\n# Install dependencies\npip install -e .\n```\n\n## Usage\n\n### Terminal UI\n\nTo start the terminal UI:\n\n```bash\npython -m main.py\n```\n\nKey bindings:\n- `Tab`: Cycle between windows\n- `Up/Down`: Navigate lists\n- `Enter`: Select task (in task list)\n- `n`: New item (in task list or plan)\n- `e`: Edit item\n- `d`: Delete item\n- `Space`: Toggle completion (in plan)\n- `Esc`: Exit\n\n### Command-line Interface\n\nThe CLI provides access to all functionality:\n\n```bash\n# List all tasks\npython -m app.api.cli task list\n\n# Add a new task\npython -m app.api.cli task add \"Implement feature X\" --description \"Details about feature X\" --priority 2\n\n# Mark a plan step as completed\npython -m app.api.cli plan toggle STEP_ID\n\n# Export data to JSON\npython -m app.api.cli export data.json\n```\n\n### API Usage\n\n```python\nfrom app.core.task_manager import TaskManager\nfrom app.core.plan_manager import PlanManager\nfrom app.api.api import TaskTrackerAPI\n\n# Initialize managers\ntask_manager = TaskManager(\"tasks.json\")\nplan_manager = PlanManager(\"plan.json\")\n\n# Create API\napi = TaskTrackerAPI(task_manager, plan_manager)\n\n# Add a task\ntask = api.add_task(\"Implement feature X\", \"Details about feature X\", priority=2)\n\n# Add a plan step\nstep = api.add_plan_step(\"Design architecture for shared operations module\")\n\n# Mark step as completed\napi.toggle_plan_step(step[\"id\"])\n\n# Save data\napi.save_all()\n```\n\n## Project Structure\n\n```\nterminal-task-tracker/\n\u251c\u2500\u2500 app/\n\u2502   \u251c\u2500\u2500 __init__.py\n\u2502   \u251c\u2500\u2500 core/               # Business logic\n\u2502   \u2502   \u251c\u2500\u2500 __init__.py\n\u2502   \u2502   \u251c\u2500\u2500 task_manager.py\n\u2502   \u2502   \u2514\u2500\u2500 plan_manager.py\n\u2502   \u251c\u2500\u2500 ui/                 # Terminal UI\n\u2502   \u2502   \u251c\u2500\u2500 __init__.py\n\u2502   \u2502   \u251c\u2500\u2500 terminal_ui.py\n\u2502   \u2502   \u251c\u2500\u2500 ui_components.py\n\u2502   \u2502   \u2514\u2500\u2500 input_handler.py\n\u2502   \u2514\u2500\u2500 api/                # API and CLI\n\u2502       \u251c\u2500\u2500 __init__.py\n\u2502       \u251c\u2500\u2500 api.py\n\u2502       \u2514\u2500\u2500 cli.py\n\u251c\u2500\u2500 main.py                 # Main application entry point\n\u2514\u2500\u2500 README.md\n```\n\n## Data Storage\n\nBy default, data is stored in the `~/.tasktracker` directory:\n- `tasks.json`: Tasks data\n- `plan.json`: Project plan data\n- `notes.json`: Notes data\n\n## License\n\nMIT", "tools": [{"name": "Tab", {"server_name": "A2A-MCP-Server", "server_id": "gongrzhe/a2a-mcp-server", "description": "An MCP server that bridges the Model Context Protocol (MCP) with the Agent-to-Agent (A2A) protocol, enabling MCP-compatible AI assistants (like Claude) to seamlessly interact with A2A agents.", "readme": "# A2A MCP Server\n\n[![License](https://img.shields.io/badge/License-Apache_2.0-blue.svg)](https://opensource.org/licenses/Apache-2.0)\n![](https://badge.mcpx.dev?type=server 'MCP Server')\n[![smithery badge](https://smithery.ai/badge/@GongRzhe/A2A-MCP-Server)](https://smithery.ai/server/@GongRzhe/A2A-MCP-Server)\n\nA mcp server that bridges the Model Context Protocol (MCP) with the Agent-to-Agent (A2A) protocol, enabling MCP-compatible AI assistants (like Claude) to seamlessly interact with A2A agents.\n\n## Overview\n\nThis project serves as an integration layer between two cutting-edge AI agent protocols:\n\n- **Model Context Protocol (MCP)**: Developed by Anthropic, MCP allows AI assistants to connect to external tools and data sources. It standardizes how AI applications and large language models connect to external resources in a secure, composable way.\n\n- **Agent-to-Agent Protocol (A2A)**: Developed by Google, A2A enables communication and interoperability between different AI agents through a standardized JSON-RPC interface.\n\nBy bridging these protocols, this server allows MCP clients (like Claude) to discover, register, communicate with, and manage tasks on A2A agents through a unified interface.\n\n### Demo\n\n#### 1, Run The Currency Agent in A2A Sample\n\n![agent](public/agent.png)\n\n`also support cloud deployed Agent`\n\n![cloudAgent](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/481cbf01-95a0-4b0a-9ac5-898aef66a944)\n\n\n#### 2, Use Claude to Register the Currency Agent \n\n![register](public/register.png)\n\n#### 3, Use Claude to Send a task to the Currency Agent and get the result \n\n![task](public/task.png)\n\n## Features\n\n- **Agent Management**\n  - Register A2A agents with the bridge server\n  - List all registered agents\n  - Unregister agents when no longer needed\n\n- **Communication**\n  - Send messages to A2A agents and receive responses\n  - Stream responses from A2A agents in real-time\n\n- **Task Management**\n  - Track which A2A agent handles which task\n  - Retrieve task results using task IDs\n  - Cancel running tasks\n\n- **Transport Support**\n  - Multiple transport types: stdio, streamable-http, SSE\n  - Configure transport type using MCP_TRANSPORT environment variable\n\n## Installation\n\n### Installing via Smithery\n\nTo install A2A Bridge Server for Claude Desktop automatically via [Smithery](https://smithery.ai/server/@GongRzhe/A2A-MCP-Server):\n\n```bash\nnpx -y @smithery/cli install @GongRzhe/A2A-MCP-Server --client claude\n```\n\n### Option 1: Install from PyPI\n\n```bash\npip install a2a-mcp-server\n```\n\n### Option 2: Local Installation\n\n1. Clone the repository:\n   ```bash\n   git clone https://github.com/GongRzhe/A2A-MCP-Server.git\n   cd A2A-MCP-Server\n   ```\n\n2. Set up a virtual environment:\n   ```bash\n   python -m venv .venv\n   source .venv/bin/activate  # On Windows: .venv\\Scripts\\activate\n   ```\n\n3. Install dependencies:\n   ```bash\n   pip install -r requirements.txt\n   ```\n\n## Configuration\n\n### Environment Variables\n\nConfigure how the MCP server runs using these environment variables:\n\n```bash\n# Transport type: stdio, streamable-http, or sse\nexport MCP_TRANSPORT=\"streamable-http\"\n\n# Host for the MCP server\nexport MCP_HOST=\"0.0.0.0\"\n\n# Port for the MCP server (when using HTTP transports)\nexport MCP_PORT=\"8000\"\n\n# Path for the MCP server endpoint (when using HTTP transports)\nexport MCP_PATH=\"/mcp\"\n\n# Path for SSE endpoint (when using SSE transport)\nexport MCP_SSE_PATH=\"/sse\"\n\n# Enable debug logging\nexport MCP_DEBUG=\"true\"\n```\n\n### Transport Types\n\nThe A2A MCP Server supports multiple transport types:\n\n1. **stdio** (default): Uses standard input/output for communication\n   - Ideal for command-line usage and testing\n   - No HTTP server is started\n   - Required for Claude Desktop\n\n2. **streamable-http** (recommended for web clients): HTTP transport with streaming support\n   - Recommended for production deployments\n   - Starts an HTTP server to handle MCP requests\n   - Enables streaming of large responses\n\n3. **sse**: Server-Sent Events transport\n   - Provides real-time event streaming\n   - Useful for real-time updates\n\nTo specify the transport type:\n\n```bash\n# Using environment variable\nexport MCP_TRANSPORT=\"streamable-http\"\nuvx a2a-mcp-server\n\n# Or directly in the command\nMCP_TRANSPORT=streamable-http uvx a2a-mcp-server\n```\n\n## Running the Server\n\n### From Command Line\n\n```bash\n# Using default settings (stdio transport)\nuvx a2a-mcp-server\n\n# Using HTTP transport on specific host and port\nMCP_TRANSPORT=streamable-http MCP_HOST=127.0.0.1 MCP_PORT=8080 uvx a2a-mcp-server\n```\n\n## Configuring in Claude Desktop\n\nClaude Desktop allows you to configure MCP servers in the `claude_desktop_config.json` file. This file is typically located at:\n\n- **Windows**: `%APPDATA%\\Claude\\claude_desktop_config.json`\n- **macOS**: `~/Library/Application Support/Claude/claude_desktop_config.json`\n- **Linux**: `~/.config/Claude/claude_desktop_config.json`\n\n### Method 1: PyPI Installation (Recommended)\n\nAdd the following to the `mcpServers` section of your `\n[...truncated for length...]", "tools": [{"name": "mcpServers", "description": "section of your `claude_desktop_config.json`:", "inputSchema": {"type": "object", "properties": {"input": {"type": "string", "description": "Input parameter for mcpServers"}}, "required": ["input"]}, "source": "readme", "access_level": "read"}, {"name": "task_id", "description": "2. Maps this ID to the agent's URL in the `task_agent_mapping` dictionary", "inputSchema": {"type": "object", "properties": {"url": {"type": "string", "description": "URL or link to process"}}, "required": ["url"]}, "source": "readme", "access_level": "read"}, {"name": "list_agents", "description": ")", "inputSchema": {"type": "object", "properties": {"input": {"type": "string", "description": "Input parameter for list_agents"}}, "required": ["input"]}, "source": "readme", "access_level": "read"}, {"name": "MCP_TRANSPORT", "description": "is set to `\"stdio\"` in the `env` section", "inputSchema": {"type": "object", "properties": {"input": {"type": "string", "description": "Input parameter for MCP_TRANSPORT"}}, "required": ["input"]}, "source": "readme", "access_level": "write"}, {"name": "A2AServerTaskManager", "description": "class that extends `InMemoryTaskManager`. {"server_name": "celo-mcp", "server_id": "celo-org/celo-mcp", "description": "MCP server that provides AI agents with access to Celo blockchain data and functionality", "readme": "# Celo MCP Server\n\nA Model Context Protocol (MCP) server for interacting with the Celo blockchain. This server provides comprehensive access to Celo blockchain data, token operations, NFT management, smart contract interactions, transaction handling, and governance operations.\n\n## Installation\n\n1. Clone the repository:\n\n```bash\ngit clone https://github.com/celo-org/celo-mcp\ncd celo-mcp\n```\n\n2. Install dependencies:\n\n```bash\npip install -e .\n```\n\n3. Set up environment variables (optional):\n\n```bash\nexport CELO_RPC_URL=\"https://forno.celo.org\"  # Default: Celo mainnet\nexport CELO_TESTNET_RPC_URL=\"https://alfajores-forno.celo-testnet.org\"  # Alfajores testnet\n```\n\n## MCP Integration\n\n### Cursor IDE Integration\n\nTo use this MCP server with Cursor IDE, add the following configuration to your MCP settings file (`~/.cursor/mcp.json`):\n\n```json\n{\n  \"mcpServers\": {\n    \"celo-mcp\": {\n      \"command\": \"uvx\",\n      \"args\": [\"--refresh\", \"celo-mcp\"]\n    }\n  }\n}\n```\n\nThe `--refresh` flag ensures that the latest code is always loaded when the MCP server starts.\n\n### Claude Desktop Integration\n\nFor Claude Desktop, add this configuration to your MCP settings file (`~/Library/Application Support/Claude/claude_desktop_config.json` on macOS):\n\n```json\n{\n  \"mcpServers\": {\n    \"celo-mcp\": {\n      \"command\": \"uvx\",\n      \"args\": [\"--refresh\", \"celo-mcp\"]\n    }\n  }\n}\n```\n\n## Usage\n\n### Running the Server\n\n```bash\n# Run the MCP server\npython -m celo_mcp.server\n\n# Or use the CLI entry point\ncelo-mcp-server\n```\n\n### Available Tools\n\n#### Blockchain Data Operations\n\n1. **get_network_status**\n\n   - Get current network status and connection information\n   - No parameters required\n\n2. **get_block**\n\n   - Fetch block information by number, hash, or \"latest\"\n   - Parameters: `block_identifier`, `include_transactions` (optional)\n\n3. **get_transaction**\n\n   - Get transaction details by hash\n   - Parameters: `tx_hash`\n\n4. **get_account**\n\n   - Get account information including balance and nonce\n   - Parameters: `address`\n\n5. **get_latest_blocks**\n   - Get information about recent blocks\n   - Parameters: `count` (optional, default: 10, max: 100)\n\n#### Token Operations\n\n6. **get_token_info**\n\n   - Get detailed token information (name, symbol, decimals, supply)\n   - Parameters: `token_address`\n\n7. **get_token_balance**\n\n   - Get token balance for a specific address\n   - Parameters: `token_address`, `address`\n\n8. **get_celo_balances**\n   - Get CELO and stable token balances for an address\n   - Parameters: `address`\n\n#### NFT Operations\n\n9. **get_nft_info**\n\n   - Get NFT information including metadata and collection details\n   - Parameters: `contract_address`, `token_id`\n\n10. **get_nft_balance**\n    - Get NFT balance for an address (supports ERC721 and ERC1155)\n    - Parameters: `contract_address`, `address`, `token_id` (optional for ERC1155)\n\n#### Smart Contract Operations\n\n11. **call_contract_function**\n\n    - Call a read-only contract function\n    - Parameters: `contract_address`, `function_name`, `abi`, `function_args` (optional), `from_address` (optional)\n\n12. **estimate_contract_gas**\n    - Estimate gas for a contract function call\n    - Parameters: `contract_address`, `function_name`, `abi`, `from_address`, `function_args` (optional), `value` (optional)\n\n#### Transaction Operations\n\n13. **estimate_transaction**\n\n    - Estimate gas and cost for a transaction\n    - Parameters: `to`, `from_address`, `value` (optional), `data` (optional)\n\n14. **get_gas_fee_data**\n    - Get current gas fee data including EIP-1559 fees\n    - No parameters required\n\n#### Governance Operations\n\n15. **get_governance_proposals**\n\n    - Get Celo governance proposals with pagination support\n    - Parameters: `include_inactive` (optional), `include_metadata` (optional), `page` (optional), `page_size` (optional), `offset` (optional), `limit` (optional)\n\n16. **get_proposal_details**\n    - Get detailed information about a specific governance proposal including content and voting history\n    - Parameters: `proposal_id`\n\n#### Staking Operations\n\n17. **get_staking_balances**\n\n    - Get staking balances for an address, including active and pending stakes broken down by validator group\n    - Parameters: `address`\n\n18. **get_activatable_stakes**\n\n    - Get information about pending stakes that can be activated for earning rewards\n    - Parameters: `address`\n\n19. **get_validator_groups**\n\n    - Get information about all validator groups, including their members, votes, capacity, and performance metrics\n    - No parameters required\n\n20. **get_validator_group_details**\n\n    - Get detailed information about a specific validator group including its members and performance data\n    - Parameters: `group_address`\n\n21. **get_total_staking_info**\n    - Get network-wide staking information including total votes and participation metrics\n    - No parameters required\n\n## Key Features\n\n### Token Support\n\n- **ERC20 Standard**: Full support for ERC20 tokens\n- **Celo Stable Tokens**: Built-in su\n[...truncated for length...]", "tools": [{"name": "block_identifier", "description": ", `include_transactions` MCP Server Data: {"server_name": "VibeShift", "server_id": "groundng/vibeshift", "description": "[MCP Server] The Security Agent for AI assisted coding", "readme": "# VibeShift: The Security Engineer for Vibe Coders\n\n**VibeShift** is an intelligent security agent designed to integrate seamlessly with AI coding assistants (like Cursor, GitHub Copilot, Claude Code, etc.). It acts as your automated security engineer, analyzing code generated by AI, identifying vulnerabilities, and facilitating AI-driven remediation *before* insecure code makes it to your codebase. It leverages the **MCP (Model Context Protocol)** for smooth interaction within your existing AI coding environment.\n\n\n[![Twitter Follow](https://img.shields.io/twitter/follow/Omiiee_Chan?style=social)](https://x.com/Omiiee_Chan)\n[![Twitter Follow](https://img.shields.io/twitter/follow/_gauravkabra_?style=social)](https://x.com/_gauravkabra_)\n![](https://img.shields.io/github/stars/groundng/vibeshift)\n\n\n**The Problem:** AI coding assistants accelerate development dramatically, but they can also generate code with subtle or overt security vulnerabilities. Manually reviewing all AI-generated code for security flaws is slow, error-prone, and doesn't scale with the speed of AI development. This \"vibe-driven development\" can leave applications exposed.\n\n**The Solution: GroundNG's VibeShift** bridges this critical security gap by enabling your AI coding assistant to:\n\n1. **Automatically Analyze AI-Generated Code:** As code is generated or modified by an AI assistant, VibeShift can be triggered to perform security analysis using a suite of tools (SAST, DAST components) and AI-driven checks.\n2. **Identify Security Vulnerabilities:** Pinpoints common and complex vulnerabilities (e.g., XSS, SQLi, insecure configurations, logic flaws) within the AI-generated snippets or larger code blocks.\n3. **Facilitate AI-Driven Remediation:** Provides detailed feedback and vulnerability information directly to the AI coding assistant, enabling it to suggest or even automatically apply fixes.\n4. **Create a Security Feedback Loop:** Ensures that developers and their AI assistants are immediately aware of potential security risks, allowing for rapid correction and learning.\n\nThis creates a \"shift-left\" security paradigm for AI-assisted coding, embedding security directly into the development workflow and helping to ship more secure code, faster.\n\n# Demo (Click to play these videos)\n[![Demo](https://img.youtube.com/vi/bN_RgQGa8B0/maxresdefault.jpg)](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bN_RgQGa8B0)\n[![Click to play](https://img.youtube.com/vi/wCbCUCqjnXQ/maxresdefault.jpg)](https://youtu.be/wCbCUCqjnXQ)\n\n\n## Features\n\n* **MCP Integration:** Seamlessly integrates with Cursor/Windsurf/Github Copilot/Roo Code\n* **Automated Security Scanning:** Triggers on AI code generation/modification to perform:\n * **Static Code Analysis (SAST):** Integrates tools like Semgrep to find vulnerabilities in source code.\n * **Dynamic Analysis (DAST Primitives):** Can invoke tools like Nuclei or ZAP for checks against running components (where applicable).\n* **AI-Assisted Test Recording:** Generate Playwright-based test scripts from natural language descriptions (in automated mode).\n* **Deterministic Test Execution:** Run recorded JSON test files reliably using Playwright.\n* **AI-Powered Test Discovery:** Crawl websites and leverage any LLM (in openai compliant format) to suggest test steps for discovered pages.\n* **Regression Testing:** Easily run existing test suites to catch regressions.\n* **Automated Feedback Loop:** Execution results (including failures, screenshots, console logs) are returned, providing direct feedback to the AI assistant.\n* **Self Healing:** Existing tests self heal in case of code changes. No need to manually update.\n* **UI tests:** UI tests which aren't supported by playwright directly are also supported. For example, `Check if the text is overflowing in the div`\n* **Visual Regression Testing**: Using traditional pixelmatch and vision LLM approach.\n\n## How it Works\n\n```\n+-------------+ +-----------------+ +---------------------+ +-----------------+ +-------------+\n| User | ----> | AI Coding Agent | ----> | MCP Server | ----> | Scan, test, exec| ----> | Browser |\n| (Developer) | | (e.g., Copilot) | | (mcp_server.py) | | (SAST, Record) | | (Playwright)|\n+-------------+ +-----------------+ +---------------------+ +-----------------+ +-------------+\n ^ | | |\n[...truncated for length...]", "tools": [{"name": "get_security_scan", "description": ", `record_test_flow`, `run_regression_test`, `discover_test_flows`, `list_recorded_tests`).", "inputSchema": {"type": "object", }

{'raw_input': 'ONLY RESPOND WITH JSON. NO EXPLANATIONS. NO MARKDOWN. NO TEXT OUTSIDE JSON.

Analyze the MCP server for financial relevance. Look for keywords: payment, banking, credit, loan, finance, money, currency, crypto, investment, trading, portfolio, market, exchange, wallet, account, budget, expense, income, tax, invoice, billing, accounting, insurance, compliance, KYC, AML.

JSON FORMAT (NOTHING ELSE):
{
  "server_name": "string",
  "server_id": "string", 
  "is_finance_llm": "yes|no|unclear",
  "confidence": "high|medium|low",
  "threat_models": [],
  "analysis_notes": "Brief reason"
}

If financial keywords found: is_finance_llm="yes". If not: is_finance_llm="no". If unclear: is_finance_llm="unclear".

RESPOND ONLY WITH JSON.

MCP Server Data:
{"server_name": "Markdown Rules", "server_id": "@valstro/markdown-rules-mcp", "description": "The portable alternative to Cursor Rules and IDE-specific rules.\n\nTransform your project documentation into intelligent AI context using standard Markdown files that work across any MCP-compatible AI tool. Escape vendor lock-in and scattered documentation forever.\n\nWhy Choose Markdown Rules?\n\n\ud83d\ude80 Universal Compatibility \u2014 Write once, use everywhere. Your documentation works with Cursor, Claude Desktop, and any future MCP-enabled AI tool. No vendor lock-in.\n\n\ud83d\udd17 Smart Dependency Resolution \u2014 Automatically traverse and include linked files & docs, ensuring AI agents receive complete context for complex projects without manual file hunting or relying on the AI agent to follow links.\n\n\ud83c\udfaf Precision Context Control \u2014 Inject exact inline code snippets with line-range embeds (?md-embed=50-100) instead of dumping entire files. Get relevant context, not noise.\n\n\ud83c\udfd7\ufe0f Perfect for Complex Codebases \u2014 Ideal for large projects with custom tooling, internal libraries, or proprietary frameworks that AI models have limited training data for. Provide the context they need to understand your unique architecture.", "readme": "", "tools": [{"name": "get_relevant_docs", "description": "Get relevant markdown docs inside this project before answering the user's query to help you reply based on more context.\n\n      # Usage Instructions\n\n## When to use \"get_relevant_docs\" tool\n\n*   You **must** call the \"get_relevant_docs\" MCP tool before providing your first response in any new chat session.\n*   After the initial call in a chat, you should **only** call \"get_relevant_docs\" again if one of these specific situations occurs:\n    *   The user explicitly requests it.\n    *   The user attaches new files.\n    *   The user's query introduces a completely new topic unrelated to the previous discussion.\n\n## How to use \"get_relevant_docs\" tool\n\n*   \"attachedFiles\": ALWAYS include file paths the user has attached in their query.\n*   \"projectDocs\"\n    *   ONLY include project docs that are VERY RELEVANT to user's query.\n    *   You must have a high confidence when picking docs that may be relevant.\n    *   If the user's query is a generic question unrelated to this specific project, leave this empty.\n    *   Always heavily bias towards leaving this empty.", "inputSchema": {"type": "object", "$schema": "http://json-schema.org/draft-07/schema#", "properties": {"projectDocs": {"type": "array", "items": {"enum": [], "type": "string"}, "description": "A list of docs by their description in the project."}, "attachedFiles": {"type": "array", "items": {"type": "string", "description": "The file path to attach"}, "description": "A list of file paths included in the user's query."}}, "additionalProperties": false}, "source": "smithery", "access_level": "read"}, {"name": "reindex_docs", "description": "Reindex the docs. {'raw_input': 'ONLY RESPOND WITH JSON. NO EXPLANATIONS. NO MARKDOWN. NO TEXT OUTSIDE JSON.

Analyze the MCP server for financial relevance. Look for keywords: payment, banking, credit, loan, finance, money, currency, crypto, investment, trading, portfolio, market, exchange, wallet, account, budget, expense, income, tax, invoice, billing, accounting, insurance, compliance, KYC, AML.

JSON FORMAT (NOTHING ELSE):
{
  "server_name": "string",
  "server_id": "string", 
  "is_finance_llm": "yes|no|unclear",
  "confidence": "high|medium|low",
  "threat_models": [],
  "analysis_notes": "Brief reason"
}

If financial keywords found: is_finance_llm="yes". If not: is_finance_llm="no". If unclear: is_finance_llm="unclear".

RESPOND ONLY WITH JSON.

MCP Server Data:
{"server_name": "COTI Blockchain MCP Server", "server_id": "@davibauer/coti-mcp", "description": "This tool lets you play with the COTI blockchain right from your AI assistant.", "readme": "", "tools": [{"name": "change_default_account", "description": "Change the default account used for COTI blockchain operations. This allows switching between different accounts configured in the environment. The account must be configured in the environment variables with corresponding private and AES keys. Returns the new default account address upon successful change.", "inputSchema": {"type": "object", "required": ["account_address"], "properties": {"account_address": {"type": "string", "description": "COTI account address to set as default, e.g., 0x0D7C5C1DA069fd7C1fAFBeb922482B2C7B15D273"}}}, "source": "smithery", "access_level": "write"}, {"name": "create_account", "description": "Create a new COTI account with a randomly generated private key and AES key. Returns the new account address, private key, and AES key.", "inputSchema": {"type": "object", "properties": {"set_as_default": {"type": "boolean", "description": "Optional, whether to set the new account as the default account. Default is false."}}}, "source": "smithery", "access_level": "write"}, {"name": "decrypt_value", "description": "Decrypt a value using the COTI AES key. Requires a ciphertext as input. Returns the decrypted value.", "inputSchema": {"type": "object", "required": ["ciphertext"], "properties": {"ciphertext": {"type": "string", "description": "Ciphertext to decrypt"}}}, "source": "smithery", "access_level": "read"}, {"name": "encrypt_value", "description": "Encrypt a value using the COTI AES key. This is used for encrypting values to be sent to another address. Requires a value, contract address, and function selector as input. Returns the signature.", "inputSchema": {"type": "object", "required": ["message", "contract_address", "function_selector"], "properties": {"message": {"type": "string", "description": "Message to encrypt"}, "contract_address": {"type": "string", "description": "Contract address"}, "function_selector": {"type": "string", "description": "Function selector. To get the function selector, use the keccak256 hash of the function signature. For instance, for the transfer function of an ERC20 token, the function selector is '0xa9059cbb'."}}}, "source": "smithery", "access_level": "write"}, {"name": "export_accounts", "description": "Backup all available COTI accounts and export them as a JSON string for future import. Returns a JSON string that can be copied and used for importing later.", "inputSchema": {"type": "object", "properties": {"account_addresses": {"type": "array", "items": {"type": "string"}, "description": "Optional list of account addresses to export. If not provided, all accounts will be exported."}, "include_sensitive_data": {"type": "boolean", "description": "Whether to include sensitive data (private keys and AES keys) in the output. Default is true."}}}, "source": "smithery", "access_level": "write"}, {"name": "generate_aes_key", "description": "Generate a new AES key for the current account. Returns the AES key.", "inputSchema": {"type": "object", "properties": {"account_address": {"type": "string", "description": "The address of the account to generate the AES key for."}}}, "source": "smithery", "access_level": "write"}, {"name": "import_accounts", "description": "Import COTI accounts from a JSON backup string previously created with the export_accounts tool.", "inputSchema": {"type": "object", "required": ["backup_data"], "properties": {"backup_data": {"type": "string", "description": "The JSON backup string containing the accounts to import. Example:\n\n{\n    \"timestamp\": \"2025-06-03T17:18:55.123Z\",\n    \"accounts\": [\n        {\n            \"address\": \"0x123...\",\n            \"private_key\": \"0x456...\",\n            \"aes_key\": \"0x789...\",\n            \"is_default\": true\n        },\n        ...\n    ]\n}\n"}, "merge_with_existing": {"type": "boolean", "description": "Whether to merge with existing accounts or replace them. Default is true (merge)."}, "set_default_account": {"type": "string", "description": "Optional address to set as the default account after import. If not provided, will use the default from the backup."}}}, "source": "smithery", "access_level": "write"}, {"name": "list_accounts", "description": "List all available COTI accounts configured in the environment. Returns the account addresses, current default account, and masked versions of the private and AES keys.", "inputSchema": {"type": "object", "properties": {}}, "source": "smithery", "access_level": "write"}, {"name": "sign_message", "description": "Sign a message using the COTI private key. This creates a cryptographic signature that proves the message was signed by the owner of the private key. Requires a message to sign as input. Returns the signature.", "inputSchema": {"type": "object", "required": ["message"], "properties": {"message": {"type": "string", "description": "Message to sign"}}}, "source": "smithery", "access_level": "write"}, {"name": "verify_signature", "description": "Verify a message signature and recover the address that signed it. Analyze the MCP server for financial relevance. Look for keywords: payment, banking, credit, loan, finance, money, currency, crypto, investment, trading, portfolio, market, exchange, wallet, account, budget, expense, income, tax, invoice, billing, accounting, insurance, compliance, KYC, AML.

JSON FORMAT (NOTHING ELSE):
{
  "server_name": "string",
  "server_id": "string", 
  "is_finance_llm": "yes|no|unclear",
  "confidence": "high|medium|low",
  "threat_models": [],
  "analysis_notes": "Brief reason"
}

If financial keywords found: is_finance_llm="yes". If not: is_finance_llm="no". If unclear: is_finance_llm="unclear".

{'raw_input': 'ONLY RESPOND WITH JSON. NO EXPLANATIONS. NO MARKDOWN. NO TEXT OUTSIDE JSON.

Analyze the MCP server for financial relevance. Look for keywords: payment, banking, credit, loan, finance, money, currency, crypto, investment, trading, portfolio, market, exchange, wallet, account, budget, expense, income, tax, invoice, billing, accounting, insurance, compliance, KYC, AML.

JSON FORMAT (NOTHING ELSE):
{
  "server_name": "string",
  "server_id": "string", 
  "is_finance_llm": "yes|no|unclear",
  "confidence": "high|medium|low",
  "threat_models": [],
  "analysis_notes": "Brief reason"
}

If financial keywords found: is_finance_llm="yes". If not: is_finance_llm="no". If unclear: is_finance_llm="unclear".

RESPOND ONLY WITH JSON.

MCP Server Data:
{"server_name": "Blockscout MCP Server", "server_id": "@blockscout/mcp-server", "description": "Provide AI agents and automation tools with contextual access to blockchain data including balances, tokens, NFTs, and contract metadata. Enable multi-chain support and deliver enhanced user experience with progress notifications for long-running queries. Facilitate seamless integration with AI hosts like Claude Desktop for blockchain data analysis.", "readme": "", "tools": [{"name": "__get_instructions__", "description": "\n    This tool MUST be called BEFORE any other tool.\n    Without calling it, the MCP server will not work as expected.\n    It MUST be called once in a session.\n    ", "inputSchema": {"type": "object", "title": "__get_instructions__Arguments", "properties": {}}, "source": "smithery", "access_level": "read"}, {"name": "get_block_info", "description": "\n    Get block information like timestamp, gas used, burnt fees, transaction count etc.\n    Can optionally include the list of transaction hashes contained in the block. Transaction hashes are omitted by default; request them only when you truly need them, because on high-traffic chains the list may exhaust the context.\n    ", "inputSchema": {"type": "object", "title": "get_block_infoArguments", "required": ["chain_id", "number_or_hash"], "properties": {"chain_id": {"type": "string", "title": "Chain Id", "description": "The ID of the blockchain"}, "number_or_hash": {"type": "string", "title": "Number Or Hash", "description": "Block number or hash"}, "include_transactions": {"anyOf": [{"type": "boolean"}, {"type": "null"}], "title": "Include Transactions", "default": false, "description": "If true, includes a list of transaction hashes from the block."}}}, "source": "smithery", "access_level": "read"}, {"name": "get_latest_block", "description": "\n    Get the latest indexed block number and timestamp, which represents the most recent state of the blockchain. \n    No transactions or token transfers can exist beyond this point, making it useful as a reference timestamp for other API calls.\n    ", "inputSchema": {"type": "object", "title": "get_latest_blockArguments", "required": ["chain_id"], "properties": {"chain_id": {"type": "string", "title": "Chain Id", "description": "The ID of the blockchain"}}}, "source": "smithery", "access_level": "read"}, {"name": "get_address_by_ens_name", "description": "\n    Useful for when you need to convert an ENS domain name (e.g. \"blockscout.eth\")\n    to its corresponding Ethereum address.\n    ", "inputSchema": {"type": "object", "title": "get_address_by_ens_nameArguments", "required": ["name"], "properties": {"name": {"type": "string", "title": "Name", "description": "ENS domain name to resolve"}}}, "source": "smithery", "access_level": "write"}, {"name": "get_transactions_by_address", "description": "\n    Get transactions for an address within a specific time range.\n    Use cases:\n      - `get_transactions_by_address(address, age_from)` - get all transactions to/from the address since the given date up to the current time\n      - `get_transactions_by_address(address, age_from, age_to)` - get all transactions to/from the address between the given dates\n      - `get_transactions_by_address(address, age_from, age_to, methods)` - get all transactions to/from the address between the given dates and invoking the given method signature\n    Manipulating `age_from` and `age_to` allows you to paginate through results by time ranges.\n    ", "inputSchema": {"type": "object", "title": "get_transactions_by_addressArguments", "required": ["chain_id", "address"], "properties": {"age_to": {"anyOf": [{"type": "string"}, {"type": "null"}], "title": "Age To", "default": null, "description": "End date and time (e.g 2025-05-22T22:30:00.00Z)."}, "address": {"type": "string", "title": "Address", "description": "Address which either sender or receiver of the transaction"}, "methods": {"anyOf": [{"type": "string"}, {"type": "null"}], "title": "Methods", "default": null, "description": "A method signature to filter transactions by (e.g 0x304e6ade)"}, "age_from": {"anyOf": [{"type": "string"}, {"type": "null"}], "title": "Age From", "default": null, "description": "Start date and time (e.g 2025-05-22T23:00:00.00Z)."}, "chain_id": {"type": "string", "title": "Chain Id", "description": "The ID of the blockchain"}}}, "source": "smithery", "access_level": "write"}, {"name": "get_token_transfers_by_address", "description": "\n    Get ERC-20 token transfers for an address within a specific time range.\n    Use cases:\n      - `get_token_transfers_by_address(address, age_from)` - get all transfers of any ERC-20 token to/from the address since the given date up to the current time\n      - `get_token_transfers_by_address(address, age_from, age_to)` - get all transfers of any ERC-20 token to/from the address between the given dates\n      - `get_token_transfers_by_address(address, age_from, age_to, token)` - get all transfers of the given ERC-20 token to/from the address between the given dates\n    Manipulating `age_from` and `age_to` allows you to paginate through results by time ranges. MCP Server Data: {"server_name": "Heurist Mesh network", "server_id": "heurist-network/heurist-agent-framework", "description": "[Heurist Mesh Agent](https://github.com/heurist-network/heurist-mesh-mcp-server) - Access specialized web3 AI agents for blockchain analysis, smart contract security, token metrics, and blockchain interactions through the [Heurist Mesh network](https://github.com/heurist-network/heurist-agent-framework/tree/main/mesh).", "readme": "
\n \n
\n\n# Heurist Agent Framework\n\nA flexible multi-interface AI agent framework that can interact through various platforms including Telegram, Discord, Twitter, Farcaster, REST API, and MCP.\n\nGrab a Heurist API Key instantly for free by using the code 'agent' while submitting the form on https://heurist.ai/dev-access\n\n---\n\n## Overview\n\nThe Heurist Agent Framework is built on a modular architecture that allows an AI agent to:\n\n- Process text and voice messages\n- Generate images and videos\n- Interact across multiple platforms with consistent behavior\n- Fetch and store information in a knowledge base (Postgres and SQLite supported)\n- Access external APIs, tools, and a wide range of [Mesh Agents](./mesh/README.md) to compose complex workflows\n\n## Table of Contents\n\n- [Features](#features)\n- [Heurist Mesh](#heurist-mesh)\n - [MCP Support](#mcp-support)\n - [Recommended Mesh Agents](#recommended-mesh-agents)\n - [Full List of Mesh Agents](#full-list-of-mesh-agents)\n - [Usage and Development Guide](#usage-and-development-guide)\n- [Heurist Agent Framework Architecture](#heurist-agent-framework-architecture)\n - [Agent Structure](#agent-structure)\n - [Agent Interfaces](#agent-interfaces)\n - [Heurist Core](#heurist-core)\n - [Components](#components)\n - [Workflows](#workflows)\n - [Tool Management](#tool-management)\n - [External Clients](#external-clients)\n - [Agent Usage and Development Guide](#agent-usage-and-development-guide)\n- [Development Setup](#development-setup)\n- [How to Use GitHub Issues](#how-to-use-github-issues)\n- [License](#license)\n- [Contributing](#contributing)\n- [Support](#support)\n- [Star History](#star-history)\n\n## Features\n\n- \ud83e\udd16 **Core Agent** - Modular framework with advanced LLM integration\n- \ud83e\udde9 **Component Architecture** - Plug-and-play components for flexible agent or agentic application design\n- \ud83d\udd04 **Workflow System** - RAG, Chain of Thought, and Research workflows\n- \ud83d\uddbc\ufe0f **Media Generation** - Image creation and processing capabilities\n- \ud83c\udfa4 **Voice Processing** - Audio transcription and text-to-speech\n- \ud83d\udcbe **Vector Storage** - Knowledge retrieval with PostgreSQL/SQLite support\n- \ud83d\udee0\ufe0f **Tool Integration** - Extensible tool framework with MCP support\n- \ud83c\udf10 **Mesh Agent Access** - Connect to community-contributed specialized agents via API or MCP\n- \ud83d\udd0c **Multi-platform Support**:\n - Telegram bot\n - Discord bot\n - Twitter automation\n - Farcaster integration\n - REST API\n - MCP integration\n\n## Heurist Mesh\n\n![mesh](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/77a2ab3b-e35c-4313-8a5b-a0e751cac879)\n\n**Heurist Mesh** is an open network where AI agents are contributed by the community and used modularly\u2014similar to DeFi smart contracts. Each agent is a specialized unit that can process data, generate reports, or perform actions while collectively forming an intelligent swarm to tackle complex tasks. Each agent is accessible via a unified REST API interface, and can be used in conjunction with any agent framework or application.\n\nWant to contribute your own agent? Check out the [Mesh README](./mesh/README.md) for detailed guidelines, examples, and best practices.\n\n### MCP Support\n\n**Just In:** All Heurist Mesh agents are accessible via MCP! This means you can access them from your favorite MCP client, including [Claude Desktop](https://claude.ai/download), [Cursor](https://www.cursor.com/), and [Windsurf](https://codeium.com/windsurf).\n\nHead to [heurist-mesh-mcp-server](https://github.com/heurist-network/heurist-mesh-mcp-server) to set up a server and give your AI assistant a powerup.\n\n### Recommended Mesh Agents\n\n\u2022 [BitquerySolanaTokenInfoAgent](./mesh/agents/bitquery_solana_token_info_agent.py) - Provides comprehensive analysis of Solana tokens including metrics, holders, trading activity, and trending token discovery\n\n\u2022 [CoinGeckoTokenInfoAgent](./mesh/agents/coingecko_token_info_agent.py) - Fetches token information, market data, trending coins, and category data from CoinGecko\n\n\u2022 [DexScreenerTokenInfoAgent](./mesh/agents/dexscreener_token_info_agent.py) - Fetches real-time DEX trading data and token information across multiple chains\n\n\u2022 [ElfaTwitterIntelligenceAgent](./mesh/agents/elfa_twitter_intelligence_agent.py) - Analyzes tokens, topics or Twitter accounts using Twitter data, highlighting smart influencers\n\n\u2022 [ExaSearchAgent](./mesh/agents/exa_search_agent.py) - Searches the web and provides direct answers to questions\n\n\u2022 [GoplusAnalysisAgent](./mesh/agents/goplus_analysis_agent.py) - Fetches and analyzes security details of blockchain token contracts\n\n\u2022 [MetaSleuthSolTokenWalletClusterAgent](./mesh/agents/metasleuth_sol_token_wallet_cluster_agent.py) - Analyzes wallet clusters holding Solana tokens to identify holder behavior, concentration, and potential market manipulation\n\n\u2022 [PumpFunTokenAgent](./mesh/agents/pumpfun_token_agent.py) - Analyzes Pump.fun toke\n[...truncated for length...]", "tools": [], "tools_count": 0, "homepage": "", "url": "https://github.com/heurist-network/heurist-agent-framework/tree/main/mesh", "topics": ["agentic-framework", "ai", "mcp", "agentic-ai"], "data_sources": ["official"]}'}

\n\n[![License](https://img.shields.io/badge/license-Apache%202-blue.svg)](LICENSE)\n![Supported Python versions](https://img.shields.io/badge/python-3.9+-orange.svg)\n![Supported OSs](https://img.shields.io/badge/os-linux%2C%20win%2C%20mac-yellow.svg)\n

\n\n\n## \u4ec0\u4e48\u662fAppBuilder-SDK\n\n\u767e\u5ea6\u667a\u80fd\u4e91\u5343\u5e06AppBuilder-SDK\u662f[\u767e\u5ea6\u667a\u80fd\u4e91\u5343\u5e06AppBuilder](https://appbuilder.cloud.baidu.com/)\u9762\u5411AI\u539f\u751f\u5e94\u7528\u5f00\u53d1\u8005\u63d0\u4f9b\u7684\u4e00\u7ad9\u5f0f\u5f00\u53d1\u5e73\u53f0\u7684\u5ba2\u6237\u7aefSDK\u3002\n\n### AppBuilder-SDK \u6709\u54ea\u4e9b\u529f\u80fd\uff1f\n\n\u767e\u5ea6\u667a\u80fd\u4e91\u5343\u5e06AppBuilder-SDK\u63d0\u4f9b\u4e86\u4ee5\u4e0bAI\u5e94\u7528\u5f00\u53d1\u8005\u7684\u5fc5\u5907\u529f\u80fd\uff1a\n\n- **\u8c03\u7528**\n - \u8c03\u7528\u5927\u6a21\u578b\uff0c\u53ef\u81ea\u7531\u8c03\u7528\u60a8\u5728[\u767e\u5ea6\u667a\u80fd\u4e91\u5343\u5e06\u5927\u6a21\u578b\u5e73\u53f0](https://qianfan.cloud.baidu.com/)\u7684\u6a21\u578b\uff0c\u5f00\u53d1\u5e76\u8c03\u4f18prompt\n - \u8c03\u7528\u80fd\u529b\u7ec4\u4ef6\uff0c\u63d0\u4f9b40+\u4e2a\u6e90\u4e8e\u767e\u5ea6\u751f\u6001\u7684[\u4f18\u8d28\u7ec4\u4ef6](https://cloud.baidu.com/doc/AppBuilder/s/Glqb6dfiz#3%E3%80%81%E5%BC%80%E9%80%9A%E7%BB%84%E4%BB%B6%E6%9C%8D%E5%8A%A1)\uff0c\u8d4b\u80fdAgent\u5e94\u7528\n - \u8c03\u7528AI\u539f\u751f\u5e94\u7528\uff0c\u901a\u8fc7[AppBuilderClient](/docs/BasisModule/Platform/Application/appbuilder_client.md)\u53ef\u8bbf\u95ee\u5e76\u7ba1\u7406\u5728\u767e\u5ea6\u667a\u80fd\u4e91\u5343\u5e06AppBuilder[\u7f51\u9875\u7aef](https://console.bce.baidu.com/ai_apaas/app)\u53d1\u5e03\u7684AI\u539f\u751f\u5e94\u7528\uff0c\u5e76\u53ef\u6ce8\u518c\u672c\u5730\u51fd\u6570\u8054\u52a8\u7aef\u4e91\u7ec4\u4ef6\n- **\u7f16\u6392**\n - \u914d\u7f6e\u77e5\u8bc6\u5e93\uff0c\u901a\u8fc7[KnowledgeBase](/docs/BasisModule/Platform/KnowledgeBase/knowledgebase.md)\u7ba1\u7406\u77e5\u8bc6\u5e93\uff0c\u8fdb\u884c\u6587\u6863\u53ca\u77e5\u8bc6\u5207\u7247\u7684\u589e\u5220\u6539\u67e5\uff0c\u914d\u5408[\u7f51\u9875\u7aef](https://console.bce.baidu.com/ai_apaas/app)\u5f00\u53d1\u4ea7\u4e1a\u7ea7\u7684`RAG`\u5e94\u7528\n - \u7f16\u6392\u5de5\u4f5c\u6d41\uff0c\u63d0\u4f9b\u4e86`Message`\u3001`Component`\u3001`AgentRuntime`\u591a\u7ea7\u5de5\u4f5c\u6d41\u62bd\u8c61\uff0c\u5b9e\u73b0\u5de5\u4f5c\u6d41\u7f16\u6392\uff0c\u5e76\u53ef\u4e0eLangChain\u3001OpenAI\u7b49\u4e1a\u754c\u751f\u6001\u80fd\u529b\u6253\u901a\n- **\u76d1\u63a7**\n - \u63d0\u4f9b\u4e86\u53ef\u89c6\u5316Tracing\u3001\u8be6\u7ec6DebugLog\u7b49\u76d1\u63a7\u5de5\u5177\uff0c\u52a9\u529b\u5f00\u53d1\u8005\u5728\u751f\u4ea7\u73af\u5883\u5e94\u7528\n- **\u90e8\u7f72**\n - `AgentRuntime`\u652f\u6301\u90e8\u7f72\u4e3a\u57fa\u4e8e`Flask`\u4e0e`gunicorn`\u7684API\u670d\u52a1\n - `AgentRuntime`\u652f\u6301\u90e8\u7f72\u4e3a\u57fa\u4e8e`Chainlit`\u7684\u5bf9\u8bdd\u6846\u4ea4\u4e92\u524d\u7aef\n - \u63d0\u4f9b\u4e86`appbuilder_bce_deploy`\u5de5\u5177\uff0c\u53ef\u5feb\u901f\u90e8\u7f72\u7a0b\u5e8f\u5230\u767e\u5ea6\u4e91\uff0c\u63d0\u4f9b\u516c\u7f51API\u670d\u52a1\uff0c\u8054\u52a8AppBuilder\u5de5\u4f5c\u6d41\n\n### \u4f7f\u7528 AppBuilder-SDK \u53ef\u4ee5\u6784\u5efa\u4ec0\u4e48\u5e94\u7528\uff1f\n\n#### **\u4ea7\u4e1a\u7ea7RAG\u5e94\u7528**\n\nAppBuilder-SDK\u63d0\u4f9b\u591a\u7c7b\u578b\u7ec4\u4ef6\uff0c\u8986\u76d6\u4ee5\u4e0b\u6784\u5efa\u4ea7\u4e1a\u7ea7`RAG`\u5e94\u7528\u7684\u5b8c\u6574\u6b65\u9aa4\uff1a\n- MCP Server Data: {"server_name": "Wren Engine", "server_id": "canner/wren-engine", "description": "The Semantic Engine for Model Context Protocol(MCP) Clients and AI Agents", "readme": "

\n \n \n \n \n \n

Wren Engine

\n \n

\n\n

\n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n \n

\n\n> Wren Engine is the Semantic Engine for MCP Clients and AI Agents. \n> [Wren AI](https://github.com/Canner/WrenAI) GenBI AI Agent is based on Wren Engine.\n\n\n\n## \ud83d\udd0c Supported Data Sources\n- [BigQuery](https://docs.getwren.ai/oss/wren_engine_api#tag/BigQueryConnectionInfo)\n- [Google Cloud Storage](https://docs.getwren.ai/oss/wren_engine_api#tag/GcsFileConnectionInfo)\n- [Local Files](https://docs.getwren.ai/oss/wren_engine_api#tag/LocalFileConnectionInfo)\n- [MS SQL Server](https://docs.getwren.ai/oss/wren_engine_api#tag/MSSqlConnectionInfo)\n- [Minio](https://docs.getwren.ai/oss/wren_engine_api#tag/MinioFileConnectionInfo)\n- [MySQL Server](https://docs.getwren.ai/oss/wren_engine_api#tag/MySqlConnectionInfo)\n- [Oracle Server](https://docs.getwren.ai/oss/wren_engine_api#tag/OracleConnectionInfo)\n- [PostgreSQL Server](https://docs.getwren.ai/oss/wren_engine_api#tag/PostgresConnectionInfo)\n- [Amazon S3](https://docs.getwren.ai/oss/wren_engine_api#tag/S3FileConnectionInfo)\n- [Snowflake](https://docs.getwren.ai/oss/wren_engine_api#tag/SnowflakeConnectionInfo)\n- [Trino](https://docs.getwren.ai/oss/wren_engine_api#tag/TrinoConnectionInfo)\n\n## \ud83d\ude2b Challenge Today\n\nAt the enterprise level, the stakes\u200a-\u200aand the complexity\u200a-\u200aare much higher. Businesses run on structured data stored in cloud warehouses, relational databases, and secure filesystems. From BI dashboards to CRM updates and compliance workflows, AI must not only execute commands but also **understand and retrieve the right data, with precision and in context**.\n\nWhile many community and official MCP servers already support connections to major databases like PostgreSQL, MySQL, SQL Server, and more, there's a problem: **raw access to data isn't enough**.\n\nEnterprises need:\n- Accurate semantic understanding of their data models\n- Trusted calculations and aggregations in reporting\n- Clarity on business terms, like \"active customer,\" \"net revenue,\" or \"churn rate\"\n- User-based permissions and access control\n\nNatural language alone isn't enough to drive complex workflows across enterprise data systems. You need a layer that interprets intent, maps it to the correct data, applies calculations accurately, and ensures security.\n\n## \ud83c\udfaf Our Mission\n\n\n\nWren Engine is on a mission to power the future of MCP clients and AI agents through the Model Context Protocol (MCP) \u2014 a new open standard that connects LLMs with tools, databases, and enterprise systems.\n\nAs part of the MCP ecosystem, Wren Engine provides a **semantic engine** powered the next generation semantic layer that enables AI agents to access business data with accuracy, context, and governance. \n\nBy building the semantic layer directly into MCP clients, such as Claude, Cline, Cursor, etc. Wren Engine empowers AI Agents with precise business context and ensures accurate data interactions across diverse enterprise environments.\n\nWe believe the future of enterprise AI lies in **context-aware, composable systems**. That\u2019s why Wren Engine is designed to be:\n\n- \ud83d\udd0c **Embeddable** into any MCP client or AI agentic workflow\n- \ud83d\udd04 **Interoperable** with modern data stacks (PostgreSQL, MySQL, Snowflake, etc.)\n- \ud83e\udde0 **Semantic-first**, enabling AI to \u201cunderstand\u201d your data model and business logic\n- \ud83d\udd10 **Governance-ready**, respecting roles, access controls, and definitions\n\nWith Wren Engine, you can scale AI adoption across teams \u2014 not just with better automation, but with better understanding.\n\n***Check our full article***\n\n\ud83e\udd29 [Our Mission - Fueling the Next Wave of AI Agents: Building the Foundation for Future MCP Clients and Enterprise Data Access](https://getwren.ai/post/fueling-the-next-wave-of-ai-agents-building-the-foundation-for-future-mcp-clients-and-enterprise-data-access)\n\n## \ud83d\ude80 Get Started with MCP \n[MCP Server README](mcp-server/README.md)\n\nhttps:\n[...truncated for length...]", "tools": [], "tools_count": 0, "homepage": "", "url": "https://github.com/Canner/wren-engine", "topics": ["business-intelligence", "data", "data-analysis", "data-analytics", "data-lake", "data-warehouse", "sql", "semantic", "semantic-layer", "llm", "hacktoberfest", "agent", "agentic-ai", "ai", "mcp", "mcp-server"], "data_sources": ["official"]}'}

{'server_name': 'brlaw_mcp_server', 'server_id': 'pdmtt/brlaw_mcp_server', 'description': 'A MCP (Model Context Protocol) server for agent-driven research on Brazilian law', 'readme': '# Brazilian Law Research MCP Server

[üáßüá∑ Leia em portugu√™s](README.br.md)

A MCP (Model Context Protocol) server for agent-driven research on Brazilian law.

## Requirements

- git
- uv (recommended) or Python >= 3.11
- Google Chrome

## How to use

1. Clone the repository:
```bash
git clone https://github.com/pdmtt/brlaw_mcp_server.git
```

2. Install the dependencies
```bash
uv run patchright install
```

3. Setup your MCP client (e.g. Claude Desktop):
```json
{
  "mcpServers": {
    "brlaw_mcp_server": {
      "command": "uv",
      "args": [
        "--directory",
        "/<path>/brlaw_mcp_server",
        "run",
        "serve"
      ]
    }
  }
}
```

### Available Tools

- `StjLegalPrecedentsRequest`: Research legal precedents made by the National High Court of Brazil 
  (STJ) that meet the specified criteria.
- `TstLegalPrecedentsRequest`: Research legal precedents made by the National High Labor Court of 
  Brazil (TST) that meet the specified criteria.

## Development

### Tooling

The project uses:
- Ruff for linting and formatting.
- BasedPyright for type checking.
- Pytest for testing.

### Language

Resources, tools and prompts related stuff must be written in Portuguese, because this project aims 
to be used by non-dev folks, such as lawyers and law students. 

Technical legal vocabulary is highly dependent on a country's legal tradition and translating it is 
no trivial task.

Development related stuff should stick to English as conventional, such as source code.

## License

This project is licensed under the MIT License - see the LICENSE file for details.', 'tools': [{'name': 'StjLegalPrecedentsRequest', 'description': 'Research legal precedents made by the National High Court of Brazil', 'inputSchema': {'type': 'object', 'properties': {'query': {'type': 'string', 'description': 'Search query or term'}}, 'required': ['query']}, 'source': 'readme', 'access_level': 'read'}, {'name': 'TstLegalPrecedentsRequest', 'description': 'Research legal precedents made by the National High Labor Court of', 'inputSchema': {'type': 'object', 'properties': {'query': {'type': 'string', 'description': 'Search query or term'}}, 'required': ['query']}, 'source': 'readme', 'access_level': 'read'}], 'tools_count': 2, 'homepage': '', 'url': 'https://github.com/pdmtt/brlaw_mcp_server', 'topics': [], 'data_sources': ['github']}
raw_output:
# Brazilian Law Research MCP Server

This is a specialized MCP (Model Context Protocol) server designed for researching Brazilian legal precedents. It provides access to decisions from Brazil's highest courts through automated research tools.

## Key Features

- **STJ Legal Precedents**: Search through decisions from Brazil's Superior Tribunal de Justi√ßa (National High Court)
- **TST Legal Precedents**: Research rulings from the Tribunal Superior do Trabalho (National High Labor Court)
- **Agent-Driven Research**: Designed to work with AI agents for comprehensive legal research

## Available Tools

### StjLegalPrecedentsRequest
Research legal precedents from Brazil's Superior Tribunal de Justi√ßa (STJ). This tool allows you to search through the court's decisions using specific queries or legal terms.

**Input**: Search query or legal term
**Use Case**: Finding relevant case law and legal precedents from Brazil's highest court for civil, criminal, and administrative matters

### TstLegalPrecedentsRequest
Research legal precedents from Brazil's Tribunal Superior do Trabalho (TST). This tool focuses on labor law decisions and employment-related legal precedents.

**Input**: Search query or legal term
**Use Case**: Finding labor law precedents, employment dispute resolutions, and workplace regulation interpretations

## Setup Requirements

- Git
- Python 3.11+ (or uv package manager)
- Google Chrome (for web scraping functionality)

## Target Users

This server is specifically designed for:
- Brazilian lawyers and legal professionals
- Law students studying Brazilian jurisprudence
- Legal researchers focusing on Brazilian case law
- AI agents performing legal research tasks

The tool maintains Portuguese language support for legal terminology, recognizing that Brazilian legal concepts don't translate directly and require native language precision.

**Repository**: https://github.com/pdmtt/brlaw_mcp_server

{'server_name': 'awesome-a2a', 'server_id': 'marius12-oss/awesome-a2a', 'description': 'Agent2Agent (A2A) ‚Äì awesome A2A agents, tools, servers & clients, all in one place. ', 'readme': "# Awesome A2A üåü

![Awesome A2A](https://img.shields.io/badge/awesome--a2a-brightgreen?style=flat&logo=github)

Welcome to **Awesome A2A**! This repository is your go-to source for everything related to Agent2Agent (A2A). Here, you will find a curated collection of A2A agents, tools, servers, and clients, all in one place. Whether you're a developer, researcher, or enthusiast, this repository has something for you.

## Table of Contents

- [Introduction](#introduction)
- [Features](#features)
- [Getting Started](#getting-started)
- [Usage](#usage)
- [Contributing](#contributing)
- [License](#license)
- [Contact](#contact)
- [Releases](#releases)

## Introduction

Agent2Agent (A2A) technology allows agents to communicate with one another effectively. This can lead to enhanced collaboration, improved performance, and innovative solutions in various fields. Our aim is to gather all relevant resources and make them easily accessible to everyone interested in A2A.

## Features

- **Comprehensive Collection**: A wide range of A2A agents, tools, and servers.
- **User-Friendly**: Easy to navigate and find what you need.
- **Community Driven**: Contributions from developers and users around the world.
- **Regular Updates**: Stay current with the latest releases and improvements.

## Getting Started

To get started with Awesome A2A, follow these steps:

1. **Clone the Repository**: Use the following command to clone the repository to your local machine.

   ```bash
   git clone https://github.com/Marius12-oss/awesome-a2a.git
   ```

2. **Explore the Content**: Navigate through the repository to find agents, tools, and servers that interest you.

3. **Download and Execute Releases**: Visit the [Releases section](https://github.com/Marius12-oss/awesome-a2a/releases) to download the latest versions of the tools and agents. Follow the instructions provided in the release notes for execution.

## Usage

Once you have downloaded the necessary files, you can start using the A2A agents and tools. Each tool may have its own set of instructions, so be sure to check the documentation included in the release.

### Example

Here's a simple example of how to set up an A2A agent:

1. **Download the Agent**: Get the latest version from the [Releases section](https://github.com/Marius12-oss/awesome-a2a/releases).
2. **Install Dependencies**: Make sure you have all the required libraries installed.
3. **Run the Agent**: Use the command line to execute the agent.

```bash
./your-a2a-agent
```

### Tips

- Check the README files for each agent for specific setup instructions.
- Explore the community contributions for additional tools and enhancements.

## Contributing

We welcome contributions from everyone! If you have an A2A agent, tool, or server that you would like to add, please follow these steps:

1. **Fork the Repository**: Create your own copy of the repository.
2. **Make Your Changes**: Add your content or improve existing entries.
3. **Submit a Pull Request**: Share your changes with the community.

### Guidelines

- Ensure your contributions align with the theme of A2A.
- Keep the content clear and concise.
- Follow the existing structure of the repository.

## License

This project is licensed under the MIT License. See the [LICENSE](LICENSE) file for more details.

## Contact

For any questions or suggestions, feel free to reach out:

- **Email**: your.email@example.com
- **Twitter**: [@yourhandle](https://twitter.com/yourhandle)

## Releases

To stay updated with the latest releases, visit the [Releases section](https://github.com/Marius12-oss/awesome-a2a/releases). Here, you can download and execute the latest files to make the most out of your A2A experience.

---

Thank you for checking out Awesome A2A! We hope you find this repository useful. Happy exploring! üåê", 'tools': [], 'tools_count': 0, 'homepage': '', 'url': 'https://github.com/Marius12-oss/awesome-a2a', 'topics': ['a2a', 'agent', 'agent2agent', 'ai', 'mcp'], 'data_sources': ['github']}
raw_output:
# Awesome A2A üåü

**Agent2Agent (A2A) ‚Äì awesome A2A agents, tools, servers & clients, all in one place.**

## Overview

This is a curated collection repository focused on Agent2Agent (A2A) technology, which enables agents to communicate and collaborate effectively. The repository serves as a central hub for A2A-related resources including agents, tools, servers, and clients.

## Key Features

- **Comprehensive Collection**: Wide range of A2A agents, tools, and servers
- **User-Friendly**: Easy navigation and resource discovery
- **Community Driven**: Open to contributions from developers worldwide
- **Regular Updates**: Stay current with latest A2A developments

## Topics & Technologies

- **A2A (Agent2Agent)** - Core focus on agent-to-agent communication
- **AI Agents** - Artificial intelligence agent implementations
- **MCP (Model Context Protocol)** - Protocol implementations for agent communication

## Getting Started

1. **Clone the repository**:
   ```bash
   git clone https://github.com/Marius12-oss/awesome-a2a.git
   ```

2. **Explore resources**: Browse through the curated collection of A2A tools and agents

3. **Download releases**: Check the [releases section](https://github.com/Marius12-oss/awesome-a2a/releases) for downloadable tools and executables

## Repository Status

- **Tools Available**: Currently no MCP tools are listed in the registry
- **Community Focus**: Accepts contributions from developers and researchers
- **License**: MIT License for open collaboration

## Use Cases

This repository is valuable for:
- Developers building A2A communication systems
- Researchers exploring agent collaboration patterns
- Enthusiasts interested in multi-agent architectures
- Anyone working with agent-to-agent protocols and implementations

The repository emphasizes practical resources and executable tools rather than just theoretical concepts, making it a hands-on collection for A2A development.

{'server_name': 'eagv1-s4-mcp', 'server_id': 'milindchawre/eagv1-s4-mcp', 'description': 'MCP server for Math Agent with Microsoft Word and Gmail Integration', 'readme': '# Math Agent with Microsoft Word and Gmail Integration

A Python-based mathematical agent that solves problems iteratively using various mathematical tools and visualizes results using Microsoft Word and Gmail.

## Features

- Mathematical Operations
  - Basic arithmetic (add, subtract, multiply, divide)
  - Advanced operations (power, square root, cube root)
  - Trigonometric functions (sin, cos, tan)
  - Logarithmic calculations
  - Factorial computation
  - Fibonacci sequence generation
  - ASCII value conversion
  - Exponential sum calculations

- AI Integration
  - Google Gemini Pro model for intelligent problem-solving
  - Iterative problem-solving approach
  - Automatic tool selection and execution

- Enhanced Logging
  - Detailed execution logs
  - Debug information for tool operations
  - Error tracking and reporting
  - Comprehensive email reports with execution history

- Email Integration
  - Automatic email reports after completion
  - Detailed execution logs in email body
  - Final result summary
  - Gmail SMTP integration

- Word Integration
  - Automatic Word document creation
  - Rectangle drawing with results
  - Automated result visualization
  - Configurable text placement

## Prerequisites

- Python 3.7+
- Microsoft Word for macOS
- macOS 10.15 or later
- Google Cloud API key (for Gemini Pro)

## Installation

1. Clone the repository
2. Install dependencies:
```bash
pip3 install -r requirements.txt
```
3. Set up environment variables:

Option 1: Export in terminal (recommended for testing):
```bash
export GEMINI_API_KEY=your_api_key_here
export GMAIL_USER=your.email@gmail.com
export GMAIL_APP_PASSWORD=your16digitpassword
```
Option 2: Create a .env file:
```bash
GEMINI_API_KEY=your_api_key_here
GMAIL_USER=your.email@gmail.com
GMAIL_APP_PASSWORD=your16digitpassword
```

## Usage
Recommended Method: Run the client (automatically starts the server):
```bash
python math_agent_client.py
```
Alternative Method (for debugging): Run server and client separately:
1. Start the MCP server:
```bash
# Terminal 1
python math_agent_server.py

# Terminal 2
python math_agent_client.py
```

The agent will:

- Start the MCP server internally
- Process mathematical queries using Gemini AI
- Execute calculations using available tools
- Create a Word document with the result
- Draw a rectangle containing the final answer
- Send an email report with execution logs

## Example Queries
```plaintext
- Find the ASCII values of characters in INDIA and then return sum of exponentials of those values
- Calculate the factorial of 5
- Find the sum of first 10 Fibonacci numbers
```

## Architecture
- `math_agent_client.py` : Main client handling:
    - Gemini AI integration
    - Query processing
    - Tool execution
    - Word visualization

- `math_agent_server.py` : Server providing:
    - Mathematical tools
    - Word integration tools
    - Resource handlers

## Error Handling
- Timeout protection for AI generation
- Robust error handling for tool execution
- Automatic state reset
- Debug logging

## Logging
- All operations are logged with timestamps
- Log levels: INFO, DEBUG, ERROR
- Logs are included in email reports
- Console output for real-time monitoring

## Troubleshooting

### Email Configuration
- Ensure GMAIL_USER is your full email address
- GMAIL_APP_PASSWORD must be a 16-character app password
- Enable 2-Step Verification in your Google Account
- Check execution logs for detailed error messages

### Word Integration
- Ensure Microsoft Word is installed and running
- Allow automation permissions if prompted
- Check execution logs for any automation errors

### Common Issues
- If environment variables are not detected, try restarting your terminal
- For Word automation issues, ensure Word is not in full-screen mode
- Check console output for detailed error messages and stack traces

## Limitations
- Requires macOS environment
- Microsoft Word for macOS must be installed
- Maximum 8 iterations per problem
- Requires Google Cloud API access

raw_output:
# Math Agent with Microsoft Word and Gmail Integration

This is an impressive MCP server that combines mathematical problem-solving with AI and office automation. Here's what makes it special:

## üîß **Core Capabilities**

**Mathematical Operations:**
- Basic arithmetic and advanced functions
- Trigonometric and logarithmic calculations
- Factorial, Fibonacci sequence generation
- ASCII value conversion and exponential calculations

**AI-Powered Problem Solving:**
- Google Gemini Pro integration for intelligent analysis
- Iterative problem-solving approach
- Automatic tool selection and execution

## üöÄ **Unique Features**

**Office Integration:**
- **Microsoft Word automation** - Creates documents with visual results
- **Gmail integration** - Sends detailed execution reports via email
- **Rectangle drawing** - Visual representation of results in Word

**Advanced Logging:**
- Comprehensive execution tracking
- Debug information and error reporting
- Email reports with complete execution history

## üí° **Perfect For**

- **Educational tools** requiring mathematical computation and reporting
- **Automated documentation** of mathematical processes
- **Business applications** needing calculation results in professional formats
- **Research workflows** requiring both computation and communication

## üõ† **Setup Requirements**

- macOS 10.15+ with Microsoft Word
- Google Cloud API key for Gemini Pro
- Gmail app password for email integration
- Python 3.7+

## üìù **Example Workflow**

1. Submit complex mathematical query
2. AI analyzes and breaks down the problem
3. Mathematical tools execute calculations
4. Results are formatted in a Word document
5. Detailed report is emailed automatically

This server excellently demonstrates how MCP can bridge AI capabilities with traditional office applications, making it valuable for educational, business, and research applications that need both computation and professional documentation.

**Repository:** https://github.com/milindchawre/eagv1-s4-mcp
